PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Concert Tours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of the city of Tamworth, New South Wales, respectfully showeth:
a. that there is a very limited range of cultural provisions for rural areas;
b. that the provision of ABC Concerts significantly enriches the options available to rural residents;
c. that regional centres permit residents of wide country areas to attend concerts when they would not be able to journey to the metropolitan areas;
d. that the youth of country areas have an equal right to access to visits by outstanding musicians and should not be disadvantaged;
e. that significant savings could be effected without the complete elimination of the country concert program;
f. complete elimination in the Bicentennial year would be a retrograde step.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Broadcasting Commission be asked to continue its provision of country concert tours by leading artists.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of X-rated videos into the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.
2. The Government has ignored the repeated protests of the Senate and the people of Canberra on this situation.
3. As a result X-rated videos are being sold from Canberra to other States, although they are banned in all States.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government to ban the importation and sale of X-rated video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Pirie Education Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. has for twelve years fulfilled a wide range of educational needs among underprivileged and isolated rural people in the upper north of South Australia:
that the Federal Government's withdrawal of base grant funding will in effect cause the Centre to close at the end of 1987:

that Federal Government managerial incompetence is evident in deciding to cause the closure of the Centre at the same time as approving a Community Employment Program grant of approximately $50,000 to upgrade the Centre's grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

that the Federal Government will restore base grant funding for 1988 and beyond to ensure that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. can continue to provide its wide range of educational services to the people of the upper north of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of individual liberty.
2. We reject the notion that the government can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation and state categorically it does not reflect our will.
3. We believe that, as with the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, the government's methods and arguments in promoting this legislation have been under-handed and undemocratic.

4. We believe as a matter of faith and judgement that the proposed legislation is anti-God and that its implementation will result in further attacks on individual freedom and responsibility, the family and the Church and that the real intent is the promotion of a powerful secular humanist ``big brother'' government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should together with the House of Representatives take action to reject this proposed legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information, will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Satellite Base, Geraldton, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia strongly urge the Australian Government to give more accurate information of the proposed Satellite Base. Department of Administrative Services employees, Ross Temple, in charge, and Collin Ekert; and Civil Engineer in Housing and Construction, Mark Appelt, all stated a projected cost of 300 million dollars for this Base. —by leave-I wish to make a brief statement regarding one of the notices of motion which was just withdrawn. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES (CONVERSION TO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to the conversion of the Australian National Airlines Commission to a public company, to repeal all but certain provisions of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945, and for other purposes.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In my statement outlining the Government's domestic aviation policy, which I tabled on 7 October 1987, I indicated that the Government would serve the required three years notice to terminate the Airlines Agreement with effect from 1990. Following agreement of both Houses of Parliament, notice of termination of the Agreement was issued on 30 October 1987. An essential element of the deregulated environment after termination of the Two Airlines Agreement will be a strong, viable and efficient Australian Airlines which will be able to provide effective competition across the trunk route network.

The Bill now before the Senate represents an important first step in the process of preparing Australia for its future role by: establishing the airline as a public company; providing for re-organisation of the airline into a more appropriate structure prior to incorporation; and removing detailed Government controls on the airline's operations. The legislation will establish the airline as a company in the most efficient way possible, by providing for the Commission to be deemed to be a company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981 on a day to be proclaimed.

Secondly, the legislation provides for a re-organisation of the Commission prior to deeming. The Commission is seeking to establish a group structure which provides it with maximum flexibility to prepare for the more competitive environment facing the airline over the next few years and following deregulation. The legislation therefore makes provision for the re-organisation of the Commission prior to incorporation to ensure that the new company can operate from the outset on a proper commercial basis.

Thirdly, the legislation provides for removal of existing statutory controls on the airline which are embodied in the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 through deletion of all substantive sections of that Act. The removal of these statutory controls will occur at the time of deeming the airline to be a company. As I announced previously, the Government is giving consideration to the scope for removal of other broader controls, such as subsection of borrowings to Loan Council, in the context of the Structural Adjustment Committee. Decisions on these controls are expected to be taken early next year. I now wish to address the major provisions in the Bill in more detail.
Deeming

The Bill provides in Part IV for the conversion of the Australian National Airlines Commission to a public company. In particular, Clause 15 deems the Commission to have been, immediately before the transition, and to be, at the transition a corporation within the meaning of the Companies Act and provides for the Commission to be registered as a company under the ACT Companies legislation.

A major benefit of the deeming approach is that the company maintains the same corporate entity as the Commission. Because there is no change in the corporate entity there is no need: to transfer assets and liabilities from the Commission to a new body corporate; for novation of overseas contracts of the Commission, because there would be no new party to those contracts; to transfer any tax losses or the benefit of Capital Gains Tax exemptions for pre-20 September 1985 assets to a new corporation; or for any change to existing Commonwealth loan guarantees, which would remain in place. The deeming approach therefore avoids the administrative costs and time which would be involved in resolving these matters under alternative legislative approaches.

All contracts, agreements and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of the Commission and which are in force immediately before transition, including the 1981 Airlines Agreement, will apply to the deemed Company. All the shares in the deemed company will be held either directly by the Commonwealth, or by a Commonwealth wholly owned holding company.
Staffing Matters related to Conversion

On transition each staff member of the Commission will become an employee of the Company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the Commission. Entitlements such as long service and recreation leave, and eligibility for sick leave, will be preserved. There will be no entitlement to any payments in lieu of leave entitlements. The legislation enables the Company to become a ``prescribed authority'' for purposes of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. Those staff who have rights under the repealed Officers Rights Declaration Act 1928, or Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights. On transition the existing provisions covering superannuation for staff who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (some 950 employees) will be maintained; and the company will become an ``approved authority'' for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976.

These provisions are necessary to avoid any industrial difficulties which could arise if the terms and conditions of staff on transition were left open. The airline has proposed that, as a corporation, and subject to industrial agreement it should have the ability to withdraw from the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and to transfer CSS staff to existing airline Plans. This proposal is to be considered by the Structural Adjustment Committee. The timing of conversion to a public company does not need to be decided at this stage. However it is expected that the transition will take place on 31 March 1988.
Company Structure

The airline has indicated it wishes to re-organise its activities into a holding company/subsidiary company structure, and views this as an essential part of the changes required in establishing the airline as a fully competitive public company, and to avoid any adverse legacy of its previous statutory authority form. This new structure would also allow greater devolution of management responsibilities and assist management to focus on activities where performance may need to be improved.

The Bill provides flexibility in the way in which the final group structure is to be achieved. One such way would be for the deemed company to assume the role of holding company. The other would be for the new holding company to be incorporated by the Commonwealth and for the deemed company to become a subsidiary undertaking the major airline operation activities.
Staff Matters related to the Re-organisation

The Bill, by amending the appropriate provisions of applicable legislation, enables new companies created before commencing day as part of the group re-organisation, to also be covered by the provisions of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976. Where existing employees of the Commission are contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme or have rights relating to Public Service employment under the repealed Officers Rights Declaration Act 1928 and Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922, those rights and entitlements will also be preserved irrespective of transfer to any company in the group.
Transfers of Assets and Liabilities

Given that there will be no change in beneficial ownership by the Commonwealth, all transfers of assets and liabilities from the Commission to other companies within the group as part of this re-organisation, and for any related transfer of shares, should not be subject to Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes and duties. The Bill therefore provides for transfers to be exempt from such taxes and duties but restricts these exemptions to transfers related directly to the re-organisation which take place within the period between Royal Assent and transition day.
Taxation

The Bill will also ensure that the group re-organisation will be `tax neutral', with the overall taxation position of the companies involved being the same as would otherwise have applied to the Commission.
Removal of Government Controls

In my policy statement of 7 October 1987, I announced the removal of a number of day-to-day controls over Australian Airline's commercial operations to help streamline management decision making and place increased responsibility with the airline's board where it properly belongs. These controls included: all but exceptionally significant expenditure decisions (e.g. those requiring additional equity capital); detailed terms and conditions of borrowings and leasing arrangements; investment of surplus moneys; choice of auditor; dividend recommendations and; provision for insurance against risk.
The deletion of all substantive sections of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 will give effect to the Government's decision.

Further, as indicated earlier the Government through the Structural Adjustment Committee will be examining the scope for removal of other broader controls over Australian Airlines operations. These controls include: Loan Council borrowing limits; Remuneration Tribunal determination of board member and senior executive salaries; industrial relations arrangements being subject to Government oversight and co-ordination; restrictions on superannuation arrangements; application of the offsets policy to purchases of aircraft and related spares.

Once the position on the broader controls has been settled, the Government will address the form of Memorandum and Articles of Association, together with appropriate Guidelines to Directors of the Company to ensure that the airline continues to be subject to appropriate minimum levels of control, and so that there is an on-going basis for establishing the airline's financial target and corporate planning responsibilities previously contained in the ANA Act 1945.
Intrastate Operations

It has been necessary to retain Section 19a of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 to enable the Commonwealth to hold shares in a company operating intra-state air services in those States to which that section applies (currently Queensland, Tasmania and New South Wales). Legislation adopting Section 19a has also recently been enacted by the Western Australian Parliament and is currently awaiting Royal Assent. The Bill ensures that a group company will be able to carry on business in all States and Territories under names which have been protected in accordance with provisions of the Bill.
Amendments to Related Legislation

As required by the proposed re-organisation, the Bill amends definitions in the Airlines Equipment Act 1958 and the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981, which play an integral role in the operation of the existing Airlines Agreement, to extend the application of those Acts to over all companies in the re-organised group.

Additional legislative provisions are necessary to apply the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 and the Commonwealth Sales Tax legislation to the group of companies. For constitutional reasons these provisions will be contained in separate Bills, which cannot originate in the Senate, and will be introduced in the House of Representatives to coincide with transmission of this Bill after passage by the Senate.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill does not involve additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or additional revenue to the Commonwealth. The Bill provides for exemption from Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes on transfer of assets as part of the proposed re-organisation of the airline, in recognition of the fact that there will be no change in the Commonwealth's beneficial ownership.
Conclusion

In future, there will be greater opportunities for the aviation environment to become more competitive as aviation specific economic regulatory controls are removed. There have already been developments in the domestic aviation industry which impinge on the extent and form of future competition. Following the recent take-over of East-West by News Corporation and TNT, Australian Airlines faces the prospect of greater competition from, on the one hand, Ansett Airlines in traditional markets and, on the other, East-West Airlines in the growing price sensitive leisure and tourism markets. Australian Airlines is therefore confronted in all areas of the domestic market by strong commercial competitors backed by extensive financial resources.

In these circumstances, this Bill represents an important first step on the part of the Government towards improved competitiveness of the airline by giving the management of Australian the flexibility to structure the airline in the most effective manner to meet the current and future challenges and the ability to run the airline without the hindrance of detailed bureaucratic controls. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was interrupted last night, I was outlining that the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill amends the River Murray Waters Agreement and establishes a Murray-Darling Basin Commission. The new Commission replaces the River Murray Commission with a Murray-Darling Basin Commission which, in addition to assuming the statutory responsibilities of the old Commission, will also have an advisory role to the Ministerial Council on water, land and environmental matters in the whole of the Murray-Darling basin not covered in the 1982 River Murray Waters Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of importance is that the Bill establishes a ministerial council comprising three Ministers from each of the four governments, whereas under the previous arrangements they were for the water Ministers only from each of the States. The Bill in its Ministerial Council arrangements enables much greater ministerial participation by State and Federal governments, the four governments concerned being the Federal Government, and the State governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The new arrangements will enable a much broader input into the activities of the new Commission than was the case previously.

The Bill also establishes a Community Advisory Committee to bring together, and present to the Ministerial Council, community views on the management of the natural resources of the basin. The Chairman of the new Commission-it is an appointment that we certainly welcome-is Professor John Burton of the University of New England. Approximately 17 representatives of regional and national organisations are to be included on the new community advisory committee. Complementary State legislation, which is essential for the effective operation of the new arrangements, is presently before State parliaments.

This is an important Bill because the River Murray is a very important part of our river system in Australia; it is also a very important part of the economy of the relevant regions of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The River Murray system is a major provider of irrigation water. It provides irrigation water for 75 per cent of Australia's irrigated land. It is an area that supports a quarter of the total cattle and dairy farms in Australia and approximately half the sheep, lambs and national crop land. It is also an important source of water supply for the city of Adelaide and other centres along the Murray system. It is a very important recreation area and with the growth of tourism within Australia it will become increasingly important. The River Murray system is a wonderful tourist area and has great potential. It also plays a large part in the history of this country. It is, therefore, an area of concern to all Australians.

The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. Indeed, we believe that there are aspects of it which will, hopefully, lead to an improvement in the management of the Murray-Darling river basin system. But we do have some concerns about it. In particular, there is every prospect-unless the matter is handled carefully-that we will simply be presiding over the growth of a whole new series of bureaucratic structures for the management of the region at a time when that would be detrimental to the work going on. What is really needed in this area is a much greater degree of co-operation between the Federal and relevant State governments over the whole history of the River Murray system.

I think the River Murray Commission goes back to the 1920s. The period since then has been fraught with a great deal of difficulty in getting the respective governments to work together as co-operatively as is necessary if we are to tackle the real problems of the system. Whilst new ministerial and other bureaucratic arrangements may have some beneficial effect, provided they do not become over-bureaucratised, the real solution will lie in the goodwill of the various governments and their willingness to co-operate, and also in an adequate supply of funds being put into the system.

The Opposition is concerned that the Bill does not make any new financial provisions for the system. We are concerned that over the last few years, since the Hawke Government came to office, funding for this very important region has declined progressively on a dollar for dollar basis. The Fraser Government believed that the States were not acting urgently enough in the light of what could and should be done to solve some of the major problems, perhaps the major one being salinity. I will come back to that. Over a period of years $640m of Commonwealth money was to have been provided as a result of a major initiative announced, I think, in 1982 by the Fraser Government when it initiated the bicentennial water program. This money was to have been provided because of the frustration involved in waiting for the States to play their part.

A number of valuable works which would have improved the situation in the Murray were planned, including the Mallee pipeline. But when this Labor Government came to power one of its early actions was to drop the bicentennial water program. That is a matter of great regret. It is certainly a matter of concern to the region because the problems facing that region, particularly salinity, are compounding all the time.

There has been a salinity problem in the Murray River system throughout its history and it has been exacerbated over the years by the development of irrigation. However, it is important to recognise that the salinity problem has always been present. The soils and the groundwater of the Mallee zone around the Murray are salty; indeed they are sometimes more salty than the sea. This is a result of the area having been submerged beneath the sea for millions of years. The area extends as far east as Swan Hill. The groundwater of the Riverine Plains received salt from the weathering of sediments in the eastern highlands and from salt swept in from sea spray and rain.

Therefore, salinity of the Murray resulted from natural causes but, as I have said, the problem has been exacerbated by the activities of man through land clearing, river structures and irrigation drainage. Of course the clearing of trees reduces transpiration of water causing ground water to rise through salt laden soil and flow into streams. Lakes and weirs raise upstream water levels, increasing pressure on underlying salty ground water and forcing it into the river downstream. Irrigation can also allow ground water mounds to form under irrigation areas, increasing hydraulic gradients towards, and saline seepage into, the river or tributary. Salinity problems increase towards the west as more and more salt is poured into the Murray via the tributaries and ground water inflow. Anyone who has driven through the area or, more particularly, flown over it would have seen the enormous problems of salinity in certain regions along the Murray system around Kerang, Swan Hill, towards Mildura and beyond. It is a problem of considerable magnitude.

In supporting the legislation that is before us, the Opposition hopes that the new arrangements will enable a broader perspective to be brought to the consideration of the issues of concern, some of which I have already outlined. As I said earlier, it will be very dependent on the attitude which the participants bring to the Council and to the advisory tables. If that co-operation is not forthcoming then, of course, no particular administrative or bureaucratic arrangements will solve the problem. The Opposition is also concerned about the role of the Community Advisory Committee. In practice that sounds an admirable establishment because in theory it should enable community representatives to have proper technical and other input into matters of concern. The issue will be whether the membership of that Committee is sufficiently representative and non-bureaucratised to enable that to happen. We hope that the four governments concerned will do all that they can to ensure that that Community Advisory Committee fulfils the role for which it is designed.

Having introduced this legislation, the Government has a tendency to promote the new arrangements almost as the saviour of the area as if nothing has been done in the past. In my earlier remarks I mentioned that previous governments-and particularly the Liberal-National governments-over the last 30 to 40 years have indeed done an enormous amount to improve the situation along the Murray River. We fully recognise that a great deal more needs to be done but it would be regrettable for us now not to recognise the work that has been done, not only by previous governments but also by the persons who live along the River Murray and in the river's drainage area. For that reason the Opposition has moved an amendment to the second reading of this Bill which, amongst other things, notes the recognition of the progress made by previous governments and by the persons who live along the Murray River and in the river's drainage area.

Our second reading amendment, which was moved by Senator Lewis yesterday on behalf of the Opposition, also points out the need for the Federal Government, with the State governments, to provide a firm commitment to finance the already known and necessary remedial measures along the Murray River, which would immediately improve water quality. There is need for additional research and the development of new concepts and techniques, but a great deal is already known. I believe that political will, political co-operation and necessary funding are required. With those ingredients, the scene will be set for a major improvement in the Murray system. The coalition will watch with great interest and monitor the activities of the newly created Ministerial Council and Community Advisory Committee to ensure that they are playing their full role to meet the objectives which are commonly agreed on both sides of this chamber. I support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Lewis in supporting this Bill, whilst at the same time highlighting the work that has already been done by previous governments and drawing to the attention of the Government the potential concerns that will arise if the new arrangements are not handled appropriately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987 amends the River Murray Waters Act 1983 to give effect to a Murray-Darling Basin Agreement which is designed, at least on the surface, to improve the management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. It is the last in a long line of gestures by governments, both State and Federal, to improve access to and the quality of water in that area. The Bill establishes a Murray-Darling Basin Commission which replaces the River Murray Commission and comes into effect on 1 January 1988. I think all honourable senators would agree that that is an appropriate date. In addition, the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council are given a legislative base and a community advisory committee is established to allow for community input into the management of the basin. To what extent that community input will be effective will depend, as has already been pointed out, on the political good will or otherwise of the relevant State governments and the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably indisputable that the major dissatisfaction with regard to the quality of water in the Murray comes from the end users in South Australia. Over the years their complaints have had very little impact on governments in other States, particularly, of course, in New South Wales and, to a lesser extent, in Victoria. So I approach this Bill with a certain amount of frustration and caution and not a small pinch of cynicism, although I am glad to have the opportunity that the presentation of this Bill gives me to make a number of important points in relation to the effects in South Australia of increased salinity in the River Murray Basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Adelaide water.
—For about the fourth or fifth time since I have been in this place I am about to treat Senator Chaney to a description of Adelaide water.
—It is disgusting.

—I could not agree more with the comment that Senator Chaney just made. Most Adelaidians, of course, resent the fact that we have this problem. Having made that point, it is worth while pointing out-as members of this chamber and others ought to be aware-the World Health Organisation recommendations for salinity levels. Over and over again during the last 10 years I have pointed out the way in which South Australia is getting a raw deal with regard to its water quality-a consequence, of course, of the fact that the original 1914 Agreement related only to the quantity of water rather than the quality of River Murray water reaching each State.

SPEECH.PARA: Like most other South Australians, I have become increasingly fed up over the years at the procrastination and the buck-passing that has gone on amongst State and Federal governments, local government authorities, the Commission and other relevant organisations, regarding a solution to this problem. The result of that procrastination for South Australians has been water which smells, tastes and looks revolting-as Senator Chaney pointed out, rather opportunely. It is not suitable for washing, much less for cooking or drinking. It has quite justifiably given Adelaide an international reputation as having the worst water in the world. The States that have contributed to the problem ought not to sit back and smirk about it. It has been largely due to the impact of agricultural procedures, enthusiastically supported by State governments looking for votes, that South Australia has the worst water in the world and is having to tolerate it when a solution ought to be found. It is a matter of considerable irritation to all of us from South Australia to see, popping up over the years, ministerial statements and pieces of legislation relating to the River Murray waters when most of us suspect that very little will result as a consequence. This is, of course, not to make light of the problem, as some members of this place have tried to do.

The need for quality control of River Murray water has been so obvious for so long, I would have thought, that the reluctance of previous governments to act constructively amounts almost to a dereliction of duty on the part of the relevant authorities. It is all very well for Senator Short and others to castigate this Government for its inaction, but I cannot say that I noticed in the time I was here during the previous Fraser governments that they did much more than introduce ministerial statements on the matter. If one reads the Hansards, one will see that these statements tended to be greeted with somewhat more all-party support and hope than what it appears will be the outcome of this piece of legislation. So there certainly has been a dramatic failure to act in any meaningful way with regard to the quality of River Murray water when it reaches South Australia. That failure to act rests on the shoulders of all previous governments and the existing one.

Over the years South Australians have been confronted with a plethora of reports which do no more than tell us what we already know: that is, that there is a serious problem with the quality of River Murray water and, hence, for the end users of that water, and it is getting worse. We hear time after time from State and Federal Ministers and from authorities of one sort or another that the quality of River Murray water is appalling and getting worse and is causing significant economic problems for South Australia. Yet very little action is being taken.

Let me refer for a moment to an excellent report that appeared last month in the Times on Sunday. This significant article was entitled `The degradation of the noble Murray'. A number of other senators, including my colleague Senator Powell, have already referred to that, but I think it is important that I cite some paragraphs from that article which highlight the problem that is relevant to the debate today. The article points out:
But time is catching up with the Murray, where over a century of irrigation projects . . . have created an environmental disaster.
I do not think that is putting too excessive a label on the problem that we are facing in South Australia with regard to the Murray. The article points out:

Millions of tonnes of salt, fertilisers and pesticides are being dumped into the river every year. Hundreds of thousands of hectares of some of the richest farming lands in Australia are salting up or suffering other forms of land degradation. Wetlands have been altered or destroyed, forests endangered and much wildlife killed off or put in jeopardy.

The environmental plight facing the Murray is a product of poor planning, lack of understanding of the delicacy of the river ecosystem and bad farming practices such as deforestation, overcropping and excessive irrigation. The Murray also suffers from political opportunism.
Of course, it has been political opportunism that has in fact allowed the deforestation programs, the overcropping and the excessive irrigation. The article continued:

According to Bruce Davidson, a senior lecturer in agricultural economics at Sydney University, the irrigation program was a `terrible' mistake and has cost Australian taxpayers around $1 billion in expenditure never recouped.
The article continued:
The problem is that after spending billions of dollars winning votes over the past century-
and that is how long we have been debating this problem-
the State and Federal Governments now have to decide how to share the astronomical costs of repairing the damage to the river environment.
In the whole of the Murray-Darling basin, governments have put in 13,500 kilometres of supply channels and 7,000 kilometres of drainage channels.
Massive irrigation programs have clearly been undertaken over a period of far too many years. The article points out:
Excessive irrigation means that water percolates down into the soil, raising the water table.

This part of Australia was once a sea (though there are other theories about how the salt got there), and a higher water table means salt rises to the surface. The man-made process adds to the natural salination of the Murray.
However, the author points out:

salt is only part of the problem. Downstream from Swan Hill in Victoria, the water in the Murray is becoming more polluted with fertilisers and pesticides washed off the farmland and drained into the river.

I pause here for a moment to point out that we have already suffered quite significant embarrassment in our trade area because of excessive use of fertilisers and pesticides. It is time that governments at State and Federal level, political parties of all persuasions and those people involved in the agricultural sector got together to look at the long term needs of this country, and of the people they represent, rather than simply proceeding with very damaging and long lasting short term methods of increasing profit and producing the products that we all need. The article goes on to say:

The widespread clearing of land-less than 9 per cent of the original vegetation remains in the wheat/sheep belts is making the soil problem worse and also creating more salination. Trees suck up moisture, and when they are killed off, the water table rises.

An average of 2.5 tonnes of salt flows over the South Australian border every minute. At Morgan, nearly out of the weir system and in the final run to the sea, the water is monitored and the results are appalling.

The Murray has accumulated pollutants and naturally and agriculturally derived salt from nearly the whole course of the river. The salinity level is 20 times what it was at the start of the voyage, and this has to be filtered out before inhabitants of Adelaide and other South Australian population centres can use it.

I would suggest to the author that he come back to South Australia and see how little use we actually get out of that water, even after it has been fiddled about with, allegedly to make it potable. The article continues:
The task of repairing the ecological damage to the Murray is daunting, both in size and complexity.

It finishes off on much the same line as it started on, with a comment from Adelaide University's Dr Walker, who points out that fixing the Murray would `require a cost even the government cannot accept'. He said:
We are locked into a situation where solutions are apparent, but politically impractical.

That means that some government might lose a few seats if it puts into practice the solutions that are necessary to improve the quality, as distinct from the quantity, of water flowing through South Australia down towards Adelaide and then into the sea. I think it is fairly clear from this article, among others, that we cannot afford to pussyfoot around any longer about the problem that we, as a country, are facing. While the problem is certainly significant for South Australia, it is a national problem.

Two other decisions that have been announced recently-interestingly enough by the State most affected-also point to the urgency of the situation. In the Adelaide Advertiser recently, a small article headed `Report urges halt to irrigation development' pointed out that:
A State Government committee report has recommended suspending irrigation development in the Keith area.

I would simply note that those of us who have been involved in these debates over the years have been calling for the suspension, or at least the considerable diminution, of irrigation in a variety of areas along the course of the Murray for a very long time indeed. This particular recommendation was in a five-year draft water resources management plan for the Tatiara Proclaimed Region. The plan was prepared by the Upper South East Water Resources Advisory Committee, and it is to be discussed at a series of public meetings in the Tatiara area. The recommendations for suspending irrigation followed the discovery that the area had severe ground water stress resulting from overuse of reserves.

The second article appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser a little more recently, headed `$22m scheme to desalinate Murray'. It points out that the Federal Government and three State governments, South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria, have agreed to fund a $22m, 12-year project, aimed at dramatically reducing River Murray salinity. The article says towards the end that irrigators in Victoria had drainage problems and were looking to drain water directly into the river, which could negate the effects of the Woolpunda scheme. So again there is a report of a continuation of the very actions which have led to the problem, actions by irrigators in States which have access to the Murray water before those of us in South Australia do.

The River Murray Waters Amendment Bill appears on the surface to be a step in the right direction. But we in South Australia could be forgiven for having developed some cynicism or, at the very least, a healthy scepticism about the possibility of some improvement occurring. As I said a moment ago, year after year in this place we have debated ministerial statements on new and presumably improved River Murray waters agreements, with no discernible results to date for South Australia. However, the Bill seeks to do something positive and I will suspend, at least temporarily, my concern that maybe all that is going to happen is that history will be repeated and all the good intentions expressed will come to nought. At worst, the more comprehensive approach taken in this Bill will do no harm. At best, the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission will provide a central point for discussion and consideration of the sustainable use of the natural resources of the basin.

It is particularly pleasing to see that at long last the governments concerned-I say again, apparently-have put aside their parochial interests and appear willing to approach the problem in a more co-operative way than in the past. One can describe those past approaches only as dismal failures. While the Murray has been dying, political opportunism has dictated the actions of all the governments involved. State governments, with an eye to the next election, have failed persistently to address the fact that the granting of irrigation licences needed to be cut back. It would be nice to think that with good will on the part of all concerned and a real determination to make the new arrangements work, the environmental health of the basin and the economic well-being of the urban centres in the valley would be assured. Unfortunately, it is still by no means certain that State and Federal governments, with different aims and ambitions but with one mutual aim and ambition of winning each next election, will agree on politically unpopular moves, for example as has already been indicated in the articles I have referred to and in comments that have been made in the past about measures to limit irrigation licences.

We all know how much damage is being done by irrigation to the quality of the River Murray water. In South Australia, fruit trees are dying, people are becoming bankrupt and most South Australians are unable to drink the water because of what happens before the water even gets to our border. As Senator Short mentioned a moment ago, anybody with an eye that cares to see can note, simply by flying over or driving through the area, the devastation that has occurred. We all know the problem is there. We have lacked so far the political will to do something about it. I do not want to underestimate the difficulties and the complexity of the problems to be resolved but, unless something changes, South Australians will continue to suffer from what I believe is nothing short of selfishness, thoughtlessness and political gutlessness-I suppose that is the most polite way of putting it-that applies in other States, particularly in New South Wales.

The new Commission envisaged by this legislation will certainly have a greater advisory role. But its enforcement powers are very similar to those of the old Commission. One knows that advice can be handed out willy-nilly. It is the capacity to enforce the provisions that we all know are necessary that is the most important element of improving any situation and those are still lacking. The Bill refers to the whole drainage basin; that is, the Murray-Darling Basin and extends the Commission's advisory role to land management, water use and the environment. There is, therefore, within this legislation a recognition that solutions to the problem depend on more than just engineering; for example, salt interception works. That recognition is welcome, overdue as it is.

The Bill also gives a clear legislative basis to the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, as the Council will be made up of Ministers representing the portfolios of water, land and environment from the Federal Government and the State governments of South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. It will, I suppose, be in a position to initiate worthwhile programs and exercise general oversight and control over all major policy questions-and perhaps there will be a greater willingness of State and Federal Ministers to agree, since all the governments are of one political persuasion. One of the problems, particularly over the last decade, has been that governments in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and the Federal Government have not always had the unity of political purpose behind them, so there has been an impediment to getting an agreement with regard to the best action to take in this area.

Within this framework, the purported purpose of this Bill is to improve intergovernmental collaboration in all aspects of natural resources management. I hope that finally this aim will be achieved. The legislation also provides for the Ministerial Council to establish a community advisory committee. The committee is intended to bring together and present to the Council community perceptions and views on matters referred to it by the committee or raised by the community in relation to management of the basin's natural resources. The aim is to encourage consultation and participation. Again, it is to be hoped that this laudable objective is achieved and has some results. It is all very well to encourage consultation and participation; but if no positive actions result, all we have had is yet another frustrating talkfest and more South Australian fruitgrowers going into bankruptcy.

There is an increasing amount of leeching, more trees are dying and the salinity level of the Murray as it passes through South Australia continues to rise. So while it is gratifying that the Government has introduced this legislation, yet again it has tried to take credit for some improvements in recent years, as if nobody else had ever noticed that there was a problem or tried to suggest improvements. The improvements that are claimed to have been achieved by this Government probably are more likely to have been achieved somewhat fortuitously by the prevailing climatic conditions that, in recent years, have favoured improved quality of water in the basin. These climatic conditions have meant less demand by irrigators on the river water and a reduction in saline inputs compared with what happens during periods of drought. It is precisely during these sorts of better climatic conditions that we should have readied ourselves for the less favourable conditions. Unfortunately, we have not done so. To make that matter worse by claiming that some sort of political situation has improved the condition of the water temporarily, rather than simply fortuitous climatic ones, is simply not helping matters.

In any event, I welcome this latest attempt to solve the problems in the Murray-Darling Basin. They have been going on for so long that I suspect it will take almost as long to cure the problem as it took to produce it. It is impossible to overestimate the importance of this river as a resource for this country, particularly for South Australia. This country is very dependent on river water, with a host of primary industries and urban centres vitally affected. It is in the interests of all of us to look after the Murray. Failure to look after it, indeed failure to remedy the existing problems, will have catastrophic consequences not simply for South Australia's economy but eventually for the economy of the country as a whole, dependent as it is on the commodities that are produced in the area along the course of the Murray. This legislation will not in itself, of course, solve the problem. It may, however, facilitate the means whereby the problems might be overcome.

So while I welcome this step, there is no room for complacency. Commitment, co-operation and adequate funding are, as Senator Short and others have already pointed out, necessary adjuncts to the new arrangements. They have been sadly missing in recent decades, and I think it is very important that we acknowledge yet again that we cannot do this simply by an Act of parliament in the Federal scene. There must be commitment, co-operation and adequate funding, and that must be evident not just in this place but also within the State governments that are involved. Until commitment, co-operation and adequate funding become automatic elements of solving the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin, and in particular the problems of the Murray after it has wound its way into South Australia, we are going to continue to have a very serious problem economically and, I suggest, socially with the Murray. Whilst I commend this Government's move in this direction, I hope that it will have a better and longer lasting effect than the moves made by previous governments have had so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987. Unfortunately I, too, am somewhat sceptical as to what this Bill might in fact achieve. The effective management of Australia's major river resource has a long and largely disappointing history. When we look back we see, on the one hand, so little progress and, on the other hand, so many examples of regional and State jealousies, bureaucratic conflict and, most of all, a lack of political resolve to really come to grips with the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Salinity in the River Murray system alone has been estimated to cost urban, industrial and agricultural water users some $40m to $60m each year. Add that to production losses due to soil degradation in the adjoining dry land cropping areas and the total damage comes to over $200m each year. Unfortunately, evidence suggests salinity below Euston is still increasing at the rate of 2 per cent per annum. So we see a situation where enormous damage has been done, and at best the remedial action taken to date has simply succeeded in reducing the rate of further damage.

If we look at this Government's response to the situation, we find that it has been prepared to spend only some $27m on salinity and drainage during the whole of its term of office. To put that in context with what it would cost to try to put the River Murray system right, let us look at a recent technical report to the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council which suggested that high priority projects alone, to overcome the most urgent problems, would cost in the vicinity of $172m. That report from an expert committee advised that to repair the entire Murray-Darling irrigation system would cost in the vicinity of $785m. So we are looking at enormous sums of money, but I suppose everything should be looked at in its true perspective. That would be some $400m less than we have spent on the new Parliament House. But, as I said, in actual fact the Government has spent only $27m.

Salinity is, of course, only one of the River Murray's problems. We have to add to it the problem with nutrients and pesticides entering the river system. The by-products of agriculture are killing wildlife and fish and choking the watercourse with weeds. These matters have been dealt with in greater detail by previous speakers. But it is salinity which so much impresses us, particularly South Australians. I reiterate the figure cited last night. South Australia receives 1.4 million tonnes of salt from upriver each year, and that to us is highly significant. Even those of us who live in Adelaide suffer the consequences of that. I remind honourable senators that in most years about 40 to 50 per cent of Adelaide's water comes from the Murray. In dry years, such as in 1977 and 1978, up to 83 per cent came from it. We see salinity levels hovering around 835 electrical conductivity units, which of course is the World Health Organisation's maximum salinity level for a domestic water supply. So it is not surprising that South Australians are conscious of this continuing problem with the River Murray, or that when from time to time Bills such as this arise in the Senate we wish to address them. We do know how fragile the whole system is. We are reminded that it was only a few years ago, in 1980, that the river ceased to flow for 240 days, producing a near catastrophic situation.

We now better understand what has gone wrong with the total river system. We know that much of the problem has resulted from poor planning in the past, from a lack of understanding of the river ecosystem as a whole and from inappropriate farming practices, such as flood irrigation and excessive irrigation, as has been mentioned by other speakers. Although research on the river system is still too sketchy, we better understand that a lot could be done to improve the situation. What that requires is a concerted and co-ordinated program of management. It requires reclamation, land management and environmental protection. When it comes down to the bottom line, that must be the responsibility of the governments concerned, and therein lies the problem.

It is with that background that one has to address the terms of this Bill, the latest attempt to provide further remedial action for the river's problems, and see just what it can contribute in relation to the responsibility of this Government. The Bill, and the expanded agreement covered in the Bill, changes the River Murray Waters Agreement to the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement. I commend that change. I recall it is something that I sought in a speech I gave in this place in 1983. For too long the River Murray Commission and the other authorities concerned have been limited by their legislation and by the agreement simply to looking at the River Murray, when what happens to the river is so much affected by what is happening in other river courses. So I commend that expansion. That is a small step forward, as was the 1982 agreement to allow the Commission to consider matters of water quality. Perhaps in another six years-it has taken six years for the latest advance-we might have a Bill that states that the agreement now includes Queensland, which of course it should. Queensland covers about a quarter of the basin, with the catchment area extending some 400 miles into that State. At the moment it is not a party to the agreement. Again I reflect on previous addresses I have made in this place and say that it is necessary for the three States and the Commonwealth which are now parties to the agreement to look at embracing Queensland in an expanded agreement in the future. The Government will no doubt say that under this Bill Queensland is given observer status. That, I guess, is a small step forward to future participation. I acknowledge that, but, for more effective management of the total river system, I look to Queensland being incorporated as a responsible party in the years ahead.

The new Commission will advise the Ministerial Council in relation to the management of water, land and environmental resources within the basin. We see the Commission, under this Bill, having an extended responsibility to include land use and environmental matters. It might seem that that should have been obvious, and should have been included a long time ago, but, as I indicated, because of bureaucratic jealousies and the like, it has not. It is now included, and I commend those who have negotiated the extension to include land use and environmental matters because, in a total management plan for the river, they must be incorporated.

What we see, unfortunately, is that although the Commission is expanded to look at a wider perspective, its power is simply to advise the Ministerial Council. It has no executive capacity in its own right. Therefore, when we get to the bottom line, it still relies on the attitude of the Ministerial Council, in this instance, the Ministers representing the States of South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales, and the Commonwealth Government. There has not been a resolution in this Bill of the political conflicts between the States and the Commonwealth that have existed in the past and will no doubt continue to exist in the future. The Commission's role has expanded to include land use and the environment, but it cannot act in those areas unless it is given authority by this body of Ministers which, in the past, has not been ready to give the Commission the executive responsibility that it needs. Again, I draw this obvious point to the attention of the Government, and urge that further efforts be made in that direction.

I note that now advice from the Commission can be given by a majority of commissioners. That might not seem a major step forward, but it is a small, but significant, step in the right direction. It means that one commissioner holding out will not stop advice going forward to the Ministerial Council. Therefore, one commissioner, who may be tied in one way to a particular State or particular land use problem, will not be able to thwart the program of advice being put to the Council and, one hopes, executive responsibility being given back from the Council to the Commission. I commend that small step forward.

The Commission's advice to the Ministerial Council need be only by a majority vote, but when we get to the Ministerial Council, which the Commission is advising, we find that each policy decision by the Ministerial Council still requires all parties to agree. The body that still has the ultimate responsibility to make decisions in this area must make unanimous decisions. Those of us who have looked at the history of the failure of the management of the River Murray all know how often one State, or the Commonwealth, has been able to thwart the action that would have been to the benefit of the nation as a whole. Unfortunately, this Bill will not overcome that problem.

One need only think of the example of the Commission seeking to monitor tributaries in one State, and the reluctance of the State to allow that on an ongoing basis because it might show up unsatisfactory land use and result in the other States and the Commonwealth putting pressure on that State for greater expenditure in that area or in some other way. Unfortunately, if one looks at the history of the River Murray-I do not want particularly to pick on States, but I can mention New South Wales-one finds examples of one State holding out and the Commission not being able to carry out the function that I believe it should.

A number of other shortcomings are still contained in this legislation. I note that the Standing Committee of the Ministerial Council is to remain as an advisory body to the Ministerial Council, so that the Commission may possibly have less influence in an advisory capacity than the Standing Committee, which is made up of the relevant heads of the State and Federal departments. Again, there is a potential that the Commission's more objective advice may possibly be overlooked, and that causes me concern. I note that the Commission is still restricted in its monitoring activities of water quality to the main stem of the River Murray, without first obtaining State permission. That, I would argue, is an unnecessary restraint. I would have liked to think that we have gained sufficient maturity in this area and sufficient confidence in ourselves to give the Commission power to monitor tributaries without having to go to the State for permission first, but as yet, that is not the case. The history of this matter is one of slow progress and I draw that to the attention of the Government.

All the good intentions will be thwarted if staff resources for the Commission are not made available. To date, the Commission has had only 10 professional staff. When one looks at its massive responsibility, one must ask what can be achieved by a staff of only 10 professionals. I understand that the four governments have indicated that a further sum of $320,000, borne equally by the four governments, will be put into providing six additional staff. I am pleased about that, but the situation still remains much the same. When we look at the scope of the problem, and the massive task before the Commission, to have that responsibility and to exercise it with only 16 professional staff is an impossible task. That leads one to question the bona fides of the Government's concern in this area.

Looking at what has been achieved in the past, and what is sought to be achieved by this Bill, we find that there have been slow steps forward. In 1982, the Commission was given the chance to consider water quality and not simply quantity, and, therefore, it took one step forward, beyond simply being a Commission to determine the quantity of water for each of the States and to implement the engineering functions necessary to achieve those objectives, to considering quality. Now, under this agreement and this Bill, it takes a small step further, and that step is directed to considering matters of land use and environmental resources.

The Ministerial Council will include Ministers responsible for land and environment matters, as well as Ministers responsible for water, so some practical manifestation of the increased responsibility of the new emphasis in being concerned with the total resources is indicated by that change. I remind the Senate that the Ministerial Council remains a political forum. It now allows land use and environmental matters to be discussed at a political level, and no doubt gives the capacity for the Ministerial Council to look at co-ordinated programs within that area. Whether it will determine co-ordinated programs in that area and give the Commission the responsibility and instructions to execute them is something we have yet to see.

I commend the fact that a community advisory committee will be set up. That will help to keep the mind of the Ministerial Council on the job but, again, I would not overstate what it means because all it will really do is provide another input. I guess what is needed in this area is more output rather than further input. What I have said in the past, therefore, I regret to say remains the case today despite these small steps further and that is that there is still not an executive body, a management body, that is given adequate powers to carry out the function that is necessary to manage this very important national resource. No body is given functions such as are given to river commissions in the United States. This has largely come about because the governments of the three States and the Commonwealth have not been prepared to give that responsibility to an executive body; in effect, to abdicate their political rights, particularly in the land use area, to a third party which might act objectively in the interests of the whole of that vitally important region of Australia as opposed to the interest of particular States.

I have said in the past that I cannot see that the position will be achieved without a national authority-in other words, the States giving to the Commonwealth the power to do that. I am still of that mind. Of course, were the power given, the Commonwealth would have to accept responsibility to ensure that such an executive body was properly funded, which is not the case under the present arrangement, and that it had adequate research capacity, which the present body does not have. I note that this Bill takes some further small steps forward but I remain somewhat sceptical, looking at the whole history of this matter, as to what will be positively achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear all of the second reading debate but I did hear the last few minutes from Senator Hill. I think he has put his finger on one of the real problems and noted correctly that this legislation does not fully address that real problem; that is, the divided responsibility over a geographical area covering the entire Murray-Darling Basin catchment area. Queensland, which includes a significant portion of the catchment area, is not even a party to the agreement. It is not the first time that Senator Hill has expressed views which are well in advance of those held by the majority of his Party. I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill any longer.
