SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill, which is one of the measures that are needed to facilitate the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard to private enterprise. It is, of course, entirely consistent with the Opposition's philosophy on government organisations being put into private hands where it is appropriate to do so and where there is no good purpose served by their remaining in public hands. We welcome this Bill also because it will stop the terrible drain on the public purse. We have been talking about a low of $18m a year and something had to be done to stop this drain on Commonwealth funds. Therefore, we welcome the sale of the dockyard and we welcome this Bill because it will go towards facilitating that sale.

SPEECH.PARA: We also enjoy the fact that the Government is clearly embracing the principle of privatisation. It agrees with coalition policy but I recognise that in the other place Government members were very reluctant to admit the fact that they were adopting the coalition policy of privatisation. I dare say we will once again today hear that there is some very fine distinction between privatisation as espoused by us and privatisation as practised by the Government. Nevertheless, I do not wish to harp on the subject but just to welcome the fact that this sale is taking place.

The Williamstown Dockyard is one enterprise which, quite clearly, has to be run more efficiently by private enterprise than public enterprise, as is the Government Aircraft Factories, about which the Government has also taken the same decision in regard to its sale. The history of this dockyard is an appalling, long saga of which I am sure honourable senators on both sides of the House do not really need to be reminded. It has been raised here many times over the years. It has been raised in the public forum in the Press. The fact that the public purse has been so badly served by the dockyard, by its employees, by its management, by the whole control and inefficiencies that are practised there has been constantly raised by the Auditor-General. The dockyard simply could not have been run, I think, any less efficiently than it has been run with the bad management and the overmanning.

We see that at least 600 people will be shed through voluntary retirements and phased redundancies. That in itself shows how badly overmanned the organisation has been. Of course, there had been an agreement that people would not be shed. Having so many people sitting on the public payroll unproductively at the Williamstown Dockyard has been disgraceful. It has been renowned for inefficient work practices over the years and these are still continuing. I recognise that some attempts have been made in recent times to improve the financial management of the place-not before time. It has been renowned for union problems. Let us hope for the sake of Australia, for the sake of us all, that these problems will be overcome now by the new employers. The employees, above all, will be the beneficiaries of an organisation which is efficient, vibrant and well run.

I referred earlier to the Auditor-General. I am surprised that the Government was able to find a buyer for the Williamstown Dockyard willing to part with $100m in light of the problems which are all too well known in this country and in light of the disastrous record keeping which was pointed out by the Auditor-General in numerous reports, most recently in his report on the audits to 30 June 1987. According to the Auditor-General, the records contained discrepancies and inaccuracies. He consistently found that the accounting practices were unsatisfactory, and there are pages in his report dated September 1987 concerning the dockyard. I would be appalled if I had been a part of the management that gave rise to this report. The Auditor-General said over and again in different areas of his report into the dockyard that the result of the audit was unsatisfactory. I quote from page 61 of the report:
The failure of the management information systems to produce accurate and timely reports resulted in the Dockyard severely underestimating the projected loss from operations during the year.
Management could not even keep track of how fast it was losing money. The Auditor-General's overall conclusion was:

Audit has commented previously about the unsatisfactory findings of Dockyard audits and the lack of appropriate resources devoted to major changes to the Dockyard's accounting information systems. During 1985-86, it was disappointing to see that so little progress had been made in determining asset holdings and verifying existing asset records, many of the controls and standard features associated with the new financial systems had not been introduced, and up-to-date procedural instructions were yet to reach the drafting stage for so many of the new functions.

The Dockyard's preparation of its financial statements for the year ending 30 June 1986 is nearing completion. When the statements are received, it is envisaged that the AAO will be able to bring that audit to a conclusion. It is also hoped that the Dockyard will be able to prepare financial statements for 1986-87 in a more timely fashion.

That report was issued in September 1987. The management of the dockyard had been dragging its feet in upgrading and in its recordkeeping. Only at the Senate Estimates hearings this year when I referred to this report, representatives from the dockyard told me, `Of course, that all relates to 1985-86. Things are better now'. I hope that they are better now for the sake of the purchaser, because one cannot but wonder how the successful purchaser-Australian Marine Engineering Corporation-knows whether it has its money's worth.

Huge problems in procurement procedures were identified by the Auditor-General with no accurate records of stock movements having been kept. I would like to quote again from his report. He criticised the annual stocktake, the cost of store issues, the review of obsolete stores, the reconciliation of stock values and a number of other items, and he ended by saying that the result of the audit into stores was unsatisfactory, once again. He said:

Audit considers that the lack of internal controls and deficiencies identified in existing procedures and controls are such that the system cannot be relied upon to ensure: the accuracy and completeness of opening balances of all stores accounts at 1 July 1985, and the accuracy, adequacy and reliability of the stores accounting and financial records at the Dockyard.

How did the purchasers have a clue what they were buying? It is beyond belief that they could have known what they were getting. I hope that they have not bought a pig in a poke. I notice in the Auditor-General's report that he mentioned how outside stocktakers had to be brought in to try to see whether they could get some sort of order out of the chaos in the stocktaking section of the dockyard. That is all history. Very glad I am to think that it will be history.

The Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill, which is a very little Bill, simply deals with the question of redundancy or otherwise of employees at the dockyard. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in his second reading speech, said:

This Bill recognises that there is continuity of employment in this case. It is designed to facilitate the handover of the dockyard to the new owners without the absurdity of making employees eligible for large redundancy payments where there is continuity of employment. This could result in savings to the Commonwealth of between $4m and $13m, dependent on the number of employees involved.

What will happen to the employees at the dockyard? I recognise that these decisions have been taken after long consultations and negotiations. People who are not offered work will be given redundancy payments. People who choose to retire will be able to do so, and other people, who are offered either the same or better terms, will go to the new employer without any redundancy rights at all. We are very pleased that this has been able to be negotiated because nobody wants the Commonwealth to be spending enormous sums of money when people have other employment to go to.

But we, in the Opposition, are concerned for a very small group of employees who are under the Public Service Act, not the Naval Defence Act, under which the bulk of employees are employed. A very few professional engineers and technical people who are under the Public Service Act are currently permanent public servants. In the Commonwealth Public Service at present there are not many opportunities for employment and redeployment of these people and, in a sense, without wishing to exaggerate the case, they are almost forced into being conscripted into accepting employment with a new employer. If they are offered the same or slightly better conditions, they will be unable to get any redundancy assistance. Retirement is a very difficult option, if, say, one is approaching 50, with a family at its most expensive. These people, therefore, are losing their rights of permanency in the Public Service and are being pushed into employment with an employer for whom they may not wish to work. They might quite willingly be going to the new employer but might find that their employment is really intended by the employer to be for only a fairly short period. It may be that these people have some technical or accounting knowledge that will be very useful to the new employer in the short term and that their knowledge is simply to be sucked out of them and then, in a sense, they are to be spat out by the new employer.

We are concerned to see that the rights of these people are protected in the 12 months after the transition period. We hope that the Government will look at the situation of these very few people, who do not have much opportunity currently to be redeployed in the Public Service, which I think would be the wish of most of them, and may be forced into either retirement or employment with a new employer against their will. We on this side of the chamber would like to see preservation of their rights to apply for positions in the Public Service without the disadvantage which comes from being outside the Public Service when applying for a job. Only a few positions in the Public Service would be applicable to these people, and they would be disadvantaged once they were outside the Public Service in relation to positions that are available only to people in the Public Service for promotion within.

So we are speaking about a very few people. But if the Government intends to persist with the sale of these government companies, this is something which should be taken into consideration. The Government is unilaterally removing their right to be permanent public servants. We hope that the Government will see and acknowledge that it has some sort of responsibility to facilitate these people getting back into the Public Service within a reasonable period of, say, a year, or maybe two years, if an opportunity were to arise, so that they could apply on the same basis as if they were still in the Public Service.

We hope to get an undertaking from the Government that it will protect this small group of people before the sale is finalised. I understand that the Government is prepared to look at this, and I am hoping that, when we get to the committee stage, such an undertaking will be forthcoming. It is only fair that all employees at the dockyard get fair treatment in something which is being taken above their heads by the Government, although I recognise that negotiations have taken place. The people for whom there seems to be small gap do not have much industrial muscle and are very few in number.

The sale of the dockyard is taking place, not before time. As I have said before, it is very appropriate that it be privatised. I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate any more by labouring the point. I wish the new owners well, for the sake of their employees, for the sake of the enterprise and for the sake of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for long. The Australian Democrats have some reservations about the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill. In essence, we support the intention of the Government. We are concerned about some of the impacts of the Bill on those currently employed at the Williamstown Dockyard. However, we support the objectives of the Government in rendering the Williamstown Dockyard more efficient-as Senator Newman has pointed out, it has a bleak history of inefficiency-and the sooner we get on with the business of rendering it much more effective, the better. We respect the Government's intention of doing this without a huge burden upon the public purse.

SPEECH.PARA: The strategy of this Bill, essentially, is to ensure the transition from Commonwealth ownership to private ownership with minimum redundancy payments. There was potential for an outgoing of between $4m and $13m had generous redundancy payments been undertaken. It is the intention of this Bill to avoid that impact upon the public purse, and we respect that intention. However, we make the observation that some of the effects of the Bill appear to be unjust and warrant the attention of the Government. I believe that initially some assurances were given that the Government would give the injustices appropriate attention and attempt to remedy them through regulation but, as Senator Newman has said, we will be seeking those assurances in the committee stage of the debate.

It is interesting that, although the essential intention of this Bill is to avoid huge redundancy payments, the word `redundancy' does not occur in the Bill at all. The difficulties of the Bill hinge around the concepts of resignation and retirement. The impact of redundancy is catered for within the context of the Public Service Act. As Senator Newman has noted, the majority of employees are currently employed under the Naval Defence Act, but a significant proportion are employed under the Public Service Act and they would seem to be the ones who may suffer injustice should injustice occur.

In essence, a ministerial announcement was made on Friday that the new owner is the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC). It is interesting that the new owner, the employer now, has a choice as to whom it will employ, but the employees have no choice, except as to whether they stay or leave voluntarily, the impact of one of those choices-namely, leaving-having the potential to disadvantage many of them.

If we analyse the impact of this transition from Commonwealth ownership to private ownership by AMEC, we see that the current employees are confronted with four possible choices. The first of those choices is to be re-employed by AMEC under the same or better conditions, assuming that they are offered a position. I understand that, while approximately 1,000 people are employed at the dockyard at the moment, it is anticipated that within the next three to four months AMEC will offer in the vicinity of 300 to 400 positions, so it follows that in the vicinity of 600 to 700 people currently employed there will have to find employment elsewhere. So the impact of the transition in terms of employment will be quite considerable. That is the first possibility-that employees may be re-employed under the same or better conditions. Presumably they will no longer be public servants, but will be reasonably happy with their new situation because they have accepted it.

The second possibility-this would seem to be the most frequent occurrence-is that an employee will not be offered a position at all. The consequences of this are one of two possibilities. A person who is not offered a position may be redeployed within the Public Service, perhaps within Victoria or elsewhere in Australia. One would imagine that of those who are offered redeployment and who accept it, a considerable proportion at least will be satisfied. It is quite possible that a considerable number will be dissatisfied by their new circumstances, but they will not really have much choice because they fall into the group of 600 or 700 who will not be offered a new position. The other possibility for those people is that they will not be offered a position elsewhere within Victoria or Australia but will be retrenched and become the beneficiaries of the redundancy provisions. Because the redundancy provisions are quite generous, one would imagine that they will be reasonably happy.

The third possibility is that employees may be made an offer which they find unsatisfactory and may refuse it. They will fall into the same ongoing path as those I have just mentioned-they will either be redeployed or become redundant. However, the fourth possibility is probably the one of greatest conjecture; namely, that a person offered a position under similar circumstances will refuse it for personal reasons, perhaps having made a judgment about the new circumstances and deciding that the potential of the new position is not what he requires even though the conditions offered are the equivalent of his present ones. I believe these are the people who are likely to be most dissatisfied because, by virtue of doing that, they will be deemed to have resigned from the Public Service-the implications of that are quite considerable, financially and otherwise, for some people-but will not receive any redundancy payments.

This is the group of people whom I believe Senator Newman and certainly the Australian Democrats are most concerned about. It may not be a large group; it could be between 10 and 20 people. In reality, it appears already to be a group of five to 10 people. We have to remember that these people are having this imposed upon them by a decision of the Commonwealth. Their life circumstances are being impacted upon, but they are not being offered any redundancy provision. We see them, to use Senator Newman's expression-one that we shared yesterday-as tantamount to being civil conscripts. They really do not have much choice. It would seem that they have been caught up in what is virtually a package deal. Not only has the plant been sold, but also the employees have been transferred, some of them without much real choice. In fact, a package deal has been undertaken which involves not only the sale of the plant, but also the sale of the expertise, the skills, the knowledge and the know-how that have been working within it.

In the old days if one sold the boat and the rowers it was called slavery, but perhaps that is putting too much of an emotional interpretation on it. We are simply citing the fact that there is potential for injustice. In the committee stage of this debate we will be seeking assurances from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that those injustices can be attended to through regulation. As I cited earlier, it is a curious situation that these injustices are not catered for within the Bill itself, but we are dependent upon the provisions of the Public Service Act to cater for those potential injustices.

It was the intention of the Australian Democrats to attempt to resolve this difficulty with an amendment and an amendment has been circulated. However, I now give notice that that amendment will not be moved. We are not convinced that it will achieve what we are hoping to achieve. It was only in the last 48 hours that we became fully informed, through our discussions with the Opposition and the Minister, as to the diverse implications of this Bill. It is quite complex. Although we thought that an amendment would correct the situation, we do not now believe that it would.

In essence, what we were hoping to do was to impose a period of 12 months during which people had the right to make a choice, should an offer be made to them by the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation, as to re-entering that work force without loss of entitlement. We understand that, due to complications in the Public Service Act, that is not possible. Once redundancy payments have been accepted by a public servant they cannot be re-paid under any circumstances. The only way in which we could achieve that would be to insert a delay clause of 12 months before anybody received redundancy payments. Clearly this would be quite unsatisfactory for the majority who, by virtue of the nature of the shrinkage of the work force from 1,000 to 300, would take their money, go elsewhere and build a new work life.

In essence, we have no fundamental objection of what the Government is intending to do, namely, to render the Williamstown Dockyard more efficient by its privatisation thus avoiding a huge burden upon the public purse. We simply state the fact that there is potential for injustice to be done and the matter cannot be resolved through an amendment to this Bill. We will be calling upon the Minister-we understand that the Opposition will also do this-to offer adequate assurances that these difficulties can be resolved, and will be resolved, through regulation. If we believe that the assurances are not adequate we will move a motion that the Bill be adjourned to the next session. We hope that that action will not be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate is debating a Bill for an Act to make provision for certain employees of the Williamstown Dockyard. Staff at the Williamstown Dockyard number approximately 1,600. What is involved here is the sale of the dockyard to a new owner. It happens to have been owned by the Commonwealth of Australia and the new owner will be private industry. The Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987 deals with the conditions for those Public Service employees who may be made redundant in the changeover.

SPEECH.PARA: With the greatest of respect, I would suggest that for Senator McLean to talk about this measure in terms of civilian conscripts and slavery is to put an incorrect emotional connotation on what, in one sense and at one level, is just a normal, everyday, commercial transaction going on in the business world. We have a responsibility, insofar as we are the representatives of the former owners, and our concern is the welfare of those men and women who have been employed at the Williamstown Dockyard and we do not wish to see them unfairly disadvantaged in any way at all in the transfer. At present they are employed under the Public Service Act or under the Naval Defence Act.

Williamstown was a Royal Australian Navy dockyard. It dealt purely with building, re-fitting and modernising Navy ships. In 1982 it was transferred out of the control of the Navy into the Department of Defence. After having been advertised for an appropriate period it has been sold to the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation with two ships on order-the O5 and the O6, the last two of the FFGs to be bought for the Royal Australian Navy contracted to be built at Williamstown Dockyard. In April 1986 figures, that was an approved expenditure of $835,240,000. So we can see that nearly $1 billion of work is on the books for the incoming company.

The purchaser, the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation, must have staff to operate the dockyard to build these ships. There are not many shipyards in Australia on which to draw for staff so the presumption is that the great majority of present employees at the Williamstown Dockyard will be employed by the new owners. The O5 and O6 are relatively large ships by Australian naval standards. They will have a full load displacement of 3,650 tons.

Up to the present time employees could apply to leave the Commonwealth service subject to the approval of the Government because it wished to retain certain key personnel who are critical to the operation of the dockyard. Apart from those whom the Government wished to retain, employees of the dockyard had the right to leave and were eligible for redundancy payments. Redundancy payments were quite generous. They provide all leave entitlements-long service leave, recreational leave, 3 1/2 times their superannuation contributions, two weeks salary for each year of service up to a maximum of 24 years and four weeks termination pay-that were due to employees.

The dockyard has now been sold and we enter into a transition period which will run for some months. During this period employees can leave or they can accept employment with the new owner. Those who leave are eligible for redundancy pay, as I understand it, and those who are offered less by the company than they are receiving at the present time will also be entitled to apply for redundancy pay. But those who are offered the same pay and elect not to take it are deemed to have resigned and, basically, their entitlement is diminished in that circumstance because they get the re-payment of their superannuation contributions plus interest and their leave entitlements, which is considerably less than that of those who are officially declared redundant.

In general, the Opposition supports what the Government is doing. I think the Government has gone as far as it can in looking after the welfare of the employees of this dockyard. It has to be put on the record that probably no operation in Australia, no engineering works, has had the abysmal record that the Williamstown Dockyard has had over such a very long period. I think it is generous of the Government, on behalf of the people of Australia, to now offer redundancy terms when one looks at the hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars that this dockyard has cost the taxpayer over the years of its life, which goes back over 100 years.

Senator McLean said that we will raise some points in the committee stage of the debate and make a judgment as to whether amendments are required to look after some special cases or clear up some areas of uncertainty. The Opposition overwhelmingly supports and applauds the decision to sell the dockyard. The general rule that I hold-I do not hold it dogmatically or ideologically-is that governments simply should not be in commercial operations if they can be operated by the private sector. The reasons for that are basic and fundamental.

The Public Service, it does not matter how intelligent or how devoted it is, simply does not have the experience in the commercial world that enables people to make a profit on a commercial operation. One has to make a profit if one is to stay in business. The Public Service does not have the judgment and, above all, it does not provide a system of incentives and rewards in the commercial field. If a public servant, who is the head of a department, gets involved in some commercial venture and loses $100m a year, no one censures him. When he comes before an Estimates committee, no one ever censures him for the lack of commercial judgment because it was a policy decision by the Government. But the taxpayer pays. In fact, the taxpayer probably pays twice because the person who loses $100m gets an increase in staff and probably advances up the promotional ladder, so he can lose $150m next year. Similarly, when someone is successful there is no way of beating the Public Service pay and salary structure to give him the sorts of rewards that he would get in private industry. In the past in Australia there was a definite need for the Government to be involved in commercial ventures. We had a very big country with a very low population and above all-this is the critical point-we were short of capital. It was very hard to raise money in Australia. It was relatively easier for the government of the day to go to the international markets and get the funds to build railways, government dockyards and all the things that were needed to develop the country.

But that is all changed; we are in the 1980s now and we have no problems at all in raising capital. As the boards of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines have made very clear, private industry finds it easier to raise capital for these enterprises in the commercial world than the Government does because the only way the Government can raise it is by taxing or by borrowing and taxing again to pay for the interest on it. That leads me to the crucial point: it is not difficult to raise capital now, but it is difficult to meet the interest payments on it. Private industry is much better able to meet those interest payments than governments.

We applaud the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard to private industry. The Government has been aware of the abysmal record of this institution and over the last two or three years it has tried as hard as it can to reform it. But the Government has recognised that while there have been some improvements-some of which have been significant-these are nowhere near enough. The reason why it cannot get enough improvements is that being a Labor Party government it is a captive of the trade union movement. We are bedevilled by the rigidity of the work practices dictated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its minions. In a flash of honesty the Government has recognised that as it will never beat the union movement, and as it will never make Williamstown Dockyard efficient, it will sell it. Although that move was reached by a tortuous path, we applaud it.

But the point I want to put before the Senate this morning is that selling the dockyard to private industry does not necessarily solve any problems. It does not necessarily save the taxpayer one cent. Unless the Royal Australian Navy and the Department of Defence get their act together and run the program correctly, with correct program management, instead of our paying taxpayers' money directly to the dockyard for a hugely expensive program, we will now pay it through the circuitous route of paying for cost overruns caused by inefficiency. We are looking at a very big program here. As I said before, in April 1986 the approved cost was $835.24m. By the time the ships are completed in the mid-1990s, the program will probably cost at least $1.2 billion. It is very difficult to get out of the Navy figures relating to costs. I have gone back through a few of the recent Estimates committee transcripts. I would like to quote from them to illustrate how I have tried to determine from the Navy the cost of this program. Unless the FFGs can be built at a reasonable price, we are better off buying them overseas and using the scarce funds to put some weapons on them and to flesh out the Department of Defence, thereby giving it an operational capability. On 17 April 1986-in the Estimates Committee hearings I asked a general question on shipbuilding. The Hansard reads as follows:
How is the frigate construction at Williamstown going? Has it been subjected to any audit in any way at all?
Rear-Admiral West-It has not been subject to an audit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it on time and is it on cost?

SPEECH.PARA: Rear-Admiral West-It is running on cost at the moment. It is about two to three months behind in its current program. I do not know that that means it will be delivered late.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a contradictory statement.
—As Senator Watson says, it is a contradictory statement. On 18 September 1986 at an Estimates Committee hearing I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Williamstown Dockyard construction of the fifth frigate on schedule and on budget?
Commodore Hunt replied:

Let me try to separate those two questions. Indeed, my compatriots from the Office of Defence Production might want to join the conversation. Because of the number of issues involved in this project, which sees the first major warship construction at Williamstown for a long time, the agreements reached between the Navy, Defence Production and the Dockyard allow for a band of completion. For instance, we have set ourselves the task that the first ship will complete within a band of June 1990 to June 1992. The answer then to your first question is: Yes, it is inside that band. However, having set ourselves a plan to stick to the front end of the band as a guideline, the answer is: No, we are probably just a little under nine months.
I presume that is behind. On 7 April 1987 Senator Vigor asked how the AFP 05 was going with respect to schedules and budgets. The answer from Commodore Hunt was:

Senator, 05 is now scheduled to be completed by mid- 1991. As I have explained in previous hearings of this Committee, the agreement between Navy, the customer and yard management, was that 05 would be delivered in the band 1990-92 and 06 in the band 1994-96. So while the slippage in the front end of the band has been something like nine months for 05, she is still inside the agreed delivery time.
At the last Estimates hearing on 22 October 1987 I asked the question again of Rear-Admiral West:
Is the Australian frigate program, given the rubbery limits you have for schedules, within those limits?
The Hansard record then reads:
Rear-Admiral West-It is still in those limits.

TALK.START.PARA: —How have the dockyard staff been performing? Have you had any industrial problems?

SPEECH.PARA: Rear-Admiral West-They have come along quite well. They seem to be improving as the years go by and they get used to building ships again. At the moment we are perfectly on schedule and on budget for our anticipated progress this year.

The very fact that we have these rubbery time spans of about two years for the completion of the ship speaks volumes for the confidence that the Department of Defence does not have in the dockyard. But we will wait and see how these costs pan out. One is left with the impression that the decision in late 1983 by the Labor Government to award the contract to Williamstown Dockyard was made initially to satisfy the union movement so that it had some work on hand. Also, when the Government realised that it was going to sell the dockyard it was convenient to be able to fatten the goose before it was killed by having nearly $1 billion on the order books.

The fact that we are building these ships at Williamstown also raises the very real question of whether we need to build warships in Australia, given the facts of life in the 1980s. The question really turns on how much of a premium we pay for building them in this country. It is worth paying some amount of money and we can argue as to how much it is, whether it be 5 per cent or 10 per cent. It is probably not worth paying much more than 10 per cent for home construction because we do not get terribly much out of building warship hulls in this country. The great technology transfer comes from the weapons systems and the electronics. We would be much better off buying the hulls overseas, if there is a significant cost difference, and doing the fit-out in Australia and developing our own electronic industries. There is simply no flow-on to the commercial world from the skills we learn in warship hull construction. The commercial shipbuilding world is dominated by the Koreans, the Chinese and the Japanese and we will never be able to compete with them.

One of the great difficulties we find in this Parliament is dealing with the Department of Defence and getting information from it as to what its objectives are and how it arrives at its decisions, particularly with regard to the Navy. I am on record as saying that I find the Department of Defence the worst department to extract information from. I place on record also the fact that the Navy is the worst of the three Services from which to obtain any information in public. From that limited information that is available, one can make a few observations. Navy seldom seems to know clearly what it wants and how it wants to go about getting it. It also has the fatal habit of always wanting to have its own unique design. It always wants a ship specifically designed for tasks that no other navy requires. The building of a ship is a very complex exercise. It is as complex as the building of an aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happened with the Tobruk.

—The demand for a unique design incurs enormous cost penalties on the taxpayer. The Navy has never been able to satisfy me or anyone else in this Parliament that the huge cost penalties of its unique designs are beneficial, desirable and cost effective. We would never dream of saying to aircraft manufacturers around the world that the Royal Australian Air Force wants a fighter plane with specific performance characteristics. We would not do that in regard to a strike aircraft or a transport aircraft, either. We would look at what was available on the world market and pick the most appropriate from a production line in existence. Maybe we would modify it slightly in relation to the weapons fit. That is what happened with the F18. A fault analyser that was a little different from that installed by the Americans was installed. Most importantly, we installed a high frequency radio, which was quite a complex modification. Basically we buy the design that exists. But Navy always requires its own design. That has cost us a fortune.

SPEECH.PARA: Navy has tried to cover up this criticism by saying that it always calls in its tenders for a built design-a design that is already in service. From memory, Navy has never honoured this undertaking in the contract. It has always ignored it once it assesses designs. The Fremantle class was not a built design. It represented a stretching of a stretched design that was built for the New Zealand Navy, which was a stretch design of a patrol boat built for the Persian Gulf. It was only the brilliance of North Queensland Engineers and Agents Pty Ltd that enabled that ship to be built on time and on budget. As Senator Watson interjected a few minutes ago, HMAS Tobruk was probably the closest to a built design that the Navy achieved, but it blew it by using a heavier grade steel. The ship cannot beach in the way in which it is meant to beach, and discharge its tanks and cargo on to the beach, because it now has a heavier grade plate which means that it has a deeper draught that will not permit it to go as close to the shoreline, so it is in deeper water when the doors open.

HMAS Success, built in the French Durance class, was another bungled design. It probably cost two to three times what it was contracted to cost, because of Navy's mismanagement. Simple things that Navy did continually while the ship was being built added immeasurably to the cost. I will give the Senate one example. Navy decided it required a heavier pallet size for ammunition and stores. Because the pallet size was heavier, it needed a bigger forklift truck. This meant there was a greater all-up weight for the pallet and forklift truck. That meant that the decks buckled, so heavier steel plates had to be put on the decks where the cargo was carried. This meant that heavier deck beams were required. The whole thing rolled on exponentially, due to a lack of management skill by the Navy. It did not know what it wanted.

We have been through the drama of the submarine program. We find out now that the bow section and, it is rumoured, probably the stern section, will have to be built in Sweden because the Swedes simply do not know how to build power discharge tubes into a bow section for a submarine which is nearly twice the size of any submarine they have built before. Again, it was supposed to be a built design. But Navy rejected the only two built designs that are in existence in the world today-the Upholder class by the Vickers Shipbuilding company for the Royal Navy, and the RNV Walrus design for the Royal Netherlands Navy. The two built designs were excluded from the submarine program. I warn the Navy that the day is moving inexorably closer when, in light of information now appearing about that submarine program, the Senate will set up a select committee to inquire into all matters pertaining to its selection.

The Navy simply has no idea what it wants from the Anzac class. At an Estimates committee hearing on 22 October, various officers of the Department, in answer to questions as to what the design requirements were for that ship, stated in effect that they wanted a hull for $240m. They have no idea what the weapons fit will be. They talk loosely about `fitting as required'. One of the facts of modern life is that, as the British found when they sent ships to the Falklands without air defence weapons systems fitted to them, one must come as one is when an emergency starts. One does not have time to put ships into dockyards and spend six or nine months fitting them with elaborate air defence weapons systems or anti-submarine sensors. If those ships are not fitted up there is not much use having them. Yet that seems to be the mistake we are making with the Anzac class.

Navy simply does not seem to have any concept of operations. More accurately, the concept of operations that Navy has will not stand up to any rigorous intellectual examination. The result is that we have now committed about $8 billion to $10 billion of taxpayers' money to the submarine program, the FFGs and the Anzac class. This will take up half of the capital expenditure during the next 10 to 15 years. We must ask: Are these the right priorities for the shipyards and the Navy to be embarked upon? I would argue that they are not the right priorities. Because we do not have a concept of operations from Navy that is realistic, we do not know what equipment is needed. The obvious deficiency is the lack of any amphibious capability. As I said years ago in the Senate, in any emergency in which we are involved we will need to deploy troops and equipment over the beaches in the South Pacific region. That dictates some amphibious capability. Yet it was Navy's own decision to cancel the amphibious capability we have, to disband the amphibious squadron and disperse the talent that we had. Not only is it a Navy loss; it is an Army loss. For years the Army's 6th Brigade at Enoggera simply has not been able to do any amphibious training. The ships are no longer there.

We have no organic air power at sea. That means we cannot protect the ships in a hostile environment. It is absolutely mandatory that one has air power at sea. That was learnt generations ago. The greatest threat we face today does not relate to battleships coming over the horizon or submarines torpedoing ships; it relates to a simple aircraft with an Exocet, Harpoon or other air launched air to surface anti-shipping missile. It is a cheap, deadly, effective weapon. The only counter to that is anti-air-being able to establish air superiority around the ship or ships that are operating in that area. It is a prime essential for the Royal Australian Navy to have that, yet the Navy will not do a damned thing about it; nor will the Government. We are spending a huge amount on antique diesel electric submarines. No other power in the world would be embarking on this course for its sole sub-surface element, upon a diesel electric build, which is already outdated before the first one comes into service.

The matter of redundancy payments for dockyard workers raises some significant questions for this country. It is not simply a matter of whether we make redundancy payments to the dockyard workers; of course, we should. We have an obligation to look after their welfare. We also have an obligation to the people of Australia and the taxpayers to ask what the dockyard is doing. There are a number of profound questions on this matter that the Government simply avoids.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator MacGibbon make the point that no government-owned enterprise could make a proper commercial decision and that it was fairly inevitable that Williamstown Dockyard would go out of business. I suggest to him that he should do a little research and find out why the shipyard at Whyalla, the Evans-Deakin Industries Ltd shipyard in Brisbane, the shipyard at Maryborough, which was owned by Walkers Ltd, and the shipyards at Mortsdock and Newcastle came to grief. Most of those shipyards were run by private companies and were able to make commercial decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman talked about how bad the union position was. She should note that the term `industrial relations' obviously implies that there are two sides to any argument, that two sets of forces operate in any enterprise-that is, the one that looks after the interests of members of unions and the one that looks after the interests of management. Either the unions or management can make mistakes; either one or the other can make decisions which may be based sometimes on a feeling of anger or a feeling of not being able to achieve what is believed should be achieved. I do not think anybody can reasonably suggest that all of the problems-or most of them even-at the Williamstown Dockyard were caused by trade union activity.

The shipyards that I have referred to perished as a result of demarcation disputes and work practices. I have been involved with those and know a bit about them from personal experience. This cannot be said for honourable senators opposite who seem to substitute ignorance for expertise. Those work practices, which originated in the United Kingdom, were engaged in by both management and trade unions. I say categorically that this was not a good arrangement. Such practices have begun to cease; a move away from that concept is already proceeding.

The unions had to make a decision about what they would do at Williamstown when they were faced with the possibility of closure. Obviously they sat down and negotiated a settlement for the transfer of ownership with compensation for people who would be likely to lose their jobs and move out of the industry. Senator McLean has talked about the arrangement as a package. It is quite normal for such a package to be negotiated between two interested parties. I think it is important to be concerned about what will happen at Williamstown from now on. Honourable senators opposite can parade this rubbish about past conflicts and say that what has happened will always happen in the future. It is easy to do this, particularly if one is ignorant and does not know what industrial relations are all about. It is quite easy to talk from that point of view.

I suggest that both management and the trade unions have learnt from the past. The trade unions, for instance, have developed policies and taken action in regard to education and training and skills formation. Some of the unions have moved towards amalgamation. The unions have also sought to change work practices of their own volition on the basis of merit. Let us look at a classic example. For many years shipwrights and boilermakers had fierce arguments, which sometimes involved other engineering trades in the shipyard. The metal workers union and the shipwrights amalgamated. As a result of that amalgamation, a proposition was put and negotiated with the employer to establish the position of shipbuilding tradesman under which tradesmen of three different types could perform the one function and as a result become much more efficient and eliminate restrictive work practices. That is a practical application of union amalgamation. It is not airy-fairy rubbish such as that that the Opposition talks about always, as I have said, from a position of absolute ignorance. That is what has been done already. We should also take note of the work practice changes which are already in the pipeline; the fact that amalgamations are going to be extended further, which will remove friction from the area of work application, the area of who may do a particular job; the question of job security; and the question of skills formation, which means multi-skilling. All of these things have been done. A new approach is needed. The trade unions have taken that new approach; they have taken the lead. I suggest that the Opposition should read some of the interesting comments in Australia Reconstructed which refer to many of these things.

We need industrial democracy if we are to have the best possible result at Williamstown. We need the involvement of the workers in decision making. When they achieve the sorts of productivity levels that are possible they need to have a clear understanding of what they are about, why and how they will benefit. It is very obvious that they need the support of a national enlightened union to assist them in formulating ideas and policy in this matter and to give them some instruction on how they should behave and respond to employers. Also, some pressure needs to be put on employers in relation to their standard of behaviour. There needs to be some sort of mutual approach which will lead to increased productivity, keep the shipyard alive, maintain the level of jobs in excess of 1,000 and create a position where the workers will benefit in terms of the income which they take home to their families. The community will benefit because the workers have a taxpaying capacity and are creative. The continuation of the shipyard will mean that we will not have to purchase ships overseas and this will result in a large difference in terms of our balance of payments. I think the Bill is a good one and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987. I do not intend to canvass the detailed redundancy aspects of the Bill which have been adequately debated by my colleagues. I look forward to the new philosophy, direction and attitude of the union movement towards shipbuilding in Australia. Unfortunately, the Williamstown Dockyard has had in its recent history a very checkered career. It is hoped that the sale of the controlling interest to private enterprise will lead to a new era of success and profitable operations for the yard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us this morning serves a twofold purpose: first, it will bring about a major restructuring of the defence shipbuilding industry; and, secondly, it will have long term benefits for the defence budget. Naturally, the Opposition supports this sort of philosophy and hopes that the two aims which have been outlined by the Government will be realised. But I think we have to be somewhat realistic in recognising that Williamstown, unfortunately, has not completed a warship since the HMAS Swan in the 1970s. However, the yard has been involved in the modernisation and fitting out of river class vessels and is involved in the Australian frigate program.

I think it is good that the State Government of Victoria and the unions have supported the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard. I think the sale price was approximately $100m. But the Senate should be reminded that the problems at Williamstown actually began in 1975 as a consequence of an ill-judged decision by the Whitlam Government, coupled with the prevailing national economy of the day, to cancel the DDL project which would have seen Williamstown building three sophisticated destroyers designed specifically for Australian needs. As a result, Williamstown as such was left with a skilled labour force and little work to do. This is another thing that we can thank the Whitlam Government for. The Fraser Government took a much more constructive approach when it came to office. A committee was established under the chairmanship of Mr Ross Hawke, a senior shipbuilding executive, to study the Williamstown Dockyard and make some recommendations as to its future use. Mr Ross Hawke recommended privatisation. It is pleasing to see the bipartisan support which has been given to this Bill which moves in the privatisation direction. I only hope that after this sale takes place the new management at Williamstown will be more responsive than the management has been in recent years. The long time lags and delays in the work of the yard are to be eliminated.

In the House of Representatives, the Liberal National Party shadow Minister for Defence, Mr Peter White, an ex-defence man, gave the example of a nine-month delay in getting materials into the yard because of the tendering system and the long bureaucratic processes. In the course of preparing a review of defence project management as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I visited the Williamstown naval dockyard. Following that visit, I am not surprised that the yard was forced to move to privatisation. The lack of some safety features was really quite alarming and gave no credit either to management or to unions. I will give three brief examples.

Although there were adequate warnings around the plant about safety issues, there appeared to be both a management and a union disinclin- ation to enforce even the most minimal of safety measures. I acknowledge that the yard had good, up to date technical, physical features. On the safety aspect, we witnessed a man assisting another man who was cutting metal. That assistant had no eye protection even though metal was being cut with a gas torch. We witnessed employees carrying around sheets of metal with the naked hand, without glove protection. These people were wearing sandshoes. However, an adequate supply of gloves and steel-capped boots was available in the store. While some people were wearing them, a significant number were not wearing metal-capped boots or safety gloves and were handling freshly-cut metal. In the pit area of the dock, where cranes and gantry were moving overhead, not all employees were wearing hard helmets.

The success of the sale is highly dependent on the attitude of the unions. New approaches will have to be devised to maximise the introduction of new technology and modern work practices. I thank Senator Burns for his assurance on behalf of the union movement that it has acknowledged the need to implement new work practices. But one of the problems of this dockyard under the old regime appeared to be the inability of the manager of the dockyard to control his employees. The problem was that there were too many bureaucrats of independent status, operating from Canberra, who had a finger in the operations. An example is that the manager's right to fire for violations of safety issues and other related matters was a drawn-out and complicated process which required numerous contacts and communications with Canberra. The other big difficulty was that there was a lack of performance targets. That sort of operation should have provided an ideal opportunity for what is now known as program budgeting.

Despite the sale of the dockyard, we hope that the Department of Defence-which will still have quite a close interest in the dockyard because it will be building for defence purposes-takes notice of the Public Accounts Committee's 223rd report. For example, we drew attention to the need for there to be skilled departmental quality assurance personnel on site in sufficient numbers to efficiently and effectively fulfil the quality assurance programs, because that is where there have been significant delays in relation to our shipbuilding program. One cannot blame the dockyards, as such, for these problems. The blame must go well and truly to Defence. The members of all future on-site resident Department quality assurance teams must have adequate skills and expertise and a clear understanding of departmental policy on quality assurance.

The Australian Shipbuilders Association feels that there should be a review of the contracting arrangements for ship construction. I remind the Government that the most effective form of industry protection is the construction of ships in Australia, because the maintenance of a de-fence capability of the industry would be greatly assisted if we had a proper sequence of defence orders. Unless there is that sort of continuity, one cannot blame the dockyard for loss of ear-nings. We have to acknowledge that the Government has bitten the bullet in making this decision. Naturally, we congratulate the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, on this. But I am disappointed that this step has taken such a long time, and that the delay, inaction and resulting inefficiency unfortunately have brought about a decline in morale at the Williamstown Dockyard. It has plummeted.

The Government has also announced that the lease of the Cockatoo Island Naval Dockyard will not be renewed after the current refitting work on the Oberon class submarines is completed in the 1990s. We on this side of the House believe that this should lead to a sensible and, hopefully, effective rationalisation of shipbuil-ding and fitting facilities to meet the requirements of the Royal Australian Navy as it moves into the twenty-first century.

In the other chamber, the Opposition really did not have a chance to refute some wrong allegations that were made by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, who contrived to blame the Fraser Government for the inefficiencies and lack of management at the Williamstown Dockyard. As I have pointed out, the problems of the dockyard began when men were recruited and equipment was purchased by the Whitlam Government to undertake the DDL project which, for political reasons, was then abruptly cancelled.

Contrary to the statement that the Fraser Government contributed to the problems of the yard, Mr Fraser and his then Minister, Sir James Killen, took a special interest in trying to solve the problems they inherited. Not only did they set up an expert committee under Mr Ross Hawke, but they implemented many of his recommendations. Certainly there have been enduring problems, which privatisation should address. But the point has to be made that it was a Labor government which originated many of these problems. So the taxpayer has already invested in all the new equipment and facilities, or much of it, required to build the light patrol frigates on time, to budget and to specification. So the decision behind this Bill to remove those aspects of the bureaucracy and the inflexible employee organisations which have hampered the Williamstown yard is welcome. Having reminded the Senate of the recent history of the Williamstown Dockyard, I join my colleagues in supporting this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions and their indicated support for the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill. The Government's decision to sell the Williamstown Dockyard was made in consultation with the work force there and it received, for the most part, support-it was not unanimous support from the work force. This Bill represents a package. It is always very difficult when people come along with further suggestions, wanting, perhaps, to put a bit more turkey on the plate, for us to accept them. It is the policy of this Government in this case to sell the dockyard. It does not indicate any greater policy of philosophical commitment to selling government enterprises. I note that my Victorian Australian Labor Party colleague, Mr Halfpenny, philosophically is opposed to privatisation. But on this occasion he was one of the negotiators who decided that it was in the best interests of the dockyard that it be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points were raised in the debate. Senator Newman referred in particular-and will probably do so again in the committee stage-to the situation regarding certain employees and their right to re-enter the Australian Public Service. This matter is not contained within this legislation. It is subject to the Public Service Act. I understand that the Department of Defence has written to the Public Service Commission suggesting that these people be given those sorts of rights. We do not have a response at this stage, and we cannot give a categorical assurance on those matters other than that our intentions are good and we believe that should be the position.

Senator McLean referred to people who receive equivalent offers from a purchaser but who, for personal reasons, do not want to take them up. These people are not in a true redundancy situation. The dockyard enterprise is on-going. It is therefore not appropriate that they should receive redundancy payments, because they have the opportunity for continued employment. It is not practical to give people in these situations unlimited choice. They do have certain choices before them. But no doubt these matters will be explored in the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the latest chapter in the saga of the Coastwatch contract, namely, his announcement last night that the interim Coastwatch contract now being performed by Skywest Aviation Pty Ltd will be extended for a year, to March 1989, that is, 18 months after the termination of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract in September. I note that the Minister in his statement says that the contract extension will be negotiated:

QUESTION.PARA: on the basis of an extension of the charging rates contained in the previous Skywest contract, with necessary allowances for the acquisition or modification of equipment.

I note that his Associate Secretary, Mr Roger Beale, told the Senate committee of inquiry that the existing rates for the interim service that Skywest is performing are lower than the rates for the original Skywest contract. In that event, will the rates to apply until March 1989 be the higher rates as in the original Skywest contract or an extension of the rates now being charged under the interim contract? Furthermore, what is the estimated cost of modification of equipment? Will this modification upgrade the Skywest aircraft in its service to the standard which Amann was intending to use, or will the Coastwatch service continue to operate for an extended period using planes below the standard specified in the previous tender requirements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major matter referred to when we talk about the modification or acquisition of equipment involved the re-establishment of the number of Skywest planes back to the basis of the original contract. There had been some divestment of planes by Skywest in anticipation of the contract going elsewhere, but once it became apparent that the interim arrangements were going to extend for a number of months-at least 12 and now 18-it became apparent that there would be a necessary re-acquisition program which would involve the amortisation of the capital expenditure incurred over a relatively short period, and thus justify some increase in the rates involved. How precisely the different elements of the equation will fall out in the final calculation of the rates payable is a subject of discussion with Skywest at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: It would be premature for me to go into any detail as to what precisely the rates would be, or how they would be put together, and what particular components would be attributed to what. I am happy to make that information available once the arrangements are settled. Senator Durack will appreciate that, although it is a commercial negotiation taking place within limited parameters, it is nonetheless a commercial negotiation and it does not help any such negotiation to embark on public discussion in the kind of detail that he is suggesting that we ought to.

To my knowledge, there has not yet been any discussion as to whether the modification to Skywest aircraft should include some of the modifications that were proposed to the basic equipment in what was to be the current period of the contract-for example, larger bubble windows than are presently installed on Skywest aircraft, and other matters of that kind. It is a matter for consideration as to the capital costs involved in making those modifications, as compared with the extra degree of efficiency in the surveillance task that would be associated with carrying them out. It is a matter to be considered as to how that balance falls out. I may not be in a position by Question Time on Friday to elaborate further on these matters, but if I am I will do so Senator Durack. Otherwise, I will let him know as soon as possible.

Are those the rates under the interim contract or are they the rates under the old Skywest contract? I refer again to what his departmental Associate Secretary, Mr Beale, said when asked about this matter in the Senate committee recently, which was:

What rates are we talking about-those under the previous contract or those under the interim contract?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would need to check what Mr Beale has said, as I have not read his evidence and I am not sure whether the passage that Senator Durack has quoted is to be taken as saying that the original rate has prevailed but with some add-ons during the interim period, or whether a new rate has been struck. It is not my impression that a new rate has been struck, but it was my impression that there were some negotiated add-ons to cover the particular contingencies and the circumstance that the numbers were larger. Whether the basic rate in issue is the previous base rate, or whether it has changed, I am not certain. Essentially, my answer is the same as the one I gave before. I am not prepared to speculate or discuss detailed matters of rates and charges which are presently the subject of negotiation by the Commonwealth, with the taxpayer's interests in mind. Senator Durack has been around this place long enough to appreciate that, without wanting to score some cheap political points in pursuing a matter which has no further milage in it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise on the Government's plans for the construction of the air traffic control training college which had been proposed for the Watson High School in Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me clear up a further loose end which has been the subject of some discussion and a point of interest for the Opposition. The situation is as follows: The Cabinet has decided to defer further the commencement of the construction of the proposed aviation central training college to enable consideration of an alternative concept for the training of air traffic control and flight service staff, involving that training taking place in a technical and further education (TAFE) college or a college of advanced education (CAE) environment. Up until now, air traffic services staff have been trained on an in-house, salaried basis by the Department of Transport and Communications, formerly the Department of Aviation. Planning was well under way to continue that in-house training concept at a new college to be constructed at the former Watson High School site here in Canberra. This would replace the existing outmoded and cramped facilities in Melbourne.

ANSWER.PARA: The new alternative concept, which has emerged primarily from a proposal put forward by the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology (TSIT) in Launceston, would involve trainees completing a two-year associate diploma course which would be capable of later being upgraded by additional study to a three-year, full diploma course. Students on this sort of model would receive cadetships rather than being salaried as government employees from the outset. It has become apparent to the Government, looking at this proposal, that it holds potential for quite significant savings through undertaking training at an existing institution rather than a new facility being built especially for this purpose. In particular, it would exploit opportunities for linking the course work with training currently being provided at the Commonwealth funded Australian Maritime College in Launceston in areas such as radar and search and rescue. In addition to a thorough evaluation of that TSIT proposal, consideration would also be given to the potential for associating a Canberra-based alternative with the Australian Capital Territory TAFE colleges or CAE. We want to look at the full range of options thrown up by this new proposal to look at the training in a tertiary context, rather than just an in-house professional context as previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it at the CCAE.

—I have already said that we will look at the TAFE and CCAE alternatives. A detailed review of these two different approaches will now be conducted-but within a short time frame-and completed in order to allow a final decision by the Government in February, which will in turn still allow a 1989 start-up for the new training program. I should say that this review will involve consideration of such matters as, obviously, the relative costs of the proposals and the educational advantages of the respective proposals, including in particular educational requirements for the performance of air traffic services functions and the effects on the career prospects of the staff concerned. It will address the impact of the proposals on the efficiency and effectiveness of air traffic and flight services programs and, in particular, it will address the balancing of supply with demand, which is a real problem the more one lengthens out these courses. Obviously, it will also address the longer term implications of the different approaches for salary levels and staffing arrangements generally.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I should say that although there have been expressions of interest in conducting this kind of training in other cities, and in other institutions in other cities, the Government's further consideration of this issue will be limited to the Launceston and Canberra options, not only because of obvious timing constraints but also because of the equally obvious locational advantages of each-Launceston by virtue of the scope for co-ordination with the Maritime College, and Canberra through the potential for efficiency gains through co-ordination with my Department and the soon to be established Civil Aviation Authority.
