QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: TAX POLICY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to his answer yesterday to a question asked by Senator Zakharov regarding a letter from Mr Howard to his colleagues rejecting the proposition that the tax policy of the Liberal Party of Australia was based on supply-side theory. Has the Minister, as he said yesterday he hoped he would, received any further information in relation to the evidence Mr Howard has put forward in regard to his contention that his were not supply-side proposals? If so, what is that information and will it provide a basis for any change in Government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time I expressed my disappointment that nobody in the Liberal Party had yet leaked to me a copy of Mr Howard's letter. The degree of unity in the Liberal Party has now been so enhanced that it took a whole three hours before a couple of pages from the letter hit my office in the proverbial brown paper envelope. I presume the reason that I did not get all the other pages-the ones I got were numbered 17 and 18-was that whoever it was who leaked the letter to me was mentioned unfavourably in some of the other pages. If somebody else cares to supply the first 16 pages I would be grateful to receive those as well. Perhaps the letter went out only to members of the Liberal Party front bench, in which case the search for the leaker is narrowed down quite a bit. Anyway, on page 17 of the letter Mr Howard wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: During the campaign we were under attack from the Labor Party because of the alleged severity of the expenditure cuts that would be needed to pay for our tax reductions. The whole `Wendy Wood' series of TV commercials had this as their theme.
Now the claim is made that our policy was based on supply-side economics.
According to Mr Howard, `The conflict is obvious'. Of course, the fact is that the Opposition election policy contained both a supply-side component and a very large number of unfunded cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. No one would hesitate to describe the Minister's current ramblings as debating anything. It does appear to me that in substance he is debating the question rather than answering it. As I recall the question, which was asked a very long time ago now, it asked the Minister whether Government policy was going to be changed. Now he seems to be, as is usual, just wandering around tiptoeing through the tulips, in one way or another. Mr President, I suggest that you call him to order and if he is not interested in answering the question that was asked of him by his Western Australian colleague, may I suggest that you sit him down so that we can ask some other Minister a question.
—There is no point of order. Senator Walsh was asked whether he had received the document. He is quoting from it. But I remind the Minister again not to debate any issue when answering a question.

—Certainly, Mr President. I was also asked in the question whether Mr Howard had put forward a defence of his contention. As I said, there was of course both an unfunded cut component and a $900m supply-side component-plus, if I might say so, another $900m worth of blue sky in enhanced tax collection.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Is it the case that section 3 of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981, the section which excises the Koongarra mining project area from Kakadu National Park, has never been proclaimed? Does the Minister agree that this is an area of great ecological significance and that mining there would also make a significant impact on other sections of the park, especially the South Alligator River catchment area? In view of this and the second Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry report recommending against mining in the Koongarra area, will the Government move to repeal the Koongarra Project Area Act and return the excised Koongarra area to its rightful place in the Kakadu National Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to do is to look at the history of this matter. The Koongarra project area was first excluded from Kakadu National Park when stage 1 was nominated by the Fraser Government back in 1979. The purpose of that effort on the part of the Fraser Government was to vary the boundaries of Kakadu National Park to facilitate the Koongarra project. If section 3 of the Act were to be proclaimed now, the shape of the window would change. That does not mean that it would be eliminated; it just means that it would be altered. As far as the past is concerned, and even looking into the future, I have stated in this place on a number of occasions the Government's policy on uranium mining. It remains unchanged and, for the foreseeable future, it does not look like changing.

ANSWER.PARA: We have a three-mines policy for Nabarlek, Ranger and Roxby Downs, or Olympic Dam as it is otherwise known. Under the policy no approval would be given for mining at Koongarra and, in any event, no valid mining leases have been given over its area. Title to the land is in the Aboriginal Land Trust. Aboriginal agreement would, therefore, be required if we were to attempt to put it back in the park and to hand it over to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Of course, it is worth noting that the Northern Land Council has signed an agreement with Koongarra Energy Ltd on behalf of the Land Trust to become a joint venturer in any proposal. The fact that we are not allowing mining at Koongarra, and do not intend to allow mining at Koongarra, means that the environmental impact question simply does not arise. Finally, I point out to Senator McLean that repeal of the Koongarra Project Area Act would not change the current situation at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Transport and Communications give some indication of what mechanisms could be used to ensure that the aged, infirm, single parents and other low income groups that are particularly dependent on telephone communication are not disadvantaged by a move by Telecom Australia towards a system of timed local telephone calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should say at the outset that telephone call charges essentially are a matter for Telecom in the first instance rather than the Government, with any decision eventually made by Telecom being subject to close consideration by the Prices Surveillance Authority before it comes anywhere near the Minister for formal approval. Telecom is keen to have a proper, full public debate on the issue of timed local calls before introducing any system of call charges. Telecom will be setting that debate, I hope, on a solid basis with the Managing Director's proposed Press conference tomorrow, at which conference the reasons for Telecom wanting to go down this particular track will be fully explained and a number of different possible implementation options will be set out as a basis for discussion over the next six to nine months. For those sorts of reasons I have not wanted to pre-empt any of Telecom's presentation in this respect. But it might help to relieve some of the more extreme concerns that are presently being expressed if I were to mention now just some of the considerations that Telecom has in mind, which will be more fully explained tomorrow, focusing particularly on the problem to which Senator Schacht has adverted-that is to say, problems that will arise for pensioners, for the disabled and for those who use the telephone as a lifeline, if some very expensive new regime is introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is appropriate to make three points at this stage. The first is that any such proposal for timed local calls would necessarily involve a cheaper basic call rate than the present 20c. The basic timing unit would be longer than the three-minute timing unit presently used for subscriber trunk dialling (STD) purposes-it could be six minutes or it could be eight minutes; that is one of the things that are being talked about-and the rate for that basic unit would be less than the present 20c local call charge. I think it will put it in perspective if I say that the overwhelming majority of local calls will, in that context, clearly end up being very much cheaper than they are at the moment. More than 82 per cent of all local calls presently take six minutes or less. More than 88 per cent of all local calls presently take eight minutes or less. So against the background of whether the timing unit is six minutes or eight minutes and, on the basis that that timing unit will be charged for at a lesser rate than the present 20c--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are being brainwashed now.
—Shirley, give it a rest.

—Might I incorporate Senator Collins's interjection. On that basis, and for the reasons I have indicated, which I think even Senator Walters can appreciate, the overwhelming majority of local calls presently taking place would be cheaper under this regime.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point that I make is that any proposal for timed local calls would certainly involve very cheap off-peak rates. Among the options being considered in this respect, and which will be spelt out more fully tomorrow, is a combination along the following lines: for weekends, from 6 p.m. on Saturday to 8 a.m. on Monday a 60-minute call could be held for a single unit fee; that is to say, less than the present 20c. For a week night call from 6 p.m. through to 8 o'clock the following morning, it is currently anticipated that, under this sort of option-and there are many others that could be considered-a 30-minute call could be held for a single unit fee. So those are the sorts of options for extended calls that we are talking about that would be compatible with the timed local call system.

The third point that I make is that, in addition, it would be possible for specific provision to be made, for example for pensioners, by an extension of the present pensioner rebate system. It would be possible, for example, to make some provision along the following lines-and this is another sub-option that is being talked about: a rebate for eight free 10-minute calls made during the week-day non-concessional period, which would cost perhaps $5 to $10 per month. These sorts of proposals would be in addition to the other sorts of considerations that could be given by government departments and business organisations to a wider use of the 008 toll free number, as I mentioned the other day, and a number of other options of that kind.

Finally, Telecom is acutely conscious, as is, of course, the Government, of the sensitive and very different problems that are involved. But the problems with the present system are real and we really need to think in a serious way about workable and equitable solutions to these problems. I am sure that those solutions are possible.

—Mr President, after that last answer I am tempted to ask whether you will introduce time charging for answers to questions. My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, follows the fascinating answer that Senator Gareth Evans gave to Senator Messner's question, in which he suggested that the import of a telephone call from Sir Peter Abeles was that the Minister could make his own decision about the Coastwatch contract. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall a whole variety of communications being made, mostly by letter, and others being transmitted through the various Opposition parliamentarians who were acting as a conduit for the Skywest neuroses through the duration of the Amann affair. I have a vague recollection that some proposition along those lines may have been advanced. There were also threats of litigation made at various stages and, as I previously indicated, it was in the context of possible litigation on behalf of the Skywest interests that I recall the particular telephone conversation occurring. It is a grotesque misrepresentation of what I said for Senator Chaney to characterise it in the way that he did at the outset of his question.

ANSWER.PARA: I say finally that none of those recommendations from Skywest-whether along the lines of the one, if there was one, to which Senator Chaney was referring, or on any other basis, whether threatening litigation, threatening a withdrawal of services or generally carrying on; and there was a fair bit of carrying on going on during this period-made one iota of difference to the particular decision that I and the Government made in relation to the termination of the Amann contract. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Commonwealth would accordingly be forced to bear much of the odium of a major breakdown in the coastal surveillance service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, again, a vague recollection of Mr Beale talking to me in terms of the poo being likely to hit the fan. He expressed it a little bit more cautiously and a little bit more bureaucratically in the letter. But I repeat without equivocation the response I made earlier that, whatever the consequences that might be contemplated as flowing from Skywest behaving in any particular way during this affair, it is inconceivable that that could have influenced the decision that was made about Amann. Every decision that was made every step along the way that I was involved in from the time of taking up this office was based on an assessment of the contractual responsibilities of Amann, whether or not those responsibilities, those obligations, had been met, and the legal consequences that flowed from that. I reject absolutely the various snide innuendos and other forms of more direct challenge to my integrity that Senator Chaney is offering on this occasion as he does so often, in his usual oleaginous fashion.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I ask: Will the new Antarctic vessel, which is to be built in Australia as announced by the Minister today, have a significant effect on Australia's scientific research in the region?
—I am sorry, I did not hear who that question was directed to.
—Senator Richardson.
—I call the Minister for the Environment and the Arts.
—I am sorry, I did not hear the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I ask: Will the new Antarctic vessel, which is to be built in Australia as announced by the Minister today, have a significant effect on Australia's scientific research in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I apologise to the Senate for being momentarily distracted. But having just received the news that as a senator for New South Wales I will be able to remain one for some time without facing another election, I think that is a matter for some celebration and I was distracted. My apologies.
—I was reading the same document myself.
—I think the President and I are the happiest of the New South Wales senators but there are a few smiles around the room. Turning to Senator Zakharov's question, there are a number of implications--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I tabled a document, Mr President. I would like it to be tabled since it has not been tabled, as yet. I handed it to an attendant and I would like it to be tabled.
—How often have you asked for documents to be tabled?
—Order! The document will be tabled.

—There are some major implications that flowed from the Government's announcement this morning of the decision to have an Australian built, Australian crewed and, indeed, a ship flying the Australian flag as part of our Antarctic efforts. The first point to make is that in the Antarctic, if we have one scientific role of prime importance at present, it is in support of the Committee for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) and the treaty which deals with marine living resources. I think the fear shared not only by this country but also by a number of others is that the resources of the oceans in and around Antarctica are under threat. If we are to monitor those resources, we need adequate fish stock and scientific research methods. To do that we need a different construction. In a very short space of time we will have a platform on our new vessel which will double the capacity that we had with the Nella Dan and finally allow us to do all that we can under CCAMLR to monitor those fish stocks. I, for one, am delighted that members of the Cabinet have agreed to that.

ANSWER.PARA: The other problem not often discussed with the Nella Dan is that the only helicopters that we could have on board in travelling to and from the Antarctic had to be stored on deck. When they are stored on deck they are subject to weathering. Therefore, we could never get new ones. They were always old and very small. We are now able to get larger ones that have got medium and longer range. This will mean that we will be able to service our summer bases and will be able to go to other points of interest in that 42 per cent of the Antarctic which Australia claims as its territory. That will mean a significantly increased scientific effort from Australia and we will be able to hold our heads high for the first time in decades as a leading nation in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Prince Charming, the Minister for Transport and Communications. —I refer the Minister for Finance to the claim by Mr Howard, reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, that the effect of the Liberal's tax package would have been to cut more than on Mr Howard's own figuring, the $270m being `the difference between expenditure savings to be achieved under our policy in the first year and the cost of the proposed tax reductions in the first year'. Can the Minister explain the technique by which the deficit can be cut by more than the net figure for expenditure savings and tax reductions? If so, will the Government employ this technique in preparing the forthcoming May statement and the 1988 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook seems to have got hold of page 18 of the letter of the Leader of the Opposition to either his front bench or the Liberal Party caucus and he quoted from it. I was asked whether I can explain the technique by which the deficit can be cut by more than the net figure of expenditure savings and taxation measures. The answer is no, I cannot explain that. Therefore it is not a technique which the Government will be using. My inability to understand how that can be done may be related to my confident expectation that I would be able to add up a column of figures without making a $1,500m error. Perhaps Mr Howard's belief that one can get more from savings than the net figure for expenditure adjustments and tax changes is related to his inability to add up a column of figures. Nor can I understand how, as Mr Howard claimed, `the enhanced revenue base would not have been affected by our commitments to abolish the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax', but he also wrote that on page 18 of his letter.

ANSWER.PARA: More importantly, this letter ignores a number of other commitments that have already been given by the Opposition regarding the expenditure cuts that the Government made in its May statement. On page 18 of his letter Mr Howard stated:
The coalition would have left in place the measures contained in the May statement.

That is, if it had won the election. This statement cannot be reconciled with the undertaking given by Mr White in a Press release of 14 May to restore defence cuts, which are worth $350m, or the undertaking given by Peter Shack in Press statements on 13 and 18 May to restore education cuts, to remove restrictions on eligibility for Austudy, and to remove the assets test on the unemployment benefit for over 25-year-olds. In round figures, those measures are worth another $70m. Mr Howard's statement also cannot be reconciled with the undertaking given in a Press release of 14 May by John Moore, the shadow transport Minister, to restore cuts to road funding. Or by Michael Baume-remember Michael Baume, the one-time shadow Minister for Health?-in a Press release on 14 May promising to reverse changes to benefit arrangements for in-hospital private medical services. Those promises given by the Opposition to reverse May statement decisions represent a total of about $700m. Mr Howard is now writing to his own people, in what he was foolish enough to think would remain a confidential letter, that the coalition would have left in place the measures contained in the May statement.

I do not want to make this answer unduly long, Mr President, but I also draw attention to the promises of the National Party of Australia. In a Press release on 14 May the National Party communications spokesman, Mr Sharp, promised to reintroduce sales tax exemptions for major Commonwealth-owned authorities, such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post-that measure is worth nearly $400m-to restore cuts to road funding, and to remove the assets test for unemployment beneficiaries over 25 years old.

If the statement written by Mr Howard-I presume that it was circulated last week-that the coalition would have left in place the measures contained in the May statement is correct one can only assume that he and various other Opposition spokesmen, who promised in May to reverse a number of May statement decisions, were again fibbing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer to the answer given by the Minister, Dr Blewett, on Monday, 7 December, concerning the charge by Dr Jodhi Menon of the Private Doctors Association of Australia of massive medifraud taking place within the Health Insurance Commission by its employees. Did Dr Blewett mislead the other place when he said that Dr Menon had not provided concrete proof of his allegations to the Government? Why will the Government not release the Australian Federal Police report entitled Review of Fraud Against the Commonwealth completed last April instead of bouncing it around between Ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can add anything to what Dr Blewett told the House of Representatives last week. In his reply, Dr Blewett pointed out that Dr Menon had, in the past, made extravagant claims about Medicare and had never been able to substantiate them. For example, Dr Menon is reported to have claimed that Medicare had lost up to $5 billion in 10 years because of an elaborate computer fraud involving bogus cheques allegedly issued by Health Insurance Commission employees. Considering that Medicare is not quite four years of age, this is a remarkable revelation.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Blewett has acknowledged that clerical errors can occur, for example, when the doctor's provider number is not shown on account documents and staff are required to make a computer inquiry to try to locate the correct number. The error rate is low. For example, in September in New South Wales the error rate was only 0.29 per cent for direct bill claims and 2.14 per cent for patient claims.

It is the case that Dr Blewett said that Dr Menon had provided no concrete proof of his allegations, and he requested the Australian Federal Police to arrange to interview Dr Menon so that he could provide proof. In relation to the fraud report in which Senator Sheil expressed an interest, my colleague Senator Tate has just passed me a note pointing out that the Review of Fraud Against the Commonwealth was tabled some months ago. Senator Sheil will be able to read it at his leisure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Press release issued by Mr Peter Reith, shadow Attorney-General, concerning the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill recently passed by the Parliament? Is the Minister aware of comments made in the Press release that the number of bankruptcies in Australia is at record levels? Is the Minister also aware that when speaking to the Bill in the House of Representatives, the shadow Attorney-General attributed the level of bankruptcies to the Government's economic policies? How does the Minister respond to Mr Reith's assertions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. The matter of bankruptcies in the community is one of great importance, and Mr Reith has made much of it in his Press statement. I am sorry that he has departed from the bipartisan attitude which had characterised the approach of both sides of this chamber to the question of amendments to the bankruptcy law which, I thought, went through the Parliament earlier this session in a very good spirit. Figures show that, in the financial year ended 30 June 1987, 7,495 Australians became bankrupt, so obviously there is a serious problem within the community. We need to look a little behind these figures-as Mr Reith was quite capable of doing, but he chose to ignore a closer reading of them.

ANSWER.PARA: Figures provided by the Attorney-General's Department, which are in Mr Reith's possession, show that, although bankruptcies are on the increase, it is in the area of consumer bankrupts that this is so. By `consumer bankrupts' I mean those people who, in the course of their usual activities, have overcommitted themselves with credit providers and wind up being forced into bankruptcy either by their creditors or on their own application.

The passage of the Bankruptcy Amendment Act earlier this session and the action taken by my colleague the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Peter Staples, are positive signs that the Government is responding to the problem. In the Bankruptcy Amendment Act the Government introduced a pre-bankruptcy moratorium. There was evidence that persons in the community with debt problems were choosing to go bankrupt without fully appreciating the consequences. For example, it is not widely known in the community that a bankrupt must surrender his passport; nor can a bankrupt generally obtain credit. The moratorium gives the person a seven-day period of protection, a cooling-off period, so that he or she can seek advice as to alternatives to bankruptcy. We also propose to produce a video explaining in a clear way what bankruptcy is all about. People will be requested to view that upon attendance at the Federal Court registry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to send out a lot.

—Senator Walters can scoff and laugh but there have been cases where people have gone in and declared themselves bankrupt, as it were, on an impulse and got themselves into terrible strife rather than having this seven-day period in which to consider consulting some debt counsellor and going through all the implications. In any case, the Opposition supported this concept when the legislation was passed a few weeks ago. Apart from those amendments, the Minister for Consumer Affairs proposes to hold a debt summit early in the new year. In this way the question of how people become overcommitted and how this can be prevented will be addressed.
—How much are you wasting on that?

—Does Senator Alston not think it is a worthwhile exercise to try to find out why people in the community are being led into consumer bankruptcy? I think this is a very important issue which is harming many households and many good and decent Australians who find themselves trapped by the over- extension of credit by unscrupulous traders and finance companies. As to whether the Government's economic policy is, as Mr Reith suggested, the underlying reason for the increase in bankruptcies, that also has been well and truly rebutted, as a perusal of last Sunday's Times on Sunday article by Christine Rau would indicate. That article stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Analysts are also unanimous that a widespread lack of management expertise and more aggressive behaviour by the banks are more important as key reasons than the recession.
Richard Grellman, a partner with Peat Marwick Hungerfords, says that-
speaking of the experience of his firm-
those going broke on the land were one of the `rare instances' of economically induced bankruptcies.
`It generally has little to do with the economy. People are getting into business that are just not suitable or competent to run them. They would be better off employed by someone else' . . .

That is the opinion of a partner in a firm which over the last five years has done a tremendous amount of work in this area. The Professor of Business Studies at Wollongong, Professor Grant, has also made that very clear in his various comments on this subject. On the whole I am trying to say that there is a very real problem out in the community. This Government is attempting to tackle it by preventing people making impulsive and quick decisions to make themselves bankrupt, as it were. The summit being organised by my colleague Mr Peter Staples will, I believe, bear good fruit and prevent a lot of distress into which so many households are plunged.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. By way of preamble, I point out that this question is being asked because of the superficial, dismissive and ostrich-like attitudes repeatedly expressed by the Opposition to sound scientific evidence in relation to the greenhouse phenomenon. Is the Minister aware that a large number of high level scientific meetings have been held throughout the world in recent years on the so-called greenhouse phenomenon? Is the Minister aware that the United Nations Environment Program, the World Meteorological Office and the International Council of Scientific Unions have published a statement making the following predictions: a rise of between 1.5 and 4.5 degrees centigrade in global temperature; a rise of between 0.2 and 1.6 metres with a mean of 0.8 metres in sea level; and significantly different global weather patterns, all within 40 to 50 years from now? Has the Government adopted a preventive or adaptive attitude to these predictions? If preventive, how is the Government modifying policies in response to these predictions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a large number of high level scientific meetings to discuss the problem in recent times, the most recent to come to my attention having been the Greenhouse 87 conference held in Melbourne just a few weeks ago. I know that preparations are already in hand for a Greenhouse 88 conference to follow up the good start that was made this year.
—Call a summit.

—I would not treat this matter flippantly. I think the greenhouse effect is a little more important than to warrant a typical flippant response. I think Senator Hill should go back to the airport and get on another plane. He will find a destination; he always has. I am also aware that the predictions referred to by Senator Coulter, while they are certainly alarming, are within the broad range generally accepted in the world scientific community. That should be sufficient to make us all sit up and take notice, because such climatic effects would have devastating results for all parts of the globe. They would have devastating results economically, socially and environmentally. One wonders where our agriculture would be if this were to come true.

ANSWER.PARA: However, given that the main cause of the greenhouse effect is the combustion of fossil fuels, the response of the Australian Government-or, indeed, of governments around the world-will be difficult to ascertain at least in the first couple of years of looking at the problem. I think that Australia's response in the first instance should be to find out enough information upon which to react. The main problem with that is that most of the research from which the figures Senator Coulter quoted are drawn has been conducted in the Northern Hemisphere. Very little research has been conducted in our area of the woods, so to speak. That being the case, the Australian and New Zealand governments have already agreed to collaborate on scientific research into the problem. A couple of weeks ago my counterpart in the New Zealand Government, Mr Palmer-I might say, just as Minister for the Environment, that I have not reached his other dizzy heights-and I put out a Press statement to announce that we had held some discussions about that collaboration and about how it might proceed. Of course, Australia is a relatively small contributor to the problem, so whatever response we make in slowing the greenhouse effect will be minimal indeed. What we can do, though, is to act, as we have in so many other areas, as a voice for sanity in world forums, and we will certainly be applying our influence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you see yourself on the world stage?

—No, but there are others in this Government who are more than well qualified to strut the world stage, and have done so admirably and with success. I have no such ambition. However, we will use our voice in international forums to try to urge those countries of the world that can have a major effect to do so. At the last meeting of the Australian Environment Council this matter was discussed. We have agreement across Australia that the advisory committee to the Council will look at the problem and report back to us next year. I just add, in my answer to Senator Coulter, that I will provide him with a copy of that resolution so that he can see how far it went.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I have raised the matter with my counterpart, Mr Barry Jones, the Minister for Science and Small Business, who is co-ordinating research within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). We will attempt to upgrade the priority given by CSIRO to this research. That, inevitably, will mean getting successful outcomes in the Budget next year. Senator Walsh and Mr Keating being the sorts of people they are, I am sure I will have further to report at that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am surprised to hear the Minister imply that somehow or other the global atmosphere stops at the equator. I have noted that the International Council of Scientific Unions has said, among other things:

QUESTION.PARA: Many important economic and social decisions are being made today on long-term projects . . . based on the assumption that past climatic data, without modification, are a reliable guide to the future. This is no longer a good assumption.

In view of that statement, will the Minister answer my last two questions? Has the Government adopted a preventive or an adaptive attitude towards these predictions and, if preventive, how is the Government modifying its policy responses in the light of these predictions?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had answered at least the tenor of Senator Coulter's question. First off, I must take issue with Senator Coulter because I do not think that I suggested that anything ended at the equator. However, I did suggest that the primary causes of the greenhouse effect do emanate from the Northern Hemisphere and affect us all; there is no doubt about that. I am sure no one disputes that. Having said that, before announcing the Government's response to the greenhouse phenomenon, I think it would be appropriate to get some more research. I have outlined that we have a program of research with the New Zealand Government. When that is completed, we will outline the response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question by Senator Panizza on 14 December. I seek leave to have the question and answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMPENSATION CLAIMS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PANIZZA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Commissioner for Employees Compensation received 340 claims for compensation following the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia and that he allowed only 13 of these on the grounds of contraction of cancer? Is it further a fact that the Commonwealth, presumably on advice from the Attorney-General's Department, is appealing against all these decisions and that, in the first case to go before the Federal Court of Australia, the Commissioner's determination was upheld by a single judge but rejected by a Full Bench to which the Commonwealth decided the matter should go? Does the Minister not agree that the Commonwealth is behaving in a very contradictory way in that, having opened up the issue through a royal commission, it now appears to be doing everything it can to avoid the consequences of its actions?

INTERJECT.PARA: RESPONSE TO QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE-SENATOR PANIZZA COMPENSATION CLAIMS

The Government policy in radiation cases and on the recommendations of the McClelland Royal Commission as stated in the Senate on 17 September 1986 by the former Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, is that the Government does not seek to deny compensation where it is justified, but will make full use of the appeals process where it believes Commonwealth liability does not exist.

The Commonwealth Commissioner for Employees' Compensation has received 340 claims for compensation from employees and former employees of the Commonwealth in respect of the nuclear tests. As at 2 December 1987 he had allowed 13 on the basis that the claimant had a radiation-caused condition and 13 in respect of other causes. As at that date 49 cases were under investigation and 21 had been investigated but undetermined pending resolution of the appeal to which the Honourable Senator referred in his question (the Bird case).

The appeal to the Full Federal Court concerned the interpretation of section 30 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. The Commonwealth's earlier appeal to a single judge of the Federal Court had been dismissed.

Mr Bird claimed compensation is respect of carcinoma of the tongue which he attributed to peace-time service in the RAAF after the Hurricane nuclear test in 1952. He had serviced and cleaned aircraft at a time when they were contaminated.

The delegate of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation determined that, as the service had possibly caused the carcinoma, the reverse onus provision contained in section 30 applied to make the Commonwealth liable to pay compensation.

The Full Court found that material before the delegate would have enabled him to find that the minor exposure to ionizing radiation which Mr Bird suffered in the course of his employment was not a probable, but could have been a possible, cause of, or a contributing factor to, Mr Bird's disease.

The decision went on to affirm the Commonwealth's view that to attract the reverse-onus provisions of the Compensation Act in radiation cases, there had to be a probable (not merely possible) cause of a claimant's pathological condition.
On 11 December the High Court granted Mr Bird special leave to appeal the Full Federal Court decision, and the matter is likely to be heard early in 1988.

The Commonwealth has not appealed to the AAT all cases in which the Commissioner has found liability, but has done so only where it considered the finding to have been unjustified on the evidence available.
