DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Senator Stone, proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to take timely action to address:
(a) the results of its own past policy failures, and
(b) the need for action to protect Australia against the impending international economic consequences of the policy failures of the major world economic powers.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that I have placed before the Senate this afternoon asks the Senate to discuss the failure of the Government to take timely action-and I stress the word `timely'-to address two important topics: first, the results of the Government's own past policy failures; and, secondly, the need for action by the Government to protect Australia against the impending international economic consequences of the policy failures of the major world economic powers.

SPEECH.PARA: Within two days the Senate will adjourn for the Christmas-New Year recess. The House of Representatives adjourned almost a week ago. Sittings of both chambers will resume on 16 February next. In other words, for two months we shall run through a period during which the results of the Government's own past policy failures, and its inaction in addressing the results of those past policy failures, will continue to mount, and during this period the consequences of the policy failures by the major world economic powers for the state of the international economy will also continue to mount.

I know that this Government is a tired government; I know that it badly needs a rest. But this postponement of any action to correct the course on which we have now been set for some time is simply irresponsible. After all, this call for action from the Opposition is not new. I am sure that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will recall that on Budget night itself we sat side by side, in an atmosphere of relative amity-a relationship which we always have-and I said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio in discussion with him that, while the mini-Budget of 19 May last had moved the fiscal policy of this Government in the right direction although not far enough, the Budget itself, brought down some four months later, had totally failed to follow up that possible beginning. I said at that time on the ABC program that the result would be that we would find, as the months ahead of us then unfolded, that the pace of adjustment on which the Government had set its course in the Budget Papers would prove to be insufficient. I said that against the background of the then known level of our international debt, which was already very high-in the order of $A109,000m-and which the Budget Papers themselves had revealed to be growing apace by, on the Government's own estimates, something like $11 1/2 billion more in the current financial year. I also said at that time that we were, of course, heavily at risk from any adverse developments abroad. All of this was said on the evening of 15 September.

On 20 October we saw the Australian stock market crash and continue to plunge in the days thereafter to an extent far greater than any other major stock exchange in the world. A week or so after those events commenced, we saw the international foreign exchange market crash and, again, our own foreign exchange market crashed in the wake of it. I remind the Senate that at that time the Opposition also called for action from the Government. In this place on 26 October, a little less than a week later, I moved an urgency motion. It is instructive to refresh one's memory of the terms of that motion. I urged the Senate to express its concern that Australia's gross foreign debt, at around 40 per cent of gross national product, is now among the highest in the world; and that our level of business fixed investment, even prior to then recent events in the stock market and financial markets generally, was forecast in the Budget Papers to increase by only 4 per cent in real terms, or little more than in line with the forecast growth in GDP. We all know that those figures have now been sharply revised downwards. I also asked the Senate to note that the state of these fundamental indicators of economic ill health renders the Australian economy excessively vulnerable to any adverse change in world economic conditions. In addition, I asked it to note the serious risks for Australia which were involved in the matters I had raised. My motion called upon the Government to undertake urgent measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment which, as the Budget Papers themselves conceded, has to be made.

A few weeks later, on 17 November, in a speech I made in this place on the second reading of the Appropriation Bills, I reiterated those warnings-as indeed did many other Opposition senators in the course of that quite prolonged debate. I wish to quote a passage or two from the amendment that I moved to the second reading motion of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I moved:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill-
that is, the Appropriation Bill which had failed to make the appropriate adjustments in the budgetary position of this Government-
is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely-
again I stress the word `timely'-
adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;
(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt . . .

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally.

In response to those and many other such expressions of opinion from this side of the chamber in the course of the past two months or so, the Government and its senior economic spokesmen have ducked and weaved, always with the looming shadow of the New South Wales election in the background. Meanwhile, our international debt has steadily grown.

Let us be quite clear that Australia today is at risk for two reasons. The Government is quite prepared to speak at some length about one of them-namely, the failure on the part of some major economic powers in the world to amend their policies appropriately-but it is not prepared to draw conclusions about the risk that bears for Australia. The Government will never concede that any of our present troubles stem from its own past failures in policy action-or, rather, inaction. It is because of the failure of this Government to deal with our problems over the course of the past 4 1/2 years and, particularly, the past three years or so, that our overseas debt and the cost of servicing that debt have continued to mount.

A tabulation attached to the balance of payments figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows that our present servicing cost for non-official capital investment in this country-mainly borrowings from abroad-is now running at either just above or just under $700m a month, or $8 1/2 billion a year. So, because of our own failures we have become more vulnerable to any adverse turn of fortune. The matter of public importance before us this afternoon also draws attention to the Government's failure to insure against the international economic consequences for the Australian economy of the policy failures on the part of the major economic powers.

In the limited time available to me, I do not want to spend undue time speaking about international economic policy failures. They are plain to most members of this chamber. But let me just mention in passing one recent development which has got much less publicity in Australia than is warranted. I refer to the recently announced decision by Moodys Investor Services Inc. to downgrade the Eurobond ratings of Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela and-in many ways much more significantly, although there are connections between the two things-to place under review the possible downgrading of the ratings of 10 major United States banks including Bankers Trust Co., New York, Bank of America Corporation, Chase Manhattan Corporation and J. P. Morgan and Co. because of the extent of loans of those major money centre banks to Third World countries such as the three first named, whose capacity and continuing willingness to service such loans is increasingly in doubt.

These disturbing-I think they can be called only that-international debt developments are already casting a pall across the face of the international financial community. Notwithstanding Australia's critical foreign debt and precarious balance of payments position, and our consequent urgent need to reduce our risk exposure and protect our creditworthiness in the face of the deteriorating outlook for world trade and growth, Ministers are about to depart this national capital for two months rest and recreation on the basis of a statement from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance, last week, I think, indicating that there will be no fiscal policy action from this Government until after the New South Wales election or, to use their words, until the middle of May. I can only repeat that I regard that inaction on the Government's part as irresponsible.

The Government has, as we all know, been taking refuge in the line `It is not our fault'. Yet the fact is that world economic growth has been going on quite steadily for almost five years now, since late 1982, early 1983-almost precisely the time when this Government first came to office. Throughout the whole of 1987 our international terms of trade, which the Government made a great deal of play about last year because at that time they were deteriorating, have been improving-not worsening. Instead of taking advantage of this breathing space, as any prudent family would do to repair the family fortunes, this Hawke-Keating Government has simply squandered that opportunity. One month ago, in a characteristic grandstanding action, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to President Reagan, then leaked his letter to the local Press before, I suspect, the President had even read it-not that, I suspect, he took much trouble to read it-to urge the United States Government to take remedial action in its budgetary and other policy fields to address the major economic problems of that government-and there is no doubt that they are major economic problems-in the interests of the world.

This brazen advice was being given to a country which, whatever its faults of omission or commission may or may not have been over the past five to 10 years or so, has a debt amounting to 13 per cent of GDP by a country whose overseas debt today amounts to over 40 per cent of GDP. That advice was being given to a country whose balance of payments deficit was then put at around 3 1/2 per cent of GDP by a country whose balance of payments deficit was then put at around 4 per cent of GDP. It was to a country whose total public sector borrowing requirement, not just the deficit in the Federal Budget, was and still is a shade lower than that of Australia.

I remember someone saying to me at the time, when I made some slightly critical comment on the Prime Minister's action in this regard, `Why should not our Prime Minister write to Mr Reagan? Mrs Thatcher is recently reported to have written to him on the same lines'. I said, `Yes, but the difference is that Mrs Thatcher counts'. Is it any wonder that Australia no longer counts in those great countries of the world where we once did count, perhaps more than our intrinsic importance really merited? But at least we did count. Now we are merely the purveyors of windy advice from a government which, by having perpetually run away from the economic problems facing us, no longer possesses any credibility or standing in those quarters.

Meanwhile, only yesterday, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) issued the balance of payments figures for November. At first sight, the deficit of $767m on current account contained in that ABS release was summed up in the phrase `Not good, but no worse than expected'. On closer examination of the supporting data, however, more can be said. First, the trend estimate of imports in November rose once again for the seventh successive month. This is in an economy which, we are assured by the Treasurer and his supporting economic Ministers including, I believe, the Minister for Finance, is turning around and in which the Government is beginning to master our external problems, among other things. Seasonally adjusted for November, imports were up by 9 per cent and, seasonally adjusted, exports fell by 2 per cent in the month.

The apparently not worse than expected overall outcome was largely a product of a sharp fall in the net income deficit which reflects in particular an increase of no less than $156m-that is, almost 100 per cent-in investment income credits-for reasons which have yet to be explained. There is no sign in all this of the Treasurer's long promised J-curve, promised now for some 2 1/2 years since the Treasury first told him about it back in early 1985. More importantly, I remind the Minister for Finance of his remarks in answer to questions from this side of the chamber very shortly after the stock exchange developments began in October, when, among other things, he said that of two possible consequences which would cause the Government to take those matters seriously, one would be an outflow from Australia of private capital. The Minister might now begin to note that that has occurred. The November balance of payments figures show that in that month private capital outflow, including the balancing item, was $1,252m. I refer to table 4 of the ABS release. So in November, our central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, had not merely to finance our current account deficit of $767m, but also to cover the drain of private capital flowing out of the country.

To sum up, Australia is at risk because of the results of the Government's past policy failures and because, in particular, of the Government's failure to insure against the likely consequences for Australia, including particularly for the prices of our major export commodities, of the impending slow-down or worse abroad. I wish the Minister and his colleagues a happy Christmas. I do not think that he or, much more importantly, the Australian people can now look forward to a happy new bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone referred to timely action. In light of his usual conviction of infallibility, I expect that he knows precisely at what time action should be taken. That is a certainty obviously not shared by his Opposition leader, if not his Party leader. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, for example, was interviewed on AM on 26 October on the matter of the share market fall. In reference to mini-Budgets-that is his term by the way-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . exactly when that should come down is a matter of practicality, I think sooner rather than later.
But almost two months later, on 10 December, he was arguing that the stock market decline would-and I use his words:
. . . reduce confidence and therefore have an impact on the real economy--
I notice that he uses the term `real economy'. He continued:
We won't know that until three or four months have gone by next year . . .

So, although Senator Stone, with his usual certitude, believes that action should have been taken yesterday, his Opposition Leader believes that we will not really know the effects until three or four months into next year. But, more important than that customary or characteristic exhibition of disunity on the other side, Senator Stone referred to the alleged failures of this Government. I would just like to remind the Senate of some of the facts and of what those alleged failures are. For a start, when we came into office we were facing a prospective Budget deficit of $10 billion. I quote Senator Stone's own note, prepared for delivery to Mr Howard had he still been Treasurer after the 5 March 1983 election. Senator Stone wrote:
When the estimated cost in 1983-84 of the new policy proposals announced in the policy speech is added-
that is, Malcolm Fraser's policy speech-
the prospect is for a Budget deficit of almost $10 billion. Such a deficit would be equivalent to 5 1/2 per cent of projected GDP, the highest in Australian post-war history.

Senator Stone set out accurately enough the fiscal mess that this Government inherited. It has, it is true, taken us five years to clean up the mess that John Howard left behind. But, so far as the Commonwealth Budget is concerned, we have now, in 1987, produced a surplus-the first time since adequate accounts have been kept that that has happened, and possibly the first time ever. So that is our failure on cleaning up John Howard's mess-we have turned a $10 billion prospective deficit into a surplus.

Real unit labour costs have fallen by 10 per cent at the same time as the overall unemployment rate has fallen. There is no precedent in Australian economic history for that outcome. We have taken three percentage points off the consumer price index, in spite of the very significant boost it received from the devaluation of the Australian dollar and its effect on export prices. We must contrast those failures, as Senator Stone would call them, with the big trifecta that this Government inherited from John Howard-above 10 per cent unemployment, above 11 per cent inflation and a $10 billion Budget deficit, to which I have already referred.

Senator Stone referred repeatedly to the need for adjustment. But apart from reference to the Commonwealth Budget deficit-or Commonwealth fiscal policy; the deficit has already been eliminated; he wants further changes in fiscal policy and he believes that they should have been made yesterday-he actually stipulated nothing about the adjustments that were required. I suggest that more important than the Commonwealth fiscal policy or the Commonwealth Budget outcome-given that on present expectations it has now been put into surplus-are matters such as unit labour costs and productivity. This, of course, embraces work practices, which I know Senator Stone has spoken about at other times, but he did not mention them today.

I do not know whether he is still committed to the sort of policy which he has long advocated and which the Fraser-Howard Government actually experimented with in 1981-82; that is, of course, a deregulated labour market whereby collective bargaining was allowed out in the market-place to determine wage outcomes. That was the policy that was followed for 18 months after the Fraser-Howard Government abdicated responsibility for wages policy in May of 1981. That little experiment was undertaken, and we know what the outcome was. The outcome in 1981-and I am using calendar years-was a wages explosion of 13 per cent. The outcome in 1982 was an even bigger wages explosion of 14 per cent. So although Senator Stone did not mention it, in regard to the alleged failures of this Government we can stack up our performance-a 10 per cent real decline in unit labour costs over the period that we have been in government-against the wages explosions of 1981 and 1982 which happened immediately before.

My next point is not a critical one, but I think it is worth making, given Senator Stone's background. Speaking of his urgency motion moved last month, I believe he referred to Australia's gross foreign debt as being around 40 per cent of gross domestic product. I think that figure is correct. But what makes it surprising, coming from a former Treasury Secretary, is the emphasis on gross foreign debt. I am far from sanguine-and I have made this point many times publicly-about Australia's net foreign debt, but gross foreign debt does not necessarily matter at all. It is the net foreign debt that matters. If Australians owe $100 billion to somebody overseas in loans and Australians have lent to people overseas $100 billion-overlooking such minor complications as possible divergences in respect of interest rates and so on-it does not matter at all. It is no problem at all, because under those circumstances the net foreign debt is zero. So I am surprised that Senator Stone, first at that time and again, apparently uncritically, now, focuses his attention on the gross foreign debt. The only possible explanation for that that I can think of is that, for a political propagandist-as distinct from a professional Treasury officer, which he once was-quoting the gross foreign debt makes better political propaganda.

Senator Stone is acquiring a reputation in some quarters as the chameleon senator. In case some people do not know what a chameleon is, it is a lizard that takes on the colours of its background. He is acquiring that reputation for such things as initially opposing the floating of the Australian dollar and later approving of it; and for saying in 1981, as he did when he spoke at the Agricultural Outlook Conference:
The current account deficit in 1980-81 is therefore likely to be significantly larger than earlier suggested. This fortunate development will, of course, work to supplement domestic savings . . .

An increase in the current account deficit was seen by Senator Stone in 1980-81 as being a fortunate development. An admittedly large but declining current account deficit is seen by him as catastrophic in 1987. Two days ago, I believe, in the debate on the Government's petroleum resource rent tax legislation, Senator Stone voted against the second reading motion. But in 1981, when appearing as a witness before the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, he made an interesting reply to a question by Senator Tate. Those who are interested can find this quotation on page 1070 of the transcript of evidence. He said:
But Senator Tate is seeking to suggest, by picking up the term `economic rent' on page 57 of our submission-
that is, the official Treasury submission-

that over and above that there may be an area for exploitation, if that is the right word, by other forms of taxation, including in particular resources rent taxes. I suppose that is what he had in mind. The answer to that is yes . . .
Senator Tate said:
I am delighted with the answer, of course, but it seems not to be unexpected.
To this Senator Stone said:
I am simply answering a question of fact.

He spoke then as Treasury Secretary, and he took on the background colour of Treasury. But as a National Party senator from Queensland, when there is legislation before the Senate, he takes on the colour of the Queensland branch of the National Party.

Then, of course, we had the extraordinary performance two weeks ago when Senator Stone delivered a eulogy to none other than the former Country Party Leader, Sir Earle Page, who was, more than any other Australian in the 1920s, responsible for running up, on behalf of various governments-governments; not the private sector-a foreign debt about three times as large as the net foreign debt which Australians, both government and private, owe today. And for what purpose? Investment, Senator Stone? It was for investment in crazy land settlement schemes and irrigation schemes, which failed because Sir Earle Page had an obsession about redistributing the population of the Empire, as he called it, in order to exploit its unlimited resources. As I observed the other day, he was able, unfettered of course by the remotest understanding of economic principles or concepts, to pursue those sorts of obsessions without any intellectual problems to himself. But, of course, they left a massive economic problem for the rest of Australia which, again as I mentioned the other day, a number of respected economic commentators would suggest took us two decades to overcome.

Senator Stone, with his normal absolute conviction of infallibility, not only believes that he knows the precise time at which action should be taken; he also believes that he knows what sort of action should be taken. His record as a forecaster does not, unfortunately, live up to his conviction of infallibility. Indeed, on 19 August 1986, when commenting upon and criticising the 1986 Budget, he said:
I personally doubt whether any real growth in non-farm product will occur in 1986-87. Certainly, any forecast for it greater than, say, 1 per cent should excite disbelief.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that the Budget you had to repair with the mini-Budget in May this year?
—It is from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 August 1986. Repair the 1986 Budget, Senator Stone?
—The mini-Budget this year was simply repairing the omissions of last year.
—No, we have brought in economic statements in May for most of the years we have been in government. Senator Stone also said that there would be:

SPEECH.PARA: a balance of payments current account deficit higher in money terms than in 1985-86, and probably no lower even as a percentage of GDP.

But to take up Senator Stone's interjection-and his logic is failing as well as everything else-let us assume that the May statement should be regarded as a repair exercise. What he was making a forecast about was employment growth, and obviously any change to economic policy announced at the end of May is not going to have any effect on employment growth for the financial year, particularly on a year on year basis; so, as I said, his logic is failing as well as his prophecy. On 27 August Senator Stone said:
Moreover, detailed examination now shows the truly awful Budget facing us in 1987-88, with a deficit which even on a conservative basis looks like being $8 billion or more.

It is true that the Government, principally on the outlay side and to a lesser extent on the revenue side, announced policy changes in May which, combined, had the effect of bringing the Budget deficit down by $4 billion, so take that off. Senator Stone's forecast about the Budget deficit in prospect for 1987-88 was exaggerated by a bit more than 100 per cent, because what we finally brought in was a balanced Budget when he said the conservative estimate was $8 billion, from which we subsequently took $4 billion. He also said that the Budget description for unemployment of `some increase' was `patently dishonest', `is going to increase'-and so on and so forth.

I do not know whether all of this dogmatic but inaccurate forecasting should be attributed to the fact that Senator Stone no longer has the resources of the Treasury behind him, or whether it should again be attributed to the chameleon factor-that is, that when he was Secretary to the Treasury, as well as having the resources he did not have any particular vested interest in interpreting information that was available in a way that, let us say, for other reasons was slanted. I will not speculate on that any more, but I let the facts speak for themselves.

On a minor point, Senator Stone said that after Friday-it is not his word, but it is the sense of what he was saying-there would be a hibernation period of two months. Well, hibernation periods of much more than two months are not unknown on the Opposition side of politics. I know that, and perhaps all of the Opposition members are going to hibernate for the next two months. But I can assure Senator Stone that although I am going to take a holiday, for somewhat less than half of two months, and various other people will as well, we will not be hibernating for two months.

Senator Stone obviously not only believes that his predictions and prophecies are infallible, and that his judgment about the timing of events or policy changes is immaculate, but also believes that major economic policy changes should be put together in a matter of a few days or weeks. I would have thought that the experience of the last election campaign would have driven home, even to the Opposition, the lesson that putting things together on the run, doing cut and paste jobs, carries hazards with it, such as the hazard that major mistakes will be made, not just in failing to take account of all the possible variables and ramifications that are associated with a policy change, but even in arithmetic-in other words, the sort of horrendous mistake, and politically catastrophic mistake, even, in arithmetic, that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made in the run-up to the last election, when he tried to put an alternative Budget together on the run, in a cut and paste way in about one or two weeks.

The Government, of course, completely rejects the charges that it does not take timely action, and I think it has pretty convincingly demonstrated that the alleged failures of this Government are actually achievements, and, in particular, spectacular achievements when compared with the failure of the previous Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate today, submitted by Senator Stone, is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to take timely action to address
(a) the results of its own past policy failures, and
(b) the need for action to protect Australia against the impending international economic consequences of the policy failures of the major world economic powers.

I would have to say that this is probably one of the most extraordinary matters for discussion that we have had before this chamber, at least in the time that I have been a senator. I think it is extraordinary in its arrogant assumption that only Senator Stone, presumably, has the answers to the world's economic problems. It is ironic too, and extraordinary in that irony, that the Government's policies have been put into legislation, supported in the main over the years by Senator Stone's own political party--

TALK.START.PARA: —By the Australian Democrats.

—No. If the honourable senator looks at the voting figures on Government legislation in the last few Budget sessions-the Budget session of 1986, the May economic statement of 1987 and the Budget session of 1987-he will find that on legislative matters he and his colleagues have voted in divisions on Government legislation more often than the Democrats have. That is why the Treasurer has already announced that there will be a mini-Budget in May of next year. It has not taken the Government very long to work out that, as long as the word `Budget' is attached to a piece of legislation, the Opposition parties will lie down, roll over and have their tummies tickled, and pass absolutely everything that the Government dishes up to them. If there is a problem with the policies of this Government, then it is shared equally with the Opposition parties, whose support has put many of those policies into place.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an astonishing matter to be discussing, given the views of economists of considerably greater international note than Senator Stone-for example, Dr Henry Kaufman, Managing Director of New York's Salomon Brothers Inc. I refer the Senate to a recent article in the financial pages of the Australian headed `US, world economies face crisis in the new year', which quotes this economist as making the point that renewed international discord between the United States and its trading partners, tightening monetary policy world-wide, rising interest rates and inflation and a plummeting greenback are the issues that will preoccupy the United States and world economies next year. He went on to say:

The rebound in economic activity will strain resources, heighten inflation, reintroduce discord internationally, induce much higher interest rates and eventually pose serious risks to the economic expansion.

He said that it was unlikely that the major industrial nations would be able to fashion policies with enough flexibility to reduce structural world trade imbalances. Yet, apparently, of all the countries in the world, Australia is supposed to be able to do something about this-something that no other country is able to do. If the major industrial nations will not be able to protect themselves, how can Australia be expected to do so, given its poorly developed industrial and manufacturing sector, a poor development that has been engendered by decades of Liberal-National Party protectionism and reliance on agricultural and mineral resources for export income?

This is not to say that there are not problems, nor is it to deny that these stem from policy decisions made by this and previous governments. The results of past policy failures-they certainly have been policy failures-include unemployment, which is now a way of life for some 600,000 Australians, many of them young, because the Australian Labor Party and the coalition partners have abandoned anything resembling full employment as an economic objective. The results of past policy failures include the number of Australians living in poverty, a number that has increased from an estimated 780,000 in 1973 to something like 2.2 million in 1985-86. By contrast, at least until the stock market crashed in October, the number of millionaires in this country had risen from 30,000 to nearly 50,000 in a little over 12 months. Government policy has reduced access by middle and lower income families to health care, education opportunities, child care and public housing, and Australian consumers, house buyers, businesses and farmers have consistently faced some of the highest interest rates of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

We have more consumers living on so-called credit that they cannot afford. It was only during Question Time today that it was confirmed that we have experienced a dramatic increase in the number of bankruptcies, 70 per cent of which are directly related to consumer debt, which is increasing at about three times the rate of inflation. Farmers are facing punitive interest rates and falling commodity prices, which leave them with little choice except to sell out, often to international companies and corporations which are eager to buy family farms at bargain basement prices.

It is difficult to see how Senator Stone can be so critical of this Government when both the Hawke Government and the coalition promote the same economic policies, and the difference is only one of degree. The Hawke Government has reduced wages, cut social security benefits, introduced tertiary education fees, reduced the capacity of the health system to deliver essential health services and given the biggest tax cuts to the highest income earners. As I said a moment ago, all this has been done with the help of the coalition, as the voting figures for the last three sessions clearly indicate. The coalition itself, given half the chance, would cut the living standards of average Australian working people and their families and social security beneficiaries more savagely, while presumably giving even bigger tax cuts to the highest income earners. Anybody who does not believe that that is the case need only look at the Australian of 28 November this year, in which an article by Robert Hadler headed `Howard razor cuts aid to jobless, ill' indicated that the Federal Opposition planned, if given the chance, to cut up to $7 billion from assistance programs to the unemployed, the sick and sole supporting parents as part of its radical Budget agenda for the 1990s.

Since World War II, successive Labor and Liberal governments have pursued economic policies that have cut our manufacturing capacity in half and shifted it to South East Asia, where the wage rate is one tenth as high. Successive protectionist policies pursued by the National and Liberal parties in government have created a manufacturing industry which can survive only with billions of dollars worth of subsidies. The business community, which benefits most from these subsidies, continues to press for reductions in government expenditure on education, health care and social security. The corporate welfare mentality is alive and well in this country, and it is screaming for cuts in every area except its own.

Over the last 20 years, Labor and Liberal governments have allowed us to become dependent on mineral and agricultural exports and massive flows of foreign capital. Now, however, mineral and agricultural export prices have dropped, we have a massive trade deficit and a huge national debt and we have become more dependent on foreign borrowing and investment. At the same time, as I said, they have engendered a welfare mentality in our manufacturing sector, making it quite ill-prepared to fill the gap with export or import replacement goods. Instead, the New Right solution to this problem has been implemented by the Hawke Government. Financial deregulation, the admission of foreign banks, the tying of the hands of the Foreign Investment Review Board, cuts in wages, cuts in social welfare and privatisation have all been lifted out of the policy manifesto of the New Right, supported by the National and Liberal parties and implemented by the so-called Labor Government. The Labor Government is doing all of that, and the result is more poverty and cuts in the living standards of ordinary working Australians as our foreign debt and our dependence on foreign borrowing or foreign investment continue to grow.

It is amazing that those who in the past have bayed for financial deregulation and the admission of foreign banks to lock us into the international financial system are now suggesting that we need to respond independently, somehow, to the policy failures of the major world economic powers. Well, we cannot, for we are no longer, if we ever were, independent. We are, unfortunately, whether we like it or not, inextricably linked with the fortunes, good or bad, of our trading partners, and this has come about because of actions by all Australian governments, past and present, including those advised by Senator Stone when he was head of the Treasury.

Financial deregulation and the admission of foreign banks have not benefited the average Australian consumer, or the Australian economy, but they have given the Australian private sector access to more overseas funds. These foreign borrowings are now the major reason the Government advances for reducing the living standards of the average Australian through expenditure cuts and privatisation. Most ordinary Australians have not borrowed overseas, yet they are paying the price for the problems caused by those who have, and who continue to do so. Some 60 per cent of our foreign debt is the result of private sector borrowing. The companies that borrow use the funds to buy shares in other companies and claim the interest costs as a tax deduction. Whenever I get up in this place and call for action on things such as negative gearing on foreign financed takeover bids and transfer pricing on off-shore investments by the big life and superannuation funds which are able to continue their tax free status even when they do that, there are howls of outrage from those who support the corporate welfare sector while at the same time denigrating and decrying those who are forced into the social welfare sector because of the very actions of the corporate sector.

The capacity for companies to borrow overseas and then negatively gear certainly increased the price of shares during the boom but added nothing to our ability to export more or to import less. In essence many of the taxation benefits that are granted to the corporate sector are non-productive. They do not in any way at all benefit the economy as a whole by increasing our export potential or our import replacement areas. Where companies which are currently making profits and paying tax are taken over the foreign borrowers can use their interest payments to wipe out their tax liabilities and, in doing so, reduce the amount in Consolidated Revenue that the Government has to spend on areas of greatest need.

Therefore, the Australian taxpayer is, and has been, for far too long, subsidising the activities of speculative takeover merchants who are responsible for our growing debt while the Government uses the debt as the excuse for reducing the living standards of those Australians who have not borrowed overseas. The Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party will take no action to stop this process, thereby denying something in the vicinity of $2 billion annually to tax revenue. To that extent those parties are all culpable through the adherence to the selfish and greedy policies of the New Right.

The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this matter of public importance. Senator Stone has not made out any case for how any government in this country at the moment can protect Australia against the policy failures of other nations, unless of course he is suggesting that we build a very big wall around Australia, dig a huge moat, fill it up with sharp pointed spikes, not let anybody in or out and isolate ourselves totally from the rest of the world while trying to go it alone. I presume that even Senator Stone is not silly enough to suggest something of that sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The consideration of the matter of public importance is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the tabling statement which Senator Bolkus, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, incorporated in Hansard yesterday. I refer here to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee report entitled Report on the Operation and Administration of the Freedom of Information Legislation. The Freedom of Information (FOI) Act 1982 was first referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, as it was then called, for review of its operations and administration in November 1985. That reference was transferred to the newly named and, I suppose I should also say, newly composed Committee on 22 September this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be understood by the Senate that the task given to the Committee proved to be an enormous one, particularly enormous, if I may say so, to those new members of the Committee such as me who, from September this year, have had to attempt to catch up with all the work done by their predecessors in the preceding 18 months or so. But in any event, I take this opportunity of congratulating the staff of the Committee, particularly the Secretary, Miss Susan Gibb, on the herculean task which it has done in assisting the Committee to put together the report.

Notwithstanding the other pressures upon the Committee in the course of what has been, I think, a very rugged session of the Senate, it has produced a report containing no fewer than 126 separate recommendations for amending or otherwise commenting on the present FOI Act. In regard to all but 15 of those recommendations, from which I personally dissented, the Committee members were unanimous.

I wish to say something about those aspects of the report in respect of which, regrettably, I found it necessary to separate myself from the views of my colleagues on the Committee-including, I should say, those two of my colleagues, Senator Robert Hill and Senator Richard Alston, whose company I have the privilege to share on this side of the Senate chamber. Before I do so I should like to say something about the whole question of freedom of information legislation and my own attitude to it.

First of all, I would like to make it clear that I have always been a supporter of the principle of freedom of information legislation, insofar as that principle can render government more open without, at the same time, threatening the proper workings of the Westminster system of government under which, within our constitutional procedures, we live and work in this place. However, I have never favoured an FOI process which would result in some kind of public or, if you like, Press, voyeurism into the inner workings of government. Incidentally, I have been interested to note that, as experience has grown of the actual operations in practice of both the Commonwealth Freedom of Information Act and its counterpart in Victoria, Labor governments in both places have come to much the same conclusion.

Nor have I ever favoured a process whereby information in the possession of governments-the retrieval of which and the decision making provisions for the release of which can be very costly-should be treated as some kind of free good to be available without cost, or largely without cost, to anybody who turns up and simply holds our his or her hand to ask for it.

It follows that while it is always recognised that the public interest in the accessibility of information should mean that less than full cost should be charged for its recovery-in other words, because of the external benefits which, it can at least be argued, can derive from the provision of that information-I have nevertheless always favoured a policy of charging which much more nearly equates to full cost recovery than was the case when the 1981 Act was originally brought into being under the Fraser Government and when that situation continued to obtain even under the 1982 Act. I may say in passing that my dissents from the recommendations such as No. 111, No. 112 and paragraph (b) of recommendation No. 58 derive from that position.

Again, it appears to me basic that wherever any third party had been implicated in the production of information now reposing in Government files and, therefore, now subject to request for access by an applicant it should be mandatory that, in the decision making process leading to decisions on that application, that third party have a right both to be consulted and, if desired, to intervene in any subsequent review process, including before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which might be invoked by an initially unsuccessful applicant. That is the view which underlies two of my dissenting comments on this report.

To me, one of the more encouraging aspects of the development of the Commonwealth freedom of information processes has been the manner in which, on the whole, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has brought to bear a generally common-sense attitude towards the appeals which have been brought before it under the Act. In the course of doing so, members of the Tribunal have been required, in the normal course of their duties, to interpret a number of provisions of the Act dealing with matters such as those in section 24 (1) (b) of the Act. The motives of certain applicants-I should say fortunately very few applicants-have to be taken into account by the Tribunal when interpreting that section of the Act. There is also the interpretation by decision-makers of the words `and would not, by reasons of the deletions, be misleading', appearing in section 22 (1) (b) of the Act, and so on. Given that course of quasi-judicial interpretation, I have not felt it appropriate in this Committee to seek to reverse the views arrived at by the Tribunal on those interpretations and, therefore, I have not been able to agree with my colleagues' recommendations to do so in several cases of that kind.

I could say more but I am aware that we are under constraints of time. More importantly, to go on addressing those limited areas of the report from which I have dissented would, I fear, have the effect of misrepresenting my position of general support, not only for the Act in its now considerably amended form but also for the general body of the report which the Committee has brought before this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a new member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as was Senator Stone, having been elected in July. I was faced with the rather daunting task of coming into a very significant inquiry--
—Awesome.

—It was awesome, yes. I came into this very significant inquiry in its final stages and I felt that, if my name was to be attached to a report, a considerable amount of work had to be done in order for me to feel that that was possible. I want to put on the record my appreciation of the staff of that Committee, particularly Susan Gibb, its Secretary, and the other members of the Committee for the for- bearance in this exercise they showed both tonew members and, continuing members of that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The report encompasses the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee and I was eventually happy to have my name attached to it. The Australian Democrats have always placed a very high priority on freedom of information (FOI) legislation and it was particularly pleasing that the Committee was able to conclude unanimously that the Freedom of Information Act has been of considerable benefit to the community and that it has attracted more support than opposition. This is not to say that the Freedom of Information Act is free of imperfections, nor that the notion of freedom of information receives universal support. Unfortunately, resistance to the availability of information and the placing of obstacles in the path of those who seek access are still problems.

One important aspect of access, of course, is cost and the 1986 amendments to the Act significantly reduced the possibility of some people being able to pursue their rights under the Act. In some cases, the impact of these increased costs would have been prohibitive. It is noteworthy to see that the 1986-87 annual report on the Freedom of Information Act shows that freedom of information requests decreased by 18 per cent during that year. While the report surmises that a significant part of this decrease seems attributable to a stricter definition of what constitutes an FOI request for reporting purposes, I am not so sure. It is regrettable that the report did not make any real attempt to assess the impact of the increased charges.

Given that charges are central to the workability of freedom of information of legislation, I take this opportunity to stress my view that charges will deter people from using the Act and thus defeat the whole purpose of the legislation. I did join with the rest of the Committee in accepting some charges-importantly with an upper limit-but this is not my preferred position. Ideally, no charges should be imposed on applications for, and provision of access to, documents under the Freedom of Information Act. Nevertheless, it is pleasing that the Committee has recommended a range of reductions in the quite excessive charges imposed by the 1986 amendments and I trust that these recommendations will be acted upon as quickly as possible.

In the time available to us here, it is not possible to refer to all of the 126 recommendations made by the Committee, but I would like to refer to some of the more significant ones. As the Chairman has noted in his tabling speech, the Committee tried to identify provisions of the Act which lend themselves to abuse by unduly secretive bureaucrats. Secretiveness being an occupational habit for some bureaucrats, I hope that the guidance we have given in our conclusions and recommendations will be followed to offset that inclination.

Another significant matter relates to access by non-citizens. Some people take the view that there should be restrictions on the rights of non-citizens, or at least on people who have not been granted permanent residence. Given that non-citizens almost invariably have some sort of documentation on them held by government department, the Committee, with the exception of Senator Stone, has quite rightly recommended that the right to seek correction of records under section 48 should be open to all persons in Australia, regardless of their citizenship or residential status. The only exception to this approach is that the restrictions on charges to which I referred earlier should not apply to illegal entrants and illegal residents in Australia.

The range of recommendations contained in the report covers other significant matters, including a proposed amendment to ensure that an applicant's motives are not taken into account for the purpose of the section 24 work load test and amendments to the system of conclusive certificates designed to strengthen the principle of accountability of Ministers to the Parliament. I particularly welcome proposed amendments aimed at ensuring better protection of privacy.

Overall, the recommendations contained in this report reflect the Committee's commitment to the concept of freedom of information. While I have some reservations about the continued existence of charges and an Administrative Appeals Tribunal fee, I believe that, if followed, the recommendations contained in this report and resulting from such a wide-ranging review will do much to protect the principle of freedom of information in this country. The object of this report-as it was in the 1979 report-should be our benchmark on this issue. The object is:
to ensure that a maximum amount of information is made publicly available, and that the barest minimum of restriction is placed on the public disclosure of such information.

It cannot be reiterated too often how important workable freedom of information legislation is to the health of a democracy. I stress `workable' because this Government's propensity to put the reduction of operating costs above access for Australian citizens is to be regretted. In saying that, I do not doubt that the Opposition parties would be behaving in the same way if they were in government. After all, they supported the Government's increase in charges in 1986.

Any government or opposition in this country, and the bureaucracies which administer government policy, should be mature enough to accommodate, and indeed welcome, freedom of information legislation that is more than a token gesture. Freedom of information legislation should be easily understood by everyone, the rights arising under it should be widely promulgated, access to information should be easy and cheap and restrictions should be at a minimum. I think we have some way to go before achieving this objective, but I believe this report will aid that process. On that basis I urge all honourable senators to support its recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also welcome the opportunity to speak to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It is a very significant report because it comes some years after the Freedom of Information Act came into operation and after a sufficient time has elapsed to enable a mature judgment to be made on its efficacy. I think all members of the Committee ultimately took the view that it has worked very well; that it is in need of some tidying up but, overall, it meets the objectives for which it was established. There is one popular misconception in the community; that is that the Freedom of Information Act is there largely to enable interested citizens, politicians, journalists and others to find their way into the inner workings of government. The reality is that more than 80 per cent of the users of this Act are those who are simply seeking access to personal records. I regard it as a very unsatisfactory arrangement that these matters should come within the purview of FOI at all. I think it would be much more satisfactory if the Australian Public Service were to enable its own employees, for example, to have access to records and if that provision were not a charge on FOI legislation. My recollection is that, as a result of the 86 amendments, the cost of maintaining this Act has fallen from about $18m to $8m. That is a very significant reduction. It comes about because of the need, I think, to try to contain the cost burden. But I certainly would not want to see a situation develop where ordinary citizens who are wanting to hold government to promises of openness are deterred.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not take the view, as the Australian Democrats do, that there should be free access to all aspects of the Act. I think in one very important recommendation we have made it clear that we take the view that persons who are not lawfully in Australia are to be made to bear the full cost burden of applications in relation to their own personal records. I think that is very significant. I have taken a more robust view than some of my colleagues about access to personal records. I believe that most persons seeking personal records are able to bear a modest cost. I would have thought about $10 to $15 is not unreasonable.

One recommendation in this report is that ordinary application fees be reduced from $30 to $15. I think that is a welcome measure if it does induce more people to make constructive use of the Act. I think it is fair to say that there is not much evidence of abuse, although one is always concerned at reports of many hundreds of hours of Public Service and court time being taken up by relatively abstruse applications and matters that are supposedly to further research but which really reflect the idiosyncratic interests of simply one citizen in the community. I would like to think that in some way restraints can be placed on those sorts of applications. One recommendation that goes some way towards that is a requirement that if the respondent-that is usually a government agency-makes an application in the first instance to have a declaration that there is no merit in the applicant's case, and that application is upheld, then a tribunal will not preclude an applicant from proceeding to a full hearing, but it will put the applicant at risk of costs. In other words, for the first time an applicant can be made to bear the costs of losing, which is the usual rule-the loser pays-but it does not apply in this jurisdiction. I did have some qualms about that, but I think the safeguards are sufficient, hopefully, to deter those who might otherwise make frivolous and vexatious applications. There is also provision for security of costs to be lodged in an instance such as that. I think that is also a worthwhile measure.

It can be said that, in many ways, the report deals with a number of tidying up arrangements which I think will improve the quality of the Act. I very much welcome my colleague Senator Stone, who endorses the principle of the Act. All right thinking citizens would recognise that this type of legislation has made a qualitative improvement in the performance of government and, hopefully, will serve as an incentive for all those concerned in government processes to ensure that there is not an unnecessary withholding of information, that public debate can proceed on an informed basis subject to a whole range of necessary safeguards but, nonetheless, give meaning to the concept of open government.

It is in this context that I think it is highly regrettable that only one State has introduced freedom of information legislation-that is Victoria. What do we find there? The position is very instructive when considering the Federal legislation. The Victorian Government had, as its model, the Commonwealth legislation. It deliberately chose to diverge from it on the basis of this very Committee's earlier report on the early operation of the Freedom of Information Act. In many respects the Victorian Government took an enlightened view of the way in which this type of legislation should serve ordinary citizens. For example, I recall that members of parliament have free access to FOI. That has led to my colleague Mark Birrell in particular making quite a number of very useful and constructive applications, much to the chagrin of the Premier, to such an extent that the Premier is now intent on closing down freedom of information in Victoria. It is utterly regrettable. I note in today's Press that it has led one member of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)-incidentally, he is not standing for re-election and I suppose he therefore feels safe-to vote against certain regulations that the Premier has wanted to introduce to emasculate the Act in certain respects. These regulations included putting sensitive government agencies, including the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Police Complaints Authority and the Solicitor-General, beyond the reach of freedom of information. Those familiar with the Nunawading scandal in Victoria a year or two back will recognise why the Premier no longer wants the public to have access to the workings of those particular organs of government. Here we have one courageous member of the Labor Party in Victoria who is prepared to say, `Enough is enough'. He has signalled that the Commonwealth legislation is the desirable model. He stated:
I was one of the people who was very keen on the idea of Freedom of Information.
To walk away from it now would not be a good idea.
The FOI Act was party policy-all I am doing is voting for party policy. . .

It is a great tragedy that the Premier of Victoria has not taken the same view. What we find in Victoria is that the Premier has waged an incessant campaign to stop Mr Birrell from getting access to absolutely innocuous documents. What we know about a series of documents that have been before the courts and tribunals over the last two years is that they relate to two-year-old public opinion surveys of the Victorian Government's performance. One would have thought-especially if we have master strategists such as Senator Richardson in the chamber-that we would not learn much from looking at two-year-old opinion polls. Our opponents are not going to learn very much either. Yet the Premier has shown this manic determination to withhold these documents through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal up to the Full Court, wisely choosing not to appeal from the Full Court of the Supreme Court to the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Unsworth has not got an Act at all.

—Mr Unsworth is having great trouble in getting his act together at the moment. I am sure the last thing Mr Unsworth would want is to have anything like this type of legislation around his neck. The Premier of Victoria chose not to follow the proper course, which was to appeal to the High Court; instead he chose to introduce scandalous regulations known as the Public Service Unauthorised Disclosure Regulations. Do honourable senators know what these regulations did? They allowed the Premier to declare any document a Cabinet document and therefore exempt from disclosure. I am reminded of the words of Humpty Dumpty, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: When I use a word it means just what I choose it to mean-neither more nor less.

That is what the Premier of Victoria has done. That is what he thinks of freedom of information. I think it is very desirable that we recognise the different position adopted. The Federal Government, apart from Senator Walsh, has not shown anything like that same determination to rip the guts out of this Act and I think that in many ways the Commonwealth legislation is setting an example that ought to be followed. It has broadly bipartisan support. It has served the people of Australia very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too bad you couldn't convince Senator Stone.

—Senator Stone exercised a very proper right in dissenting on a number of issues. I do not think they went to the heart of the Act or the report. He has acknowledged the principle and I think that is the position of all members of that Committee.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading debate on the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987 I drew attention, on behalf of the Opposition, to a matter which concerns us about a very small group of employees at the Williamstown Dockyard for whom we believe proper provision has not yet been made. We are concerned about a small group of people employed under the Public Service Act who either will be offered a job by the new employer and choose not to accept it and will therefore not be eligible for redundancy payments or will accept a job at the dockyard and perhaps will be very unhappy there or will be used and then their services dispensed with by the new employer within a very short time.

SPEECH.PARA: Neither of these groups is entitled to redundancy payments and we are not suggesting that they should be. However, we believe that, in the light of the fact that they are presently permanent public servants with all the rights and benefits that that conveys and that, through no fault or choice of their own, they are ceasing to be permanent public servants, at the very least the Government should make some extra provision for them in the event of their leaving the Public Service and either retiring or working for a new employer. Therefore, we believe that the Government should give an undertaking as to their rights to apply, without any restriction, in the 12 months following the transition period referred to in the legislation, for any Public Service positions for which they might otherwise be eligible.

Rather than our moving an amendment today, we ask the Government to give an undertaking that employees employed under the Public Service Act who resign, rather than take up employment with the new employer, or who take up employment with the purchaser of the dockyard will be able to apply for Public Service positions without loss of Public Service status for a period of 12 months from the end of the transition period. A few positions are available to public servants which are not available to people outside it. Restrictions are placed on some job applicants who are still in the Public Service and, by their enforced removal from the Public Service, there will be this small group of positions for which they will not be eligible to apply.

We believe that the Government should, in all fairness, make provision for them to apply for those positions even though they will not legally be public servants during that 12-month period. I hope that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) is now in a position to give that undertaking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be able to give some additional information as background material. Senator Newman's query relates to public servants, particularly engineers and technical staff, who have made the Public Service a career but who find themselves working for a private employer. I think the honourable senator is really asking whether there is some way in which these people could return to the Public Service at a later date. She suggested a 12-month period in which they could apply for vacancies advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman identified one particular group of people, those with specialised knowledge who might be taken over by the purchaser but later dismissed because there is no long term need for their services. In this respect there would be no problem in making specialist personnel available to the purchaser for limited periods without their being employed by that person. These people would remain Commonwealth employees. There seems no cause for concern here. The Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC), in conjunction with the Victorian Government, is developing a retraining program for staff taken over and this demonstrates long term career prospects.

With regard to the other people covered in Senator Newman's query, the following points are relevant: a program has been set up by the Department of Defence at Williamstown Dockyard whereby those officers who wish to redeploy elsewhere in the Department are assisted in their endeavours. Some 30 officers have registered for this scheme and four have been redeployed. This is a reflection of the difficulty in present circumstances of redeploying people.

AMEC will take control of the dockyard in early February 1988 and the transition period will run for three months from that date. This transition period is designed to help individuals to sort out their relationships with the new owner and vice versa. The employees to whom Senator Newman referred are primarily in professional engineering and technical classifications. Vacant positions in the Public Service in these classifications are not normally restricted to individuals already employed in the Public Service. Applications are normally accepted from all interested individuals whether or not they are public servants. Nevertheless, Senator Newman's point has been discussed with the Public Service Commission. I am happy to say that it has been agreed that the public servants who accept offers of employment at the dockyard with AMEC will have their rights in the Public Service reinstated for three years. This is on the basis that they will have to apply for vacancies and compete on merit in the usual way. In other words, with regard to vacancies, they will be in a similar situation to continuing public servants. However, no basis is seen for extending such rights to people who decline a suitable offer of employment and are deemed to have resigned or to have accepted the redundancy package. There is no reason to give such people special rights over and above anyone else. This would be against the spirit of the legislation and the agreed package of entitlements. I emphasise that the legislation reflects an agreement between the relevant staff associations and the Commonwealth agencies concerned. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) but I feel that he has omitted one tiny but important group of people. I welcome the fact that the people who go to the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) will continue to have entitlements over that three-year period. However, I see no reason for distinguishing between extending those rights to those people and giving the same rights to the people who choose not to go to AMEC, even though the offer is as good as or better than what they are presently receiving. Those people are being forced out of the Public Service. They are permanent public servants and they should at least have the same right to go back into the Public Service if they so choose. They are not leaving the Public Service of their own volition. Therefore, the Minister's undertaking is not satisfactory to the Opposition and I would ask that the Government look at this matter further before the Bill is proceeded with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to explore the impact of refusal. As I mentioned in my earlier comments, there are four options open to employees. One is to refuse an offer of similar conditions. Let us examine the implications of having made such a decision. For instance, a similar offer might include a position in Western Australia. I understand that the definition of `a similar offer' that is embraced by the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) includes offers of relocation to AMEC positions in Western Australia.
—What is wrong with Western Australia?

—There is nothing wrong with Western Australia, but if one has to relocate one's family there may be quite serious domestic and professional implications. I do not think it is unreasonable that, upon deliberation, some people might find that to be simply unacceptable. Earlier the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said that that was their choice and that people appear to have these options open to them. But these are apparent options which have been imposed upon them, so, in fact, what has been imposed upon them is the probability of the need to relocate their families. If they choose not to do that, they get absolutely nothing. They are deemed to have resigned from the Public Service when they have not voluntarily made the decision to do so. They are being forced to resign from the Public Service and, under these circumstances, to resign without redundancy benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister acknowledged that there was great difficulty in redeploying some of these people within the Public Service structure. That is not a difficulty of their own making; it is a difficulty which has been created by this transition from public to private ownership. They have to live with the implications of this redeployment. The implications may-and usually will-be the need to accept different roles and different tasks and possibly be downgraded by one, two or three levels. Admittedly, such people do not suffer a downgrading of salary for a period of 12 months, but beyond that, when perhaps they will begin to incur a downgrading of salary as a result of redeployment, they will be confronted with a choice of either staying in the Public Service in a lower grade or, alternatively, moving on and doing something else.

So we are simply asking for an acknowledgment of the fact that some people will be seriously disadvantaged-or will have the potential to be seriously disadvantaged-by this new set of circumstances which are not of their own making. They may find themselves out of the Public Service and without redundancy or settlement entitlements. Therefore, we believe that there is the possibility that a relatively small group of people will find themselves in this disadvantaged position. If we can have some acknowledgment and some assurance that this set of circumstances can be catered for within the Public Service Act by regulation, we will quite clearly have no substantial objection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A whole series of propositions have been put. I do not think these people will be offered jobs in Western Australia because the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation is really a consortium set up to deal specifically with Williamstown; albeit the shareholders may be in Western Australia, but they do not run similar operations. Therefore, I think that such an offer is most unlikely. It is almost certain that there will be no downgrading involved in any of these moves.

SPEECH.PARA: On the general issue, I am asked to give a categorical assurance that absolutely everyone in the dockyard will leave happy. I cannot do that. This is a negotiated package in which the general good of people was negotiated. If the i's were not dotted or the t's not crossed, I can hardly give such an assurance now-because I will never give an assurance that I might find at some later stage has not been met. It is really asking the impossible to demand an assurance that every group in every circumstance will be walking off the Williamstown Dockyard site with smiles on their faces. However, in virtually all cases they have alternatives. I might add that they have some alternatives that other people in the community are not fortunate enough to have. They will be offered redundancy, alternative employment or employment in the dockyard. That is not a right that everyone else has.

In one way I am pleased that Senator Newman has reacted so strongly in wanting to defend the rights of all those public servants. I hope that when the Opposition returns to government-and I hope that is a long way off-we will not see a reappearance of legislation governing public servants which the Fraser Government introduced. None of these wishy washy and wimpish points would have cut much ice in the days of the Fraser legislation, which introduced a whole series of measures whereby public servants could almost be dismissed at will. Nevertheless, I acknowledge Senator Newman's concern to make sure that everyone is happy. But if she asks me for a categorical assurance that in every circumstance everyone will be looked after, I cannot give it. I have had contact with the Public Service Commission about that three-year period when people can apply for jobs in the Public Service. We have gone as far as we can in a lot of these areas at this stage. I can give no further assurance than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) to make it quite clear that the offer which is being made to people who take employment with the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) is not also being made to the people who choose not to be employed by AMEC and are not eligible for redundancy. Is that the situation of the Government now?
—I am advised that that is the case.

—In that case, the coalition will not find it acceptable and we will need to have consideration of the Bill adjourned so that an amendment can be prepared to protect the interests of those who are involuntarily resigning from the Public Service through no choice of their own. I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The schedule sets out the rural legislation before the Senate at this time, the date on which the Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives, the date on which they were introduced into the Senate and the date set down for debate here. This schedule clearly indicates that the Government gives absolutely no priority whatsoever to this type of legislation, particularly when we find that the fisheries Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 March 1987, prior to the double dissolution, and that the meat and livestock package that we are now debating was introduced on 30 April. There is absolutely no reason why, if the Government had any interest in this matter, this legislation could not have been dealt with well before now. We would not then be going through this helter-skelter business to try to deal with it now.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, 16 December, it is suggested that the legislation should be curtailed, with a truncated debate, for no reason other than that the Government and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) have no interest in the debate or the industries involved. The proposition has apparently been put that we should at this time have a cognate debate on a group of rural Bills covering dairying, wheat, fishing in two different groups, and dried fruits. This sort of thing is simply not on. I am sick and tired, as are the rural industries, of seeing issues vital to these industries shuffled off, year after year, session after session, and relegated to being treated as though they were just a damned nuisance. But they are not. The meat industry, for a start, deserves to have a proper debate on the issues affecting the industry.
