The objects of this package of legislation include: to increase the slaughter levies to fund increased expenditure on meat promotion and marketing; to tighten the accounting and reporting procedures for the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) and the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC); to improve and formalise the consultative process between the AMLC and the AMLRDC and the peak industry bodies; to streamline administrative and certain voting procedures at the annual general meetings of the bodies; and to apply equal opportunity provisions to the two bodies involved.

In general, the industry supports the measures combined in the package, as does the Opposition. Faced by falling levels of red meat consumption, the industry has recognised the need for increased emphasis on promotion and marketing, and supports increased levy payments. The levies this year will rise from $36m in 1986-87 to $75m. I will come back to that later. The industry supports the formalisation of the peak industry bodies and the scrutiny of the AMLC-AMLRDC corporate plans and favours the streamlining of administration related to the annual general meetings (AGMs) of the AMLC and the AMLRDC. Reservations have been expressed, however, about the amendments to the voting procedures for certain motions at annual general meetings. I do not think, by any judgment, it would be possible to find a greater farce than this.

For those who may be unaware, there are currently two voting registers for the AMLC: one for producers and another for processors. At present, a special motion, or a motion to overturn a Corporation motion for an increased levy, requires a vote of 75 per cent of those people listed on each of the two registers. This legislation will require such votes to have the support of only those present at the AGM or by proxy. There is no quarrel with this move which will help liberalise voting procedures. There is concern, however, at the maintenance of the 75 per cent two registers rule. This legislation continues the situation where a levy motion-a motion generally to increase levies-will be defeated only if 75 per cent of those present or by proxy and in each register oppose the motion. This raises two concerns: first, a minority-25.1 per cent-of the shareholders on one of the two registers is able to ensure that the motion is carried; and, secondly, unlike under the Companies Act, the onus is on defeating rather than supporting the motion. In this regard the second reading speech is misleading in that it fails to point out that there must be 75 per cent opposition from both of the two registers.

The following illustration demonstrates the potential inequities that the absence of further amendments could create. At the 1985 annual general meeting, during an amendment to the levy, there were 10,300 votes cast on the producer register. On the processor register, only 29 were cast. Therefore, under this arrangement a levy motion could succeed even if only eight processors voted in favour of the motion-that is, 10,300, or 100 per cent, of the producers and 74.9 per cent of the processors could vote against a motion and it would still succeed. I do not have the figures from this year's recent AGM, but I gather that they were much the same. Of course, this legislation is put forward by a group which screams about gerrymanders, democracy, one vote one value and so on. But we still have that sort of situation in the livestock industry.

Another major concern of the industry is the requirement for levy motions to be debated at the annual general meeting. The cattle and sheep meat industries believe that the AMLC should be obliged to reach agreement with the appropriate industry organisations on proposed levy increases prior to motions being debated at the annual general meeting. It is worth noting that this requirement to consult with the appropriate industry organisations is imposed on other statutory marketing authorities-for example, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wheat Board.

For more than three decades the Australian meat industry has been discussing the development of an agreement on carcass classification. The development of Ausmeat is most welcome but the acceptance of the self-disciplines imposed by the Ausmeat scheme are critical to its success. At the moment the problem seems to lie with pig producers, where there are still problems especially in the central west of New South Wales. The point has been put that, with very little export in the pig meat industry, the producers fail to see the reason why there is need to have a classification and description of carcass which is contrary to their usual method and which, as a result, is costing them money.
When questioned on the matter in the debate in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said:

. . . the Australian Pork Corporation negotiated with the Ausmeat committee of the AMLC for an additional category of carcase which includes many of the components required to be removed under the standard carcase definition.

My understanding is that that arrangement may have meant that the trotters and something else could be left on the carcass. But that does not leave the pig intact to the same extent that it was previously. This procedure is now costing every operation which has in the vicinity of a 100-sow piggery, through the abattoirs which are registered under the Ausmeat system, about $7,000 a year. I believe that there should be provision for this new category of carcass if such a measure is necessary. But I believe that if there is disagreement in respect of the returns payable through the Ausmeat works and the non-Ausmeat works, further discussions should be held with a view to maximising the returns that pig producers are able to achieve.

No section of the meat industry has done as much as the pig producers to secure a better product. They deserve great credit for their results so far. They have secured a better pig-a much better pig. If the AMLC could show as much progress on sheep and beef, what a tremendous meat industry we would now have. Pork has deservedly lifted its popularity and market share. I urge the AMLC to concentrate on the other species so as to produce similar results.

The other major development is that of the computer aided livestock marketing system (CALM). Under the CALM system, users will be able to buy and sell livestock by electronic auction. Although there has been some disagreement on the scheme's detail, the program offers a number of benefits to the industry. At this stage I would like to enumerate six of them. First, the farmers will be able to keep stock on the farm and sell it at the price and conditions most suitable to them; secondly, the system allows for the transfer of stock direct from the farm to the works; thirdly, the sellers have a larger and more competitive buying market; fourthly, sellers must assess their stock more accurately, or have it assessed and consider the grading; fifthly, they can achieve an accurate description; and, sixthly, the system greatly reduces the travelling time and travelling cost of stock.

These Bills provide for a significant increase in the maximum levies on meat producers. These levy increases refer to the maximum rates which are provided for in the legislation. For cattle, this optimum rate has increased from $6 to $18, with the operative levy increasing by $3.30 per head to $11.30 to start on 1 January 1988. If approved, industry contributions to the AMLC in 1988-89 will result in $40.5m for the AMLC's general administration and promotion and a further $35m for residue testing procedures-a total of $75m.

The industry accepts the inevitable importance of greater promotion. But the extraction of the levies from producers will cause significant economic pain in many places. In the last 25 years the economic position of meat producers vis-a-vis average male weekly earnings has been severely eroded. Only eight years ago the income of beef producers was on a par with average weekly earnings whereas, on the latest estimate, beef producers receive only two-thirds of that benchmark. This reduced profitability is clearly demonstrated by the following statistics. In 1962-63, 25 head of cattle paid for a Holden car, whereas to buy an equivalent Holden today would require the sale of 46 head of cattle.

A significant factor in the reduced profitability of the meat industry has been the trend away from red meat over the last decade. Meat consumption peaked in the mid-1970s when Australians consumed 70 kilograms of red meat per head each year. This consumption has slumped dramatically to around 39 kilograms per head annually-about the lowest level ever. In the financial year 1985-86 alone, domestic beef consumption fell by 5 per cent. It is this trend away from red meat consumption that the AMLC and the AMLRDC hope to arrest by devoting increased resources to promotion and research and development. It all comes back to producing better meat and giving it better presentation.

It is a truism of successful marketing that the product should be market driven and not production driven. In short, the product should be tailored to the market, not the market tailored to production. Although the meat industry has made some welcome steps in the direction of greater market responsiveness, change is sometimes slow to filter through the system. One of my preoccupations as a breeder and producer was the genetic production of both lean beef and lean lamb. The recognition of the value of lean red meat as an important new direction for the domestic industry is gratifying, even if slow.

It would be improper not to make some comment on the Corporation and the industry. The Corporation generally has been successful. I give credit to Dick Austen, for the new light he has been able to throw on to it, and to Peter Frawley. I also commend Scott Ashton-Jones and others in Tasmania for the work they have done to advance the Corporation. It covers a very major group of industries. The industry presently runs something over 50 million sheep and 23 million cattle. It embraces 76,000 producers, whose product is worth $2,500m a year. It produces a million tonnes of beef, lamb and mutton alone, plus many other products. There is considerable export of a whole variety of meats and animals. The AMLC's annual report for 1986-87 lists them: live sheep, 7.7 million head; breeding sheep, 12,600 head; slaughter and feed cattle, 60,000 head; breeding beef, 17,445 head; dairy cattle exports, 3,554 head; live goats, increased to 44,000 head; buffalo, 4,536-and so it goes on. The industry has advanced in numbers and lines, and may it continue to do so.

The industry has considerable needs in research and development. There are consumer pressures. There is a world surplus. The European Community (EC) and the United States, with their protection problems, are causing us a lot of difficulty. Then there is the special Japanese situation. The need is for better description and payment by description. The success of the CALM process is absolutely essential. There is insufficient inducement for the industry to be consumer conscious and for producers to produce the best beast possible. We need to concentrate particularly on the lean meat programs and to look at breeding-including the European breeds and the bos indicus influence. We also need to study the rates of growth of various breeds of animals. We need a better definition of what constitutes prime meat, we need greater price differentials between the top and the bottom of the market and we need to look at the cut-out percentages of carcasses.

I would like to acknowledge the amount of research being done generally. I note that the annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation lists 125 different research programs under way. They cover a whole range of things, from the monitoring of the industry through to breeding, feeding, processing, marketing, health, disease control, transport and so on. I would like particularly to acknowledge the work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and, as far as the cattle industry is concerned, especially the work done in tropical areas and the areas where the cattle are. I refer to the work it has done in places such as Townsville, Cairns, Rockhampton and Brisbane, and to its work in Sydney, Melbourne and Geelong in disease immunology and things of that sort. There has been considerable advance in the work done in skins and hides treatment as a result of the efforts of its Division of Protein Chemistry.

The potential for huge lamb export markets is developing. We have to provide the right lamb to meet those markets. There is a great need for value added work in the meat we sell and the by-products. We need to assist in the promotion of the AMLC through butchers and supermarkets. At present the AMLC has over 8,000 butcher shops listed for its promotions. Brucellosis and tuberculosis need a special mention. The work in controlling brucellosis has been very effective. It is a job very well done. It appears that Australia will be clear by 1992. Apparently fewer than 30 properties in the whole of Australia still carry an infection. The tuberculosis problem is slightly more difficult, particularly where there are buffalo. But eradication can be achieved. We must ensure that we keep an eye on pet food manufacturers so we do not lose control over the problem.

We are currently facing the problem of residues. I do not intend to say very much on that matter; I will leave it to Senator Brownhill to comment. But we have in the order of 500 properties in quarantine. There are three different classes of problem. The first concerns antibiotics. There is a need for heavy penalties for anybody who tries to market property which is under the influence of antibiotics, and obviously there can be such residues only if the antibiotics are administered. Anybody who does that deserves to suffer. The second class consists of properties that are infected accidentally. This includes the properties of people who may have had their light poles sprayed by the electricity authority or something like that. The third group consists of people who used the various chemicals in the manner prescribed, well within the law, and who are now suffering although they were not responsible for having made the decisions that allowed the product to be used. Those people deserve special consideration.

Research is urgent and early results are vital. In the meantime testing must proceed. I understand that between 250,000 and 300,000 tests have already been made. We are looking for a system that will reduce costs from double figure dollars to double figure cents and will enable tests to be carried out on the premises. The big hope is that we will be able to get a colour-responsive litmus-type test. That would be ideal. That is very high on the list of the testing and research effort. Surely a fifty-fifty contribution by the Government would ensure that research was speeded up and every possible effort was applied. We have to give credit to the amount of work that has already been done by the Australian Agricultural Council and acknowledge the degree of testing that has proceeded and encourage the research in any way we possibly can.

It has been brought to my notice that moves have been made to purchase a new gee-whiz computer, at a cost of $1m, just for co-ordinating residue testing. It is proposed that the system will be totally independent of any other computer operation, and of course it will be funded mainly by the producer levy. I am aware that the Csironet Anadis operation is on the computer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and that the computer also contains information on foreign fishing, plus details of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. That installation could be enhanced 3 1/2 times, at a cost of about $600,000, and provide a much better system at a much lower cost. I would like the Minister to advise whether this project is still scheduled to go forward and whether there has been adequate investigation of whether this job can be done on the existing computer with an upgraded system. The software skills already exist. I expect the best value to be obtained for the producer's expense, particularly if this colour-responsive testing system is achieved, as we all hope it will be.

Finally, I will touch briefly on the export situation. The export meat industry makes a major contribution to the fortunes of the industry as a whole. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Australian meat exports, excluding the live sheep trade, were worth $1.9 billion in the 1986-87 financial year. That figure is cited in the AMLC annual report. These exports represent 4.7 per cent of total commodity exports. Australia's export meat industry, like most of our commodity exports, has been seriously disadvantaged by the corruption of world markets through export subsidisation and other unfair trading tactics. I recently read a European Community publication called Agricultural Prices-1987/88 Proposals which, on the question of short and medium term prospects for commodities, predicted:

The overall situation seems likely to worsen under the combined influence of three factors, namely over-production at world level, the relative inelasticity of supply and the shortage of foreign exchange in the third world.
The report continued grimly:
An analysis of the available data indicates that the structural imbalance between supply and demand is likely to persist for the foreseeable future, with prices remaining depressed.

The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. I would like to congratulate the industry on the progress it has made in the last decade, and I urge even greater attention to the product improvement and market consciousness. I give notice at this stage of the three amendments that stand in the name of the Opposition. The first amendment is to the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, and it requests the Government to honour its policy of meeting 55 per cent of inspection charges, including chemical residue inspections. The second is to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, and it concerns consultation with industry organisations before the levy charges are made. The third amendment applies to the same Bill, and it seeks to amend and insert a new clause in the equal employment opportunity provisions in line with our previously stated policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Archer in his remarks. Because these Bills that we are debating cognately today are very important for the livestock industries. They affect a number of areas and I wish to address my remarks to several of the more important issues contained in this particular package of Bills-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill will in fact amend several Acts. It will formalise the involvement of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) in the Australian pork industry through the Australian Pork Corporation, which Senator Archer has already mentioned. On a general note, it will alter the running of the AMLC annual general meetings and amend existing requirements for the Livestock Industry Policy Council to hold conferences every two years and make changes to the AMLC selection committee. With these changes, the responsible Minister will also be able to implement marketing schemes such as CALM-which is computer aided livestock marketing-and Ausmeat, which is a uniform specification system for meat and livestock.

The Bill also ensures that the AMLC consults industry bodies on five-year strategy plans on a rolling annual basis and people selected to the Board can be appointed for up to three years and not for three-year terms. This will give more flexibility to the Corporation and will be of benefit to the industry as a whole. These sections of the legislation are wanted by the industry and will benefit the administrative efficiency of the livestock industries in Australia.

However, certain aspects of this package are not popular. Senator Archer has already alluded to some of them but, for the benefit of honourable senators, I will reiterate some of them. For example, this Bill has caused a great deal of consternation to sections of the pork industry, and I would like to take some time to air the concerns sections of this industry have. The Central West Pig Producers Association, from my home State of New South Wales, together with a number of other small groups of producers, is worried about the proposed changes being made to Ausmeat classifications for the pig industry. Not all in the pig industry have the same views on this matter. In fact, the Pork Producers Association is in favour of the proposals. I feel sorry that there is disunity in the pig industry on this matter because the pig industry, perhaps more than any other livestock industry, has worked consistently over a number of years towards a standard carcass classification scheme for itself, which Senator Archer has already pointed out.

The current Ausmeat classification for pork and bacon carcasses provides for one of two choices. The first includes the head, the flare, the kidney and the fore trotters removed, with the alternative leaving the head on, but removing the tongue and the ears. Sections of the industry argue that using these two classifications will not only deny butchers the use of trotters and heads, but also mean an average loss to the producers of about $2.30 to $3 per pig. I think Senator Archer has already mentioned that that amounts to quite a considerable sum per producer. Some producers would like a third option included in the classification scheme which would allow an entire carcass. They argue that there are no cost advantages to the producers in the existing two classifications. They do not support Ausmeat's argument that the new trim will allow for higher prices per kilo, and they do not support the accommodation to an export industry which is, in relative terms, quite small.

As I said, I feel sorry that this industry, which has in the past had a reputation as being efficient-which has adopted aggressive marketing to make its product more appealing to the consumer and which has adopted new technology and now is most progressive-has had this division within its ranks. I am sympathetic to the arguments of those pig producers. However, I and my colleagues are of the firm opinion that it is up to the industry itself to sort out its problems. I do not believe it is appropriate for divided industries to turn to politicians and expect them to provide the wisdom of Solomon, although we can provide a lot of wisdom at times. We do not have to live with the system; basically the producer does. I think it is up to the producers to really participate in their organisation.

The Australian Pork Producers Association must thrash out its own problems. If that means that it is stuck with a classification system that is not to all producers' liking, so be it. The only consolation I can offer is that Ausmeat has said that the new classifications will be on a one-year trial basis and that the situation will be reviewed. So I think there is some light at the end of the tunnel for those people who are not happy with the situation at this stage. If in fact the industry does suffer a loss of income, I am sure it will not be in anyone's best interest to continue with the system and it will be changed.

Of even more concern in this package are the amendments dealing with the increases to the maximum levy rate for inspection, which will raise the levy from $6 to $18 a head for adult cattle. There are similar scaling up charges for sheep, goats, lambs and buffaloes. At present the maximum levy is some $6 a head for cattle, but in practice the charge has remained at $3.30. The AMLC meeting the other day suggested some charges which would probably be up to about $9.80, the new promotion costing about $3 and the new residue testing suggested to cost about $3.50-but it could be up to $5. I would also like to make some comments about that AMLC meeting the other day, which I attended. The producers are taking a much bigger interest now than they did in the past. In my opinion the meeting was very well run by Mr Dick Austen, and I would like to congratulate him also on the job that he has done for the industry in the last year.

The pesticides scare, however, has changed the situation. The discovery of meat in both the United States and Japan containing higher than acceptable levels of pesticide residues has posed a severe threat to the Australian beef industry. It has dented our reputation as a reliable producer and it has caused panic among producers. I might say here that it is quite interesting that the American authorities test only between 1,000 and 2,000 samples from their entire domestic cattle herd of some 100 million. On the other hand, they are now taking 4,000 samples from our beef imports, which represents-I think this has already been mentioned at other times and in other places-about 6,000 per cent closer attention to the residue testing of our beef than of their own.

The Government has reacted to the problem by announcing increased intensive testing for organochlorines in meat for export. In the circumstances that is an entirely proper and responsible approach to take and I have no argument with its decision to do so. But, as a beef producer myself and also as someone vitally concerned with Australia's trading position, I say that this is something that concerns me and all other beef producers a great deal at this stage. I would like to make several points on this issue. Honourable senators would be aware, from questions I have asked without notice in this chamber and also in the estimates hearings for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, that I have some reservations about the Federal Government's role. Prior to this pesticide scare, standard residue testing was carried out and this was funded entirely by the Government to the tune of $1.8m. The Government has decided, in light of the pesticide problems, that testing should be increased. It has also decided that it should change the payments and it has called on the industry to contribute 50 per cent of this annual cost, which has already been discussed in this place. This has been increased to approximately $5.4m a year. This means that the contribution from the industry is some $2.7m, when it was previously nothing, and the Government's contribution has increased from $1.8m to $2.7m. The proposed intensive testing is anticipated to cost a total of $15m, and the industry and the Government will each contribute $7.5m. I do not believe the industry has been fairly treated in this whole sorry affair. The Age reports Mr Kerin, when addressing the recent National Farmers Federation Conference, as follows:

`The way we've handled chemicals has been deplorable,' he said. `States have been negligent with respect to these chemicals, quite frankly. The beef industry's the one that's copped it in the neck and in effect is cleaning up the environment for the rest of the livestock industry, and the country as a whole.'

That is what is happening at the moment. The beef industry is carrying the can for the rest of the community as far as residue testing is concerned. It is interesting to read a little about liability, if the facts reported in the Press are correct. Mr David Palmer, the New South Wales Farmers Association's executive officer for meat and livestock, was mentioned in a recent Land newspaper article which states:
David Palmer, said letters written by the then Minister for Agriculture, Don Day,-
Don Day was a member of the Australian Labor Party Government in New South Wales-
in 1975 and 1976 indicated unnecessary procrastination by the NSW Government and the Department of Agriculture on banning chemicals like DDT.
Mr Palmer said Mr Day and his department had advocated the continued use of DDT at a time when farm organisations wanted the chemical banned and alternative and safer pesticides were available.

I think the Government is liable in the pesticide residue argument and I think it is partly at fault. But I suppose one could argue for hours about whether it was the fault of the chemical companies, the Federal Government or the various State governments. It may well be true in some cases that farmers were at fault for careless use of the chemicals. However, it cannot be said that it is entirely the fault of the beef industry, and it would therefore seem grossly unfair to insist that the beef industry suffer the total cost of cleaning up the residue problem. Additionally, the intensive testing will be of benefit to others, because it will point out potential problems before they affect other foods.

The beef industry is worth some $2.6 billion a year to the Australian economy. For that reason alone it should be protected and kept on a sound footing. I think the industry and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation in particular, should be commended for the way they have addressed this crisis. I think they have viewed the threat to the beef trade to America in a very responsible way. They have also taken into account that it will be a threat to Australia's economy and our current account if we do not clean it up. I must stress again that the pesticide residue problem is not the fault of livestock producers but it is this sector that has been asked to finance the clean-up. I think the Government should look again at giving it some more help to clean up the export industry problem which, if allowed to go on, will cause a lot of problems to Australia's current account.

Finally, I would like to point out the insistence on equal employment opportunity (EEO) clauses which this Government feels necessary to tack on to every bit of legislation concerning statutory marketing authorities. I am a firm believer in the premise that jobs should be allocated on the basis of merit and not sex, religion, colour or anything else. I have often said in this place that women are more than equal with men, and I do not think there is any need for that to be placed in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —More equal.

—More equal, as Senator Boswell said. The various rural statutory marketing authorities have operated very sucessfully for a number of years without the need to resort to clauses such as the EEO provisions. I do not think they are necessary. But that will all be discussed with the amendments that will be moved by Senator Archer. I will support all the amendments that will be moved by him, as our spokesman in this debate. I counsel the Government again and ask it to listen with a sympathetic ear to the beef industry's arguments about cleaning up the residue problem in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are engaged in another debate on allied Bills. To pick up Senator Archer's point, I suppose in some way we can be grateful that although at the end of the session we seem to have a large backlog of primary industry legislation-something which I note since I carry that shadow portfolio for the Australian Democrats-at least this time all the Bills we are debating relate to the meat and livestock industry. I briefly recall that at the end of the autumn session this year we had egg, wool and nursing home Bills all together in one cognate debate. I found that debate a great challenge. At least on this occasion we are addressing ourselves to a range of Bills which relate strictly to the meat and livestock industry. They are important Bills, as has been pointed out by earlier speakers. The first of the Bills, the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, amends a number of meat and livestock Acts and includes the formalisation of arrangements between the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and the Australian Pork Corporation in the development of marketing schemes for meat and livestock, changes to the operation of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation's annual general meeting, and the requirement for that Corporation's five-year plan to be updated annually and for the Corporation to consult with industry in the preparation of these plans. In addition, the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council will retain its power to call industry-wide conferences whenever it feels they are needed, while the requirement for the Council to hold such conferences at least every two years will be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Brownhill has pointed out, the legislation also requires the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council to adopt the equal employment opportunity program, which is consistent with that already existing in the Australian Wool Corporation and which is also proposed for the Australian Wheat Board and other statutory corporations, as was the commitment of the Government, strongly supported by the Australian Democrats. We are pleased to see the implementation of these important equal employment opportunity programs in these rural authorities as the legislation relating to those authorities comes through. As Senator Brownhill has pointed out, we will have some amendments from the Opposition, amendments largely based on a stated perception at least that this Bill in some way implements an affirmative action program, but that is not the case. The Australian Democrats certainly do not perceive that to be the case. Senator Brownhill expressed some concern that appointments should be on the basis of merit. This legislation provides for that, as does all of the equal employment opportunity legislation which has been passed in recent times with strong Democrat support. Senator Brownhill did mention that rural statutory bodies had been chugging along quite nicely without the need for this provision. That is something that ought to be challenged.

I refer to an article published in the business section of the Times on Sunday of 17 May which outlines some of the deficiencies within statutory corporations in the rural sector. The article appeared before the Australian Wool Corporation legislation had been passed. The article cited some figures relating to the Australian Wool Corporation. At that time the Corporation had 621 employees in total, and women made up 240 of that figure, or 39 per cent. It is interesting that the number of male employees whose salaries were above $30,000 per annum was 130, while the figure for women was 31, or 19 per cent of the total work force. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, the body which we are now addressing, had 180 employees of which 72 were women, that is, 40 per cent. Ten of those women, or 14 per cent of the total work force, received salaries above $30,000, while 61 men received salaries above that level. Forty-two per cent of the total number of employees of the Australian Dairy Corporation were women, but only 11 per cent of women, out of the total work force figure, received salaries above $30,000 per annum. In regard to the Australian Wheat Board, 32 per cent of its employees were women and 11.5 per cent of the total work force receiving salaries above the $30,000 level were women.

Those figures reflect the situation in the wider community. Women do not receive anything like the earnings of men. If one were to say that women earned 65 per cent of average male earnings, that would probably be too high a figure. It is quite clear that, although we have come a long way in recent times in our attitudes to women, we still need the sorts of provisions, such as those contained in this legislation, which draw attention to some of the deficiencies and encourage corporations and individuals to provide the possibilities for women which have existed all along for men.

This matter is particularly significant in primary industry bodies, because one of the things that have not been recognised sufficiently is the role that women have played and do play in rural areas and, in particular, on the land. All too often it is not recognised that farming and primary production generally are most often a co-operative effort between partners or between entire families. It is quite distressing that in this day and age a sales agent for a rural company can telephone a farm property, have the call answered by a female member of the household, and ask to speak to the boss. I think that that sort of attitude is quite outdated, but it still occurs in this area. There is a failure to recognise the significant role that women play in rural industries.

I draw attention to a booklet issued by Poolman Partners Australasia Pty Ltd, entitled Strategies for Survival. The subtitle is `Managing and financing the family farm in the 1990s'. The foreword by Julian Cribb points out that this booklet from Poolmans challenges some of the conventions of the family farm of the twentieth century in its struggle to adapt to change. I was very pleased to see a section on farm nepotism in that booklet. It points out:
. . . it is still a common farm and agribusiness practice to hand over management, and often ownership, of the family farm to a son or sons, while daughters are relocated in other careers.
In some cases, girls are better equipped and qualified to take over a family farm business than male heirs. Often, unfortunately, this option is not even considered.
Vital management and specialist resources are being overlooked and ignored in agriculture because of farm nepotism.

The provisions in this legislation, as far as the Corporation is concerned, recognise that, unfortunately, nepotism of this kind is still rampant in our community. It is not necessarily a matter very often of specific individual prejudice or a lack of willingness; it is simply that all too often we do not understand what we are doing when it comes to discrimination and that it has permeated throughout our whole community. We must take steps such as those that are taken in this legislation to provide for equal employment opportunity, particularly with regard to the rural sector, in which women play such a significant role.

This week I was visited by women from the Union of Australian Farmers, who I believe are playing a significant role in drawing to the attention of the community the plight of people in terms of income support and their ability to retain their farms. They are addressing issues such as those we addressed in legislation last week with regard to income support for people on the land. We are now seeing a new generation of farm women activists who are being extremely political in their activities in support of women on the land in Australia. I congratulate them; I offer them my support. The Australian Democrats certainly support those provisions in the legislation.

Further amendments provide for the appointment of members of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee for periods up to three years, and also remove the requirement for the preparation of an annual report. The Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987 and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987 contain some fairly substantial increases to the maximum allowable levies and charges. There is no doubt that these increases are substantial. The increases are largely necessary due to the cost involved following the chemical residue crisis which loomed before us earlier this year.

The last two Bills in this package-the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987-make some technical amendments to the principal Acts dealing with collection arrangements and registration charges in establishments involved in the export of fish and poultry products.

In giving the Australian Democrats' support for this package of Bills, I will address some concerns the Australian Democrats have in regard to some of the changes proposed by the Government, and some more concerns which relate to problems facing the meat and livestock industry in general. In respect of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, representations have been made to me by a number of pig producer groups, including the Central West Pig Producers Association, the Lachlan Valley Pork Producers Association and the Mudgee Pig Producers Group, all of which have strongly protested about the lack of information and communication afforded to pig producers prior to the introduction of Ausmeat and the consequent changes which have been outlined by previous speakers relating to the standard and definition of carcass trim, which is financially disadvantaging these pig producers.

These groups do not object to the principles of Ausmeat in total; however, I feel that the concern expressed is genuine and warrants the attention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), as well as greater consultation and understanding by Ausmeat representatives. I pick up the point that Senator Brownhill made. When there is conflict within an industry, and particularly within a significant industry such as the pork producing industry, that causes some problems for politicians. However, I suggest that we are happy to bring those views and concerns before the Minister and will ask for his consideration of them.

Turning to the changes to the operation of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation's annual general meeting, I understand that it is the Government's intention to streamline the voting procedure because that procedure has proved to be too unwieldy. In order to increase the levy, the requirement will now be for a vote of 75 per cent of those people present, either in person or by proxy, rather than the requirement for a vote of 75 per cent of people on the register, as is the case at present. I also understand that Senator Archer, on behalf of the Opposition, has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading, to the effect that the recommendations for levy changes should in future be made direct to the Minister by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation only after it has consulted with appropriate industry organisations. While the Australian Democrats recognise that there have been difficulties in voting procedure, our position is that we support the Government's endeavours to try to streamline these procedures in the form of this amending legislation. Therefore, we will not support the amendment proposed by the Opposition.

The Australian Democrats are in complete agreement with the new requirement, as embodied in this legislation, for the AMLC to consult with the peak industry bodies in the preparation of its five-year plan and its annual operational plan and the additional requirement that the five-year plan be updated each year so that it constantly covers the following five years. We see this as a particularly sensible requirement and one which will encourage co-operation between the Corporation and industry bodies and allow for flexibility to cope with emergencies within that five-year planning process. In this respect, I note that the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRC), in its 1986-87 annual report, has found it necessary to submit a revised plan with commencement in 1988-89 in the light of the recent and continuing residue crisis concerning our beef. This is a good example of the way in which this sort of flexibility is useful.

While I am on the subject of chemical residues, I now turn to the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, both of which propose maximum levies and charges for both the AMLC and the AMLRDC components. In about half of the species to which the levies and charges apply, the increases are up to 300 per cent. The Minister, in his second reading speech for both Bills, informed us that the reason for these proposed increases in the maximum levies and charges is to enable the AMLC itself to seek increases in levies and charges from the industry in order to expand its domestic and overseas promotion activities and `finance industry supported programs related to testing and trace-back of meat for chemical residues and the repurchase of certain meat which may contain such residues'. The Bills give legislative force to increases that the industry itself has requested and agreed to. While the legislation contains the maximum levies and charges allowable, at the annual general meeting of the AMLC which was referred to earlier in the debate the industry agreed to increases to the AMLC component, which will become operative in March or April 1988. There are also some increases to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation component.

I turn now to the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading concerning the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill. The Australian Democrats have difficulty with this. I think I understand what the Opposition intends but I do not think it has actually said what it intends. The amendment asks the Government to honour its policy of meeting 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges. I am not aware that there is anything in this legislation that does not do that. Possibly the Opposition was referring to the other charges in the other Bill-charges for residue testing and buy-back programs-which are charges on the industry. Since at least that part of the amendment seems to be addressing something which is already in existence, it cannot be supported. The second part calls on the Government sympathetically to consider requests from the industry for assistance with any special and additional export costs imposed on the industry by the chemical residue issue. That, of course, is something which we would all wish the Government to do. However, it does make an assumption that there has been no support from the Government and that, of course, is not the case. It is obvious that there is not as much support as the industry would have liked; that is an ongoing process. But it has already been pointed out in this debate that the Government's contribution to the upgrading of the national residue survey is costing the Government another $1m or so this year. There is no question that reside testing, buy-back and the whole problem are costing the industry. So, on that basis and given that these two points are put together, the Democrats will not support that amendment.

We certainly recognise, as does the industry, that levies and charges have to be instituted. We congratulate the industry on the speedy action which it has taken in the past, but we have some serious concerns about the direction of government and industry efforts to remedy the residue problem. While some of the chemicals in question, in particular DDT and dieldrin, should have been banned in Australia long ago, as they were in other countries, and while government and industry have responded quickly to the recent crisis by upgrading testing procedures and quarantining contaminated farms-we should make it clear that those quarantines are voluntary-it is not even a matter of too little too late: we believe that this crisis should prompt a fundamental rethinking of the use of chemicals in agriculture. The residue problem in our beef is really only the tip of the iceberg. Unless government, industry and producers make big changes in policy and practice now, the future for Australian agriculture is not assured.

The particular chemicals in question were widely used 10, 15 and 20 years ago, and it is only now that we are seeing the effects of their persistent qualities on much of our resource base, that is, the soil, our crops, our livestock, the food we eat and export and, ultimately, the harmful effects on the health of all Australians. The question must be asked: Just what other chemicals, either in current production or planned for the future, will have similar or worse effects? Unfortunately, that question is not being asked often enough and clearly enough, and it is certainly not being answered.

Since the initial crisis this year, I have been calling on the Government for a range of concrete actions. I have included in that a call for greater liaison with the States to set up uniform standards and legislation on chemicals. I welcome the Minister's news that we will have agricultural and veterinary chemical legislation before us first thing next year. We need legislation for a national chemicals inventory and notification scheme. We need to look at research into chemicals being done outside the industry. We need compensation for quarantined farms and we need to look at where that is coming from. We certainly cannot look past chemical companies and State governments directly at the Federal Government only. Government promotion and encouragement of alternative methods of pest and disease control are important, including the establishment of an integrated pest management unit to compile and disseminate information on pest and disease control methods which will exclude, or largely exclude, use of all chemicals.

Mr Kerin, the Minister, has already been quoted in this debate. In the Australian on 3 September this year he was reported as saying that he was committed to the establishment of legislation to cover agricultural and veterinary chemicals. That initial statement is now being followed up with action. Finally, we believe that is essential for State and Federal governments to promote more benign and effective control of pests and diseases. On the National Farm Report, I believe it was, just last week I heard that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association has established its own weed resistance task force. The director of that task force was talking about establishing integrated weed management systems which would occur with the use of procedures; and farming practices other than the simple use of chemicals. If we do not ensure that we have proper regulation and monitoring of chemicals and proper dissemination of a wide range of information on the basis of a whole range of alternatives, we will as a community continue to suffer the economic costs of repair for current and future generations, which could be crippling.

We have quite a challenge before us. The industry is to be congratulated on the responsible approach that it has taken so far. I notice that, just today, Mr Wally Peart of the Cattle Council of Australia has gone on record as calling on the industry to continue with its voluntary funding into next year, when compulsory funding is introduced. He made a strong statement in support of the process that is going on, and the industry is to be congratulated on the approach that it has taken in a difficult time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Amendment Bill 1987 and cognate Bills, which relate to the meat and livestock industries of Australia. These industries play a critical role in the welfare of all Australians and our economy. Livestock slaughtering injects $95m into our economy every week and a total of $4.9 billion was injected into the economy in 1987 and 1988. If one adds to those figures another $6 billion for products including wool, skins and dairy produce one sees what a significant industry this is, and what a major role it plays in the economy of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This magnificent performance deserves proper recognition from all levels of government and we must not underestimate the value of the livestock industries to the well being of all Australians. The Bills introduce a wide range of amendments in such areas as computer aided livestock marketing, Ausmeat, chemical residue testing, the Livestock Industry Policy Council and slaughter levies. They are fairly complicated Bills and I know that many people who are listening tonight, as they weave their way through the traffic, are not interested in primary industry. However, I say to those people that this industry plays a very significant role in the well being of all Australians.

I wish to concentrate on the particular issues of the voting procedures at the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) annual meeting, and the outlook for the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign as it affects Queensland, the Northern Territory and the northern areas of Western Australia. The problems of the voting procedures at the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation annual meeting has been well documented over a long period by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Bruce Lloyd, and his predecessor, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). Put simply, the voting procedures set down by this Government are not working and need immediate amendment and change. This Government must put its house in order and sit down to discuss the matter with an industry that provides so many millions of dollars and so many jobs for all Australians. It must come up with some realistic alternative to this mess.

Honourable senators may not be aware of the situation that our producers face at the AMLC annual meeting. It is astonishing that at least 75 per cent of producers registered with the AMLC, plus at least 75 per cent of registered processors, must vote against the motion to increase slaughter levies before the motion is defeated. In other words, a small group of people can effectively override the wishes of a majority of producers to impose a levy increase and our producers have no recourse to any further action. At the 1985 annual general meeting, when levies were increased, 10,300 producers and 29 processors were registered for a vote. That means that a vote of just eight processors in favour of increased levies on producers would ensure that increases took place. That is not democracy on any scale whatsoever; in fact, it is an absolute farce. I do not know what this Government is up to when it tries to pass legislation such as that. I say to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, that the least he can do is to sit down with representatives of this multi-billion dollar industry to ensure that the producers get some type of fair go-a fair go that they have not had in the last two or three years. I will not dwell on the matter beyond saying that the present situation cannot continue and that the Minister will be judged on his attitude on the long overdue change.

I turn in particular to the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987 and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987. It is proposed that the maximum allowable amount of levy on the slaughter of cattle will rise from $6 to $18. That levy comprises three sections of funding-the AMLC activities of promotion, industry research and development and disease eradication. The operative rate of levy will be set by regulation. It goes without saying that we on this side of the chamber will thoroughly scrutinise any increase in levies that is unsatisfactory for the industry. However, I point out to the livestock producers that of course an increase in the maximum levy does not necessarily mean an increase in the operative rate.

The Minister has claimed widespread support for substantial increases in slaughter rates and promotional expenditure. The major industry organisations have considerable doubts as to whether the maximum operational levy envisaged by the AMLC for chemical residue testing purposes will actually be acquired by the time the levies can be implemented. The reason is that many of the areas that are returning positive testings have now been nominated and the testing will take place only in those particular areas. There is a large body of opinion, particularly among Queensland producers, that Australia will be off lot testing by April 1988, which is less than six months away. Let us hope that that can be achieved.

The cattle industry is not unlike many other rural industries. It suffers from crippling interest rates, an inflation rate four times the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, a fuel excise of 20 cents a litre, high chemical and fertiliser costs and other such government charges under the Hawke Labor regime. In no circumstances must these producers be subject to anything more than the bare minimum cost required to maintain the Australian meat industry's outstanding export reputation. Already the industry's commitment to a high level of testing has paid dividends in that the violation rate is now 0.07 per cent. That represents a large decline on what was the average rate of violation of 0.4. That rate has been maintained in regard to Australian meat exports for the last few years. This reflects the dramatic effect of the quarantining of over 300 properties around Australia.

In the meantime there is a strong case for the Government sharing the residue testing costs with the industry. When the residue problem became apparent the industry swiftly responded of its own volition and, off its own bat, put in between $25m and $30m. This Labor Government has contributed very little-barely anything at all. That is quite disgraceful when we compare what the Labor Government has done for the secondary industries of this nation. Only yesterday we saw a disgraceful performance in this Senate when the Government tried to inflict on the industry a 15c a head levy to be made retrospective to 1 July, taking from the industry I think another $5m. This was to provide and charge for a service that had already been provided for the last number of years at absolutely no cost. This disgraceful performance was aided and abetted by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.

—It was absolutely shameful to see them change their attitude. After they had moved a motion in the Senate which stated that they would support the farmers, they turned their backs on the rural producers of Australia once again. I know that it disappointed everyone on this side of the House because we thought that we could do a good deed for the farmers and the graziers in their hour of need. But we got let down badly by the Democrats once again. I do not want to denigrate the Democrats; I will let the farmers and the grazing industry of Australia make their own judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to what the Australian Labor Party has done for this secondary industry and let us examine the anti-rural bias that this Labor Party displays. The steel industry is a good example. The steel industry said, `We are in strife. We need help. What can you offer us?' Senator Button, no doubt after a gentle shove from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, found over $500m to be paid over five years. On reading Senator Button's Press release I see that he said that this was the worst mistake he has ever made. He has certainly never helped rural industry and this Government has never helped the Australian farmer.

What about the car manufacturers? They said, `We need some investment money,' and the Government said, `How can we help?' The Labor Party and the Labor Government found $300m to answer that problem, yet the export reputation of our meat industry comes under question. The industry takes the bit in its teeth and says, `We will solve our own problems'. It is spending $30m, that is, $130,00 a day, to protect the living standards of every Australian. Exactly what has this Government done for rural Australia over the last five years? Nothing. It is an absolute disgrace.

It is time that our meat producers and our farmers were given some encouragement for the tremendous job they are doing on behalf of all Australians. They have had nothing from this Government except platitudes and even they are wearing a bit thin after five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But more of them are voting for us.

—I have never met a farmer yet who has voted for the Labor Party. I suppose that there are some poor misguided people around, but I have been in politics for 12 years and I have never met one farmer who has ever voted for the Labor Party. He would be socially ostracised if he voted for the Labor Party in Queensland.
—That's right; and the Democrats.

—We do not even talk about the Democrats. I turn now to the eradication of brucellosis and tuberculosis. This is another example of the meat industry and the rural industry needing some help. I want to emphasise a concern raised with me by Queensland cattle producers over the disease eradication component of the levies to be amended by this package of legislation. I am sure that all honourable senators will recognise the outstanding response by the coalition parties, when they were in government, to the threat posed by the long-standing diseases, brucellosis and tuberculosis. This has already culminated in a recent declaration in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia as being impending free of those diseases. I congratulate the farmers of those States for their achievement, but I ask them to spare a thought for the northern farmers who have to reach this impending free stage in very difficult circumstances, which I will go into a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Budget Paper No. 1 clearly retains 1992 as the target date for a nationwide disease free declaration, and I hope that we can achieve that date. It is hoped that Queensland will have its impending free status by January 1992. The Hawke Government now appears reluctant to advance further funds to Queensland so the program can be accelerated and thereby achieve overall savings in its cost.

In 1987-88 Queensland required $10.66m for compensation payments, compared with the Hawke Government's offer of $8.2m. If we spend more this year, we will spend $800,000 less next year. The Government claims that the Queensland compensation rates are above the cost of the cattle on the properties. This is frustrating the farmers. The industry bodies are seeking a high level meeting between Federal and State primary industry Ministers and their counterparts from the Northern Territory and Western Australia to resolve these fundamental differences on how the programs can be most effectively financed. As Senator Walsh is not in the chamber, I will ask a question of Senator Gareth Evans, who is the Minister in charge of the chamber. I do not think he knows a lot about rural industries, but I hope he can pass this message on to the Minister because it is very important. Queensland needs at least $10.6m for compensation payments this year. I ask the Government to accept that, despite the fact that tremendous progress has been made, a final total eradication from the more remote regions of north Australia will be quite difficult to achieve by 1992. I have been into the northern areas of my State. It is probably the roughest country in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rough people, too.

—I would not agree. They are absolutely lovely people. They are the salt of the earth. I have flown over those places and remote cattle stations in the Gulf and Peninsula country in Queensland. Farmers have tremendous problems. They have difficulty in putting down a fence line. As soon as the fence line is down the brumbies come through and knock it over. They have many other problems, such as floods, and they muster cattle in difficult circumstances. Queensland will find it extremely difficult to reach the target date of 1992. I hope it can be reached. I know that at the moment almost all the cattle have been mustered by normal means and the ones that are left have to be shot out. I know that Senator Powell will be disgusted because I know what she thinks about that type of behaviour. It is an absolute necessity up there. There is no way that the remaining cattle can be mustered because they are too wild, so a shoot-out is the only way left for Queensland to become clean by 1992. The industry needs to plan ahead. It needs an assurance that the present funding arrangements will, in principle, be maintained where necessary if the 1992 target date is not achieved. Queenslanders are already paying around $3m a year for stock crossing the border into New South Wales and Victoria because of their impending free status. Queenslanders should not suffer discrimination in the latest step of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC).

SPEECH.PARA: I seek an assurance from the Government and from Senator Gareth Evans-I know he is very interested in this matter-that funding will be maintained. The least that Senator Evans and the Hawke Government can do is to provide some money for this very important industry that gives so much for all Australians. As I have already said, the cattle industry provides millions of dollars in foreign exchange and thousands of jobs. It has to put up with many problems-the residue problem, problems associated with the BTEC, the natural disasters of fires and floods, and all of the vicissitudes that annoy farmers. But the low blow that has been dealt to the industry by this Government, when the renewal of leases incurred the capital gains tax, is just beyond the pale.

A couple of weeks ago this rumour was mentioned in the Australian Financial Review, which hinted that a capital gains tax could be charged on the renewal of grazing leases. I never believed that the Government would charge a capital gains tax on the renewal of leases so I fired off a question to Senator Walsh-only to have my worst fears confirmed, that is, that a capital gains tax now applies to the renewal or conversion of leases. I then put a series of questions on notice to which I received answers only today. I thought that I might have been able to congratulate the Australian Labor Party and Senator Walsh but, unfortunately, the anti-rural bias has come back once again. I was told that this measure was an unintended consequence. Mr Kerin said that a capital gains tax was not meant to apply to the renewal of leases and would not be charged. Three months ago I put a series of questions on notice and today I got the answer that a capital gains tax does apply, that that is the legislation and that although it may have been an unintended consequence, while the money is there the Government will put its snout in the trough and it will take a bit more off rural Australia. There is not much left to take from rural Australia.

This is devastating news for the grazing industry. Over 80 per cent of Queensland grazing land is leased. There are pastoral leases, forestry leases, household leases and other types of lease. All of the grazing land in the Northern Territory is under lease, as is much of Western Australia. Senator Panizza, a Western Australian senator, informed me that a large number of leases are held in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does capital gains tax apply to leasehold land?

—That is my point, and I am indebted to Senator Baume for pointing out that a capital gains tax will be paid on all of these leases every time they are renewed. The lease may run for 10 years and every time it is renewed a capital gains tax will be paid on it. That is a shocking state of affairs and I urge this Government to do something about it. Some grazing properties have been held in one family for over 100 years and yet as the leases are renewed the capital gains tax will still have to be paid. There are a number of leases on some properties. Three or four leases may constitute one property and a capital gains tax will have to be paid every time those leases are renewed. A grazier who has a freehold property will never have to pay the capital gains tax unless he sells it after 20 September 1985 to someone who is not in his family.

SPEECH.PARA: Many other anomalies need to be addressed and many questions need to be clarified by this Government regarding the capital gains tax. We certainly need some amendments to the capital gains tax. If this Government is not prepared to move them through both Houses of Parliament, I propose to move a private member's Bill and test it on the floor of this Parliament. We will see where the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party stand.

I want to address one other aspect of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. This legislation contains an equal opportunity clause which, in the opinion of my Party, is completely unwarranted. This clause will be inserted in the legislation of every agricultural marketing authority, including the Australian Wheat Board, the Australian Dairy Corporation, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and every other industry authority. This clause is to the effect that every authority will have an equal opportunity department within that authority investigating appointments made by the management. The equal opportunity department will be paid for by every farmer and grazier in Australia in the form of levies on their products. Although most of these farmers would be totally opposed to this type of legislation, they will be forced to pay this levy. The coalition will move an amendment, which I believe has been circulated by Senator Archer. The words of that amendment are:
. . . but not so as to permit or require any positive discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status, race, religion, or any other grounds.

If this amendment is not supported by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-and I do not believe it will be, as it was not supported in the lower House-those parties will be supporting a quota system of giving women senior positions on gender, not on ability, and discriminating against men.

When this equal opportunity legislation was introduced into the Senate, Senator Ryan told us that there would be no quotas, that we would only have equal opportunity programs and there would be no positive discrimination in the Public Service. I believe that this is not the case. I am indebted to my colleague Senator Sheil who asked questions in Senate Estimates Committee D. As recorded on page 172 of the Hansard, a Mr Taylor, in reply to a question from Senator Sheil, said that his department was working towards targets of promoting women to the Senior Executive Service. Mr Taylor said:
We do not call them quotas. We call them targets.

What is the difference between a quota and a target? I do not believe there is any. The New South Wales Labor Government is giving 40 per cent of the highest paying jobs in the Education Department to women, irrespective of their ability. That is nothing short of a quota. The New South Wales Labor Party is no different from the Federal Labor Party. The leopard never changes his spots and that is the course this Government is following.

Since you take an interest in this, Madam Acting Deputy President, I make the point that the National Party of Australia is all for equal opportunity. We believe that women are equal. Women do not need to be artificially subsidised or promoted by legislation. Women can never be made equal by legislation; it is degrading and demeaning to them. It clearly indicates to everyone that they are not capable of getting ahead under their own steam. The National Party does not subscribe to that principle at all. We believe that women and men are equal. I have asked many prominent women in business and in the grazing industries what they think about equal opportunity. They have all told me that they do not want to be treated like some disadvantaged minority group that has to depend on legislation; they want to get there on their own ability. They think this legislation is degrading, and so do I. My Party prides itself on its women parliamentarians and the contribution that they have made to the State of Queensland. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has made a similar contribution down here. They have all been excellent representatives. Our State secretaries in New South Wales and Queensland are women. All these women with whom we are associated have made the grade on their own ability, not on legislation or quotas. If the Government and the Democrats are honest about non-discrimination against any person on the grounds of sex, race, religion or anything else, they will support the Opposition's amendment. If they do not, they will discriminate against every man in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are five Bills before the Senate-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. These Bills deal with the beef industry, the sheep industry and the pork industry. But, of course, the principal interest in the Senate is in the beef industry. The interest comes from the pesticide problem that we have had in the recent past.

SPEECH.PARA: As other speakers have said in this debate this afternoon, beef is one of the really great export earners in Australia; it always has been, and has made a major contribution to the welfare of this country. When we are talking about the export earnings of beef, let us not forget that there is also a very big home market for beef consumption. I deplore the attitude of the Australian Democrats and some other people in this chamber who run down the beef industry and rural industries in general. There is an implied contempt from the Australian Democrats for anyone who gets involved in rural activity. Only yesterday or the day before, during discussion on one of the matters of public importance, they ridiculed the previous Liberal-National Party governments for having done so much to promote beef, wool and wheat as export industries in Australia. The facts of life are that they are major contributors to our export earnings. It is vitally important for a country that is on its uppers, well down the Argentinean road the way that Australia is today under the profligate spending of the Walshes, the Keatings and the Hawkes of this world, not only to maintain the markets that we have for those few products that we can sell on the free markets internationally, but also to develop and expand those markets.

Certainly, I have no argument with developing manufacturing industry. The fact that we do not have a manufacturing industry is a consequence of the rigidity in the work practices which the unions dictate to the Labor Government; we simply cannot free up the great talent in this country. There is no reason why we could not make mouse-traps, cars or all the other manufactured goods if people were allowed to work the way they want to work. But, as a country where the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) dictates what industry will do-and even more than that, dictates to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) what members of parliament will be paid, as Mr Crean, Mr Kelty and those other layabouts in the ACTU headquarters did recently-it is no wonder that we are in a state of bankruptcy.

We need to develop our manufacturing industries and our service industries-our consulting industries, our surveyors, consulting engineers and all the other services that we can render to the world. We need to develop our educational programs. But, at the end of the day, we must maintain the markets that we have. The markets that we have are good. With things like foodstuffs and primary produce, once one is pushed out of a market internationally, it is terribly difficult-if not impossible-to get back in. Since we hold markets for beef in the United States of America, Japan and various other countries, let us do all we can to support and develop them.

The export earnings of beef totalled nearly $2 billion last year, the great part of which came from my State of Queensland. The prospects for improved earnings in the immediate future are good. We need to get home consumption up. As a beef producer it amuses me how people turn to chicken. Somehow or other they think that white meat in the form of chicken is more wholesome than red meat. There is not a shred of evidence for this. In fact, all the nutritional research shows that red meat--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had some roast beef for dinner, and I thought Senator MacGibbon might like to know.

—I am delighted. No doubt that stopped Senator Tate from going to sleep this evening. It kept his haemoglobin up and kept his circulation going. I am very pleased about that. Let me make a side observation about the preparation and sale of chicken: the standards required by all the public health authorities in the States in Australia are nowhere near as strict for chicken meat as they are for beef. If people want a wholesome product, red meat should be their first choice.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that we face in rural Australia really come from the high costs of production. I do not wish to take the short time available to me tonight to reflect on all the shortcomings of the economic management of this Government but, as I said a few minutes ago, we have a very overregulated labour force. We have the highest level of tariff protection in this country, and all those costs are added on to the products that we sell from the stations, properties and farms in Australia. The difficulty is that we cannot pass on those costs. We are selling on the world market in which price is the prime parameter. Sure, quality is important but price is absolutely crucial. We have to get our costs of production down. One of the ways in which we can become competitive is for the Government to run the economy correctly. The cost of production can be reduced if we can get labour costs down and if tariffs and interest rates are reduced.

Another policy being savagely attacked at present is the decision by the Government to cut the research effort going into rural industries. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has experienced its saddest days since Mr Neville Wran was appointed as Chairman of that body. At some time in the early part of next year I will reflect at length on the shortcomings of the CSIRO under Mr Wran. But we have seen a movement away from rural research into the pursuit of more industrial research. A case can be made for doing more industrial research but we certainly need to maintain the effort that is going into rural industries.

In my own State the Tropical Crops and Pastures Division of the CSIRO-a division with which I have had quite a bit to do over the years-is losing something like 26 scientists over the next couple of years. Scientists who play an absolutely crucial role in pasture development and soil erosion control in Queensland are being axed because the Government will not recognise the great contribution that the CSIRO has made to the betterment of rural industries in Australia.

I think the beef industry stands apart from most other rural industries. Most of the people in the beef industry are strong individuals and they certainly do not have a handout mentality.
