If we look at the history of the beef industry we find that it has never been dependent on government for market controls or price support. At the other end of the scale, a great contrast can be made with the sugar industry. There has never been a more regulated industry anywhere in the world than the sugar industry, which is subject to controls over where producers can grow cane, cane quotas, prices and marketing. The whole industry is totally controlled by government regulation. Even the wool industry, with the Australian Wool Board and all the rest of it, has been dependent on government support in some way or other for more than 20 years now.

The beef industry has always stood alone; it has coped with the problems as they have arisen and it is made up of a bunch of resourceful and innovative people. One has only to look at the way in which Australian cattle herds have been bred and developed. I suppose the first brahmans were imported in the mid-1930s. A large number of British breeds, principally herefords, were introduced into the tropical areas in the mid-1950s and the early 1960s. These breeds do not do very well at all in such areas. They are not heat or tick resistant and they are not too keen to go out and feed in the heat of summer. As a result they have a slower weight gain than the bos indicus strains of cattle. One nearly goes mad if one has to drove herefords. At best this breed of cattle can be driven only something like eight to 10 miles at best each day in the heat of a Queensland summer, whereas I have moved brahman cattle something like 28 miles in a day without any problem at all.

We have seen a great change in herd development in Australia. The British breeds have been well developed in the south where the climatic conditions suit them. In the transitional areas between the more temperate regions and the tropics we have seen the development of softer breeds of cattle such as the santa gertrudis. In the northern areas, where the conditions are tough but which supply the majority of Australia's export trade, we have the dominance of the brahman breeds. This has all been done by the industry through its own resources.

Just as the industry has solved problems with cattle breeds, it has solved the pesticides problem. I would personally like to say a few things about that problem. Senator Brownhill made a noteworthy contribution to this debate a little while ago and I will not go over the ground that he covered. It is a very serious problem. The threat that it poses to our export markets cannot be underestimated. I know there are people in the industry and on both sides of this chamber who think that by talking about the pesticide problems we will undermine confidence both in the Australian consumption of beef and in our international markets. I believe very strongly that such a view is fallacious. The Australian public at present gets the best beef in the world and the beef we are selling on world markets is also, from a qualitative point of view, the best obtainable. The steps that have been taken by the industry to address the problem have been adequate and appropriate.

I would like to put the point of view that we have to maintain testing. Some people talk about the future when we will get away from analysis of beef or foodstuffs, that things will be so good that there will be no need for that. I do not share that view. We live in a world with increasingly sophisticated analytical techniques for testing chemical residues not only in beef but also in vegetables and in all foodstuffs. It is our obligation as producers and legislators not only to stay with the game but to get ahead of it-and we can get ahead of it. We have to have the sophisticated testing techniques to analyse in smaller and smaller quantities. We are getting down to quantities of parts per million of various chemicals and such things in foodstuffs. That will be an increasing requirement, through the foreseeable future, for anyone producing food. We cannot run away from the problems.

One of the things that concerns me about the pesticides problem is that there is nothing new about it. International standards have been agreed for quite a number of years. There have been numerous conferences in Australia between agriculture Ministers from the States and the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), and industry groups have discussed the problem. The procedures that have been laid down over the years are good, practical and adequate. Despite all these procedures being laid down we still had a problem. Something went wrong. It is very important for us as legislators to know precisely where the administration chain broke down. It is not a matter of a witch hunt on what chemicals are and are not dangerous or trying to apportion blame to someone or other for falling down on the job. But it is critically important for us to know what went wrong, what happened between the agreed procedures with the Commonwealth and the States, and the States that had the obligation to implement those procedures and see that at the farm level the correct use of pesticides and agricultural chemicals was observed. Quite clearly, something in the chain broke down.

It would be a fitting task for this Senate to look at that specific, narrow point-what went wrong in the administration? Unless we know clearly where the administration broke down there will be a very real risk, in fact a certainty, that we will have this problem in the future. People say that the United States in particular was playing politics, that this matter was part of the protectionist feeling in the United States, given its great balance of payments problem, and it turned on Australia. I totally reject that idea. The facts are that there are agreed international standards for chemical residues in beef. We knew those standards and we did not meet them. We could have met them. The abolition of testing in this country would do nothing to solve the problem because the purchasers of those products that we are selling in the international markets will always apply their own analytical tests to the product. So we have to know, when we ship the products, that they are right.

Putting the matter in perspective, the volume of beef that was affected, at a peak, was 0.5 per cent. It is now very much less. The residues were not at a level to affect human life. People probably would have had to eat tonnes and tonnes of beef to suffer any ill effect-and that probably would not have been a fatal effect. Nevertheless, these standards exist. The Australian industry is well able to meet them and we will just have to be able to meet them in the future.

The sad thing about this is that the beef industry ended up as the target for all the criticism on the use of pesticides in Australia. The industry, with its own resources, paid for testing plans and it has paid for the repurchase of contaminated meat overseas. It has done all that it can. There is certainly an unfair element in all this. The industry would have one or two people in it who do not follow the rules, but 99 per cent of beef producers follow the regulations that have been laid down by the various agricultural authorities in Australia. The problem often comes in the form of feed supplies. In my State of Queensland we have had a serious drought. Many producers have put cattle that were free from pesticide contamination on their properties, into feedlots. On the feedlots, they have been fed grain, some of which has been contaminated, and that is where the pesticide residues have come from.

Pesticide residues also come from some of the forage supplied on cane farms. Cane production involves a considerable use of organochlorine pesticides. That is another source of contamination coming into beef. I know that only in recent times, literally in the past few months, anyone buying grain in Queensland has been able to get any idea as to the quality. There was no way that one could say to a grain supplier, when buying grain for cattle, `Is this free of any pesticides? Will you give me a quality assurance that the grain is not contaminated with pesticides?' One would be laughed at for doing that. One either wanted the grain and bought it, as is, where is, or not. Fortunately, that is changing, but most of the problems arose indirectly in the form of feed coming into the cattle industry. There was another problem in other parts of Australia, for example, where the electricity authority went around spraying poles carrying power transmission lines with dieldrin, and cattle subsequently came along and licked them. Most of the problems arose indirectly. Nevertheless, that is not to make excuses for the industry. All these things could be dealt with, and they will have to be dealt with.

The final Bill with which I wish to deal is the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. There is a problem here in relation to annual general meetings. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) is the body that recommends the levy to be set under the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill. Currently, at least 75 per cent of producers registered with the AMLC and at least 75 per cent of processors registered with the AMLC must vote in opposition to an AMLC levy motion in order to have it defeated. The amendments in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill aim to address this problem but, in the view of most of the industry organisations, do so ineffectively. The amendments specify that a levy motion will be defeated if 75 per cent of those people present, either in proxy or in person, and in each register, oppose the motion. The Cattle Council of Australia has indicated that this provision is unsatisfactory because a minority of 25 per cent of shareholders in one of the two registers-there is a producer register and a processor register-is able to ensure that the motion is carried. That puts the onus on defeating rather than supporting the motion, whereas the reverse is the usual practice at meetings for the carriage of a motion. That apart, this parcel of legislation is very important for Australia. As all speakers have said, the meat industry is very important to Australia. It is something that deserves the closest scrutiny of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to follow my colleague and leader in the Senate, Senator Stone, in discussing these cognate Bills that relate directly to the meat and livestock industry-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill. Several amendments to be made by this legislation will have very serious effects on our great livestock industry. Like many of the other speakers, I also would like to concentrate on what I consider to be the main Bill in this package, that is, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rates of levies that may be imposed at slaughter at abattoirs. The levies cover the whole range of the livestock industry, including cattle, sheep, lambs, buffaloes, goats and bobby calves. The purpose of the levy is to raise funds to finance the activities of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and its research arm. It is worth reflecting on the substantial increases in levies imposed on the livestock industries which, in most cases, are greater than 200 per cent. In the case of the cattle industry there has been an increase from $6 to $18 to enable the purchase and disposal of meat with a high risk of containing chemical residue and to finance the anticipated expenditure by the AMLC on the initiation of a program to avoid a repetition of the recent incident in this regard.

The industry is to be congratulated on its very quick and responsible action in regard to the beef residue incident. The response has been very swift. Hundreds of thousands of tests have been carried out at an estimated cost per test of $40. Up until now the cost of the residue testing has been undertaken on a voluntary basis in each State. However, as a result of the levies, that voluntary basis will no longer operate. The AMLC has proposed that the operative levy be increased from $3.30 a head for cattle to $11.30, an increase of $8. That $8 is broken down into $3 for promotion and $5 for the residue testing procedures. It is estimated that the bottom line cost of these extra tests and Government inspections will be greater than $35m-a cost that is to be borne solely by the industry. Therein lies the fundamental flaw in the legislation which we are debating and in this Government's whole approach to primary industry.

It is quite clear that the beef industry cannot get a fair and honest deal from this Government. It has been a long and consistent policy of this Government to pay 50 per cent of all export inspection costs. It is currently doing that in other areas of primary industry. However, in this most important area the government has rejected the industry's case that it should pay 50 per cent of the cost of the increased residue testing and inspection. The fact is that the Government has backed away from its own policies at a time when this country can least afford such a backdown in regard to one of its major five export industries. This Government has to understand that if it wants to regain a good relationship with farmers and farmer organisations it has to be consistent in its policies. If its policy is to meet 50 per cent of export inspection costs, that is exactly what it must do. If it indicates to the industry that it will meet 50 per cent of the costs of residue testing, that is what it must do.

Clearly, the whole response of this Government and of the State Labor Government in Victoria has been nothing short of a disgrace and is a clear indication of the contempt with which they treat the rural industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have never worried about the farmers.

—Of course, they have not. They have never cared about farmers, as Senator Boswell rightly said. Now that the Government has gained a third term in office and now that it realises that it did not get the rural vote-the farmers' vote-it wishes clearly to turn its back on that sector. It is the sector that will not give it its vote. I certainly welcome the coalition's call for a Senate inquiry into the pesticide residue problem and the proposed terms of reference of such an inquiry. Such an inquiry would clearly show what is already known-that the farmers are not to blame for the recent residue problem but, rather, it can be traced back to the inaction of the State governments and, indeed, this Federal Government in regard to the non-removal from sale of pesticides such as DDT when they clearly knew that the use of such pesticides was not acceptable to the American markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Meanwhile, the question of compensation to the farmers who have had their properties quarantined remains unresolved. These farmers have been innocently caught up in this incident. Their livelihoods have now been threatened and their cash flows have certainly come to an almighty stop. It seems to me to be absolutely absurd that the only response that this Government can offer is in effect to increase the costs and charges upon this industry. I would have thought that the first thing this Government ought to be doing is looking at ways and means of encouraging our export industries so that they can export more and increase the value of their exports. This nation's commodity market is already finely balanced between success and failure in a very competitive world, and the last thing it needs is a government that will burden it with further costs, taxes and charges. Having said that, I say with all pride: thank goodness there is a National Party of Australia that will go in to bat for the productive industries, for the primary industries and for the working men and women of Australia.

I take issue with Senator Ray's comments yesterday when he issued his daily attack upon the National Party. He said that the National Party is no longer a country or rural party. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Nationals still are the old Country Party because we hold all our seats in rural Australia. Is the man blind? As the last election showed, in Victoria we not only regained our rural seats but we broadened our base into the regional towns of Bendigo, Traralgon and Morwell, and indeed into the city of Melbourne itself. I think Senator Ray has conveniently forgotten, and he certainly wants to forget, that Victoria returned a National Party senator at the expense of the Australian Labor Party. I suggest that Senator Ray should look at his own Party, that has gone far and wide from its roots, and even its members are willing to recognise that. I think the Labor Party has spent too much time courting the middle class trendies and greenies and it has forgotten its traditional working class roots. It had to go out and conduct polls and surveys before this was brought home to it, but it has been obvious for a very long time that it has turned its back on the working man. It saddens me to know that the once great Labor Party-we could respect it back in the 1960s when it was in opposition-is now infiltrated by radical academics, left wing teachers and party machine men and no longer has the good old time unionists who knew what work was. I welcome Senator Burns, who is about the only old time unionist from the Labor Party. He is a welcome relief from the radical academics, the left wing school teachers and the party machine men who have now infiltrated the Labor Party. Honourable senators opposite do not have to worry about the National Party. Our members were born and raised in the bush. I was born and raised in the bush.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, would you please make sure that you relate your remarks to the Bills before us.

—Certainly, Madam Acting Deputy President. I make the point clearly that the National Party does represent the bush. I think we have all spent more time in the bush than this city bound Government have has ever done, and in particular Senator Ray. Of late we have seen many other clear examples of how this Government has moved away from its interests in primary industry. Of late we have seen the slashing of the rural research division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Its scientists are certainly alarmed by what they see as a falling level of agricultural research in Australia. They claim that the farmers will soon suffer as a result of the low priority that this Government has placed on agricultural science research. Claims have been made that key research and administrative staff of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs in my State of Victoria are resigning in protest over funding priorities. The Victorian President of the Australian Institute of Agricultural Science, Mr Ian Aberdeen, said that the CSIRO cuts were part of a national trend. He claimed that the Victorian Government was also reducing support and other services to agriculture. I commend the bravery of Mr Aberdeen in speaking out. He also made a very pertinent point which is relevant to these Bills before us when he said that the value of agricultural science research was typified by its response to the chemical residue problem. He said that because we had the expertise we were able to introduce tests quickly to satisfy the Americans. He also said that this kind of expertise is now being eroded.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sick and tired of the continual attacks by this Government and its State government cohorts upon the rural community. As a National Party Victorian senator, I will not stand by and allow these events to go unheard of and unquestioned. It seems to me that this Government is just trying to pull the rural sector into line with its corporate image and ideology. Clearly, it is starting to ignore the fact that family farms have provided great benefits to the community throughout Australia's history. In addition, as is the case with small business, family farms are the dynamo of private enterprise in the rural economy. Family farms not only represent Australian ownership of our national resources but also enable individuals and families to have access to ownership of private productive property. Such access is rapidly being denied in other sectors of the economy due to the great concentration of ownership in fewer corporations and due to this Government's small business policies.

The link between ownership and work is the most powerful stimulus to personal enterprise. The integration of the family and the farm and the social and economic unit is of great social value to this country. This social-economic integration in rural Australia is unrivalled by other sectors of the economy and society. The National Party stands squarely behind the family farm concept and philosophy and it strongly rejects any suggestion, any policy, that reduces the worth of the family farm to this country. It is economically ridiculous to talk about family farms as though they need subsidies, or as though we are protecting a sacred cow. They are one of the most productive of the sectors that provide subsidies and great wealth to this nation. As we prepare to enter our bicentennial year it is time to re-affirm some of our traditions and our beliefs in the family farm. The Australian public can rest assured that the National Party stands squarely behind the rural sector and the concept of the family farm.

In conclusion, although it has been a long, traumatic and extremely costly experience for the industry it has tackled and broken the back of the residue problem on its own, with no help from this Government. It can justifiably claim that our beef has the lowest chemical residue level of any major cattle industry in the world. I support the coalition's amendments that call upon the Government to meet 50 per cent of the residue testing levy and to establish an inquiry into the pesticide residue problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for long because I understand there is quite a list of people who wish to speak on the adjournment. I rise in response to a request which I have received from a citizen of Australia who resides in New South Wales, a Mr G. G. Emblem, who is the President of a body known as the Patriotic Research Council of Australia. This is the second time that this group has approached me. In September 1985, at its request, I advised the Senate of the activities of this group of people who were then and are now running a campaign to keep the Australian flag in its present design. Of course, 1988 is our bicentennial year and it is the concern of this group of Australian citizens to continue their campaign to maintain the present flag. In 1985, I advised the Senate that the polls which the group had conducted on Anzac Day and Australia Day in 1984 and 1985 respectively and again on Anzac Day in 1985 had resulted in overwhelming support for the present Australian Flag. This little group of people have continued with their work and they have asked me again to put on the public record their results. They have indicated to me that they will be active at the official opening of the Bicentenary in Sydney and on Australia Day on 26 January 1988 and also on Anzac Day on 25 April next year. Once again they have been active in circulating petitions and polling votes and they have reported to me that the overwhelming number of people approached have again indicated their support for the present flag. They have a total of 5,817 signatures and only 228 of the nearly 6,000 people signing wanted a change to the Australian flag. As I said, at the request of Mr Emblem and his organisation I am simply advising the Senate that just as we receive many petitions from Australian citizens, that informal method of petition has indicated very strong support for the flag in the approaching bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment to comment on what was said by the Chairman of the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland in its thirty-fourth annual report. The Endeavour Foundation has been offering care and support services for intellectually handicapped people since 1951. It is recognised as Queensland's leading community agency, offering services to something over 3,000 handicapped people. The Foundation operates through 20 branches with facilities and services at 180 locations. In addition, another 56 sub-branches operate throughout the State. The services provided by the Endeavour Foundation include clinical support services, educational facilities, accommodation, employment and occupation and future care. It has a staff of some 872 full time and part time employees plus an army of 3,000 volunteer workers.

SPEECH.PARA: About a year ago this Government notified the Endeavour Foundation that it would make far-reaching changes to virtually all of the Foundation's existing tried, trusted and valued services. The organisation has been given five years to realign itself, to fit some new, ill-defined services types and philosophical thrust deemed more appropriate by the Labor Government in distant Canberra. It has been informed that if it does not make these enormous changes it will most likely have its subsidies cut or even removed. The Endeavour Foundation has objected strenuously about this unwarranted imposition and intrusion on its organisation. It has been further hampered by having to deal with ever-changing senior staff in the Department of Community Services and Health as well as three different Ministers in the past 12 months. Why is it that the present Labor Government seeks to disrupt totally what can only be described as the biggest success story in community care in Queensland? It can only be a case of callous interference in a popular organisation which has a proven track record of success.

Let me expand more on the facilities and services offered by the Endeavour Foundation. The organisation has 27 activity therapy centres, 21 sheltered workshops-I might just comment on that: in my days before I entered this place I made a point of using the Endeavour Foundation for smallish-type jobs, for instance wrapping up company newspapers and making things like survey pegs by the thousand-8 sheltered farms, 13 family group homes, 52 adult residentials, 14 clinic services and 17 special schools. Clients involved in farm activity work in small crop production, horticulture, grading and packaging produce and poultry and cattle activities.

In 1987, sales of workshop and farm products brought in $6.6m. Four new activity therapy centres were opened during last year in Cairns, Caboolture, Kingaroy and Roma, which brought the total number for the whole State to 27, a very impressive number. The Endeavour Foundation has always sought to give intellectually handicapped persons opportunities to participate in the community at large to the maximum of their potential. Examples of the sorts of activities they can become involved in are: a local toastmasters' club, a State emergency services squad, a CB radio club and local sports and arts and crafts clubs. The Foundation has a history of very successful fund raising and attracts support from station TVO in Brisbane and a string of regional television stations for its Statewide telethon appeal. Another successful appeal is its tiny tots quest. This year it raised $6.5m, which is up almost $1m on the amount it raised the previous year.

I give this background to illustrate and to emphasise the fact that the Endeavour Foundation is an outstanding organisation which operates in a most professional manner. It is a privately run community organisation which is held in the highest regard in the community throughout Queensland. The last thing it needs is to be told by a far-off government that its mode of operation and, indeed, its philosophical basis is to be moved to accommodate the whims of that government body. These demands have caused great concern to the Endeavour Foundation and I urge the Government to reconsider its most unfortunate decision which will adversely affect people in genuine need in the community-the intellectually handicapped.

In a similar vein, I refer to the treatment of parents of children who are severely intellectually handicapped. The Department of Health and Community Services seems to have no recognition whatsoever that there are people who are so severely handicapped they will never be able to take their place in the community under any circumstances. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter of frustration from such a parent to the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
18 Albar Street,
Wavell Heights, 4012
22 November 1987
The Honourable Dr N. Blewett M.P.,
Minister for Health and Community Services
Dear Minister,

My wife Mrs Robin Lynch and I are the parents of a multiply handicapped, severely intellectually disabled young man of seventeen years. For the last eighteen months or thereabouts a Joint Task Group of the Uniting Church and the Catholic Church and some parents on behalf of severely disabled teenage children have been meeting in Brisbane. We have attended these meetings as advocates of our son. The Joint Task Group is engaged in planning for the establishment of suitable residential and training facilities for the severely disabled of teenage years. We met last evening-21 November. Miss Kris Sullivan of the Department of Community Services in Brisbane attended the meeting by invitation.

We count ourselves among the people who have demonstrated our acceptance of the principles of the disability legislation brought in by your Government as we had previously refused offers of places for our son in State institutions for the intellectually handicapped. But there are aspects of the New Directions policies which we find unclear. As we are anxious to know, if the planning of the Joint Task Group is not to be futile, what are the parameters of models acceptable to the Department, I pressed Miss Sullivan concerning these policies. She told me that the meeting was not the place to go into those questions and suggested I should come and discuss them with her further. In the course of further discussion with other members of the Task Group she stated that the Department has no plans established to guide the implementation of the disability policies and will see what develops over the five year period. I expressed strong disapproval of such lack of policy as I see it as social experimentation affecting people who are among the most vulnerable in society. I made it clear that my disapproval of the attitude was directed against the decision and that I realised that Miss Sullivan was not responsible for it.

Nevertheless, after a lapse of some twenty minutes and following discussion on other points raised by a minister of the Uniting Church in which we took no part, Miss Sullivan turned to my wife and I who were sitting some distance from her. Addressing us as ``you people'' (although she had been introduced to us on our arrival and she had had dealing with my wife as Chairman of a Demonstration Project) Miss Sullivan told us that she had put up with expressions of anger from us directed at her personally, that she had come to the meeting in her own time to help the Uniting Church and that she did not thing she should have to put up with such anger. I told her that my anger was directed at the way in which policies were being applied with no clear goals. She told us she did not wish to hear from us again. I realise that I was mistaken as to why Miss Sullivan was at the meeting. I understand the New Direction policies require the consumers or their advocates to be listened to and I thought that was the reason she was there, not to help the Uniting Church.

In any case, Minister, the consequence is that communication between the advocates of one disabled person and the Department has been cut off by the Department. You will realise how difficult the group's forward planning becomes when the authority which must approve the proposal has no clear parameters or goals. It is like seeking building permission from a local authority without building bylaws. I appeal to you to intervene personally in this situation which we find stressful and counterproductive. Please have the Department establish its goals applicable to the establishing of facilities for the training and development of severely multiply disabled young adults.
Yours faithfully
Kevin Lynch

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Parer. The Foundation does very interesting work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to comment on the activities that have taken place in recent weeks at the World Heritage Committee meetings in Paris. It was very pleasing that Uluru National Park was formally listed on the World Heritage List. Of course, this had the support of the Commonwealth Government, the Northern Territory Government and, I am sure, the majority of people and interest groups right throughout Australia. However, the listing of stage 2 of Kakadu is a controversial matter and has attracted wide criticism and support from different groups throughout the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the way in which the Commonwealth Government has launched into a series of very personal attacks on the Northern Territory Government and Northern Territory Ministers in the past few weeks is disgraceful. Not only Commonwealth Ministers but also other members of the Australian Labor Party have taken this tack. For example, on 2 December Mr Ede, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, said that Mr Coulter, the Northern Territory Minister for Mines, was in Paris denigrating the Top End. He said that `he was bad-mouthing the Territory around the rest of the world'. On 8 December in the other place the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, described the efforts of Mr Coulter as `those to ravage and vandalise one of the most important environmental areas in Australia'. On 10 December he described the Northern Territory Government as a `ridiculous team of vandals from the Northern Territory'. On 10 December the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, said:
Both parks have been the targets of staggeringly expensive and, at times, stunningly racist propaganda campaigns by successive Northern Territory governments.

He further said that they were ill-advised and foolhardy campaigns against the World Heritage listing and that the Northern Territory Government had displayed its usual disregard for the protection of the environment. He further stated:
It is the Northern Territory Government which is both flawed and fraudulent.

These statements are blatantly untrue. They are incorrect. They are seen to be disgraceful if the real record is examined. We should be looking carefully at and reviewing the procedures that took place at the meetings in Paris. Last week the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, made a statement that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service controls the Kakadu National Park. He said:
It is a Commonwealth responsibility. It has nothing to do with the Northern Territory.

What does Minister Brown think it is all about? He seems to be putting the clock back by saying that Kakadu is a Commonwealth responsibility. Does he think that things cannot happen without co-operation and that there cannot be an involvement of the appropriate State authorities in matters such as this? These Commonwealth Government arguments are flawed and fraudulent.

Barry Coulter, the Northern Territory Minister for Mines, was in Paris arguing hard and strong, just as he and his team did last year for the important issues in the Kakadu stage 2 proposals. He was arguing for the standards and conditions that should be consistent with World Heritage conventions and how they should be met. He went there with a scientific document in which was incorporated submissions from some 15 eminent scientists. These covered natural values in such areas as surface geology, geomorphology and land systems, vegetation communities, floristics and mangrove assemblages, rare and threatened plants and animals, mammals, reptiles, amphibians, bird populations including water birds, feral animals, weeds, macro invertebrates, fishes and aesthetic impact. The cultural values relating to Aboriginal cultural heritage and Aboriginal sites were also well covered. The documentation was extensive and comprehensive and it argued very strongly in these areas. But the Commonwealth Government walked in and asked the World Heritage Committee to take the matter, site unseen. It had not presented the case. No members of the World Heritage Committee's advisory body had visited or looked at the area. The Government had merely allowed the listing to flow from the original submission on Kakadu stage 1. The Government had extended the original proposals that were in that submission. It did deals with Mr Whitlam, the former Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, and built up an old-boy network in Paris. During the last week it certainly became evident as to how this was put together.

What we need to do is ask what this listing has achieved or cost. It has certainly cost Australia more than $1 billion in lost mineral resources. It shuts the door forever on mining in the Kakadu stage 2 area. Surprisingly, there was a flow through to stage 3 and to further areas of Arnhem Land. Very surprisingly, again this area of consultation had not been picked up. For all of the Federal Government's pious attitude to Aboriginals and the very fine statement that Mr Hand handed down last week about consultation with Aborigines, the Government had not bothered to consult. This new surprise of looking further for listings has taken the Northern Land Council and the Aboriginal land owners in the area by surprise. Certainly these comments came out in various statements in the media and the Aborigines have expressed their surprise. Of course, any further World Heritage listing for Arnhem Land would be of great concern to the Aborigines in the area.

There is a very important point of principle involved with regard to consultation with the States. In 1984 the Commonwealth Labor Government gave a commitment at the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers that it would not proceed to listings without consent of the various State authorities. We have seen that being demonstrated in this case and in north Queensland and elsewhere. There has been a complete failure to get involved but in this particular case the Government has gone further. At this stage it has not provided a regime for the management of Kakadu stage 2. Where is it? How will they manage it? How is it to be done? Does the Government believe that any management of an area so big and so vital to the Northern Territory can be proceeded with without the co-operation and the involvement of the Northern Territory Government and its statutory authorities, the Aboriginal land owners and the other people in the area? Where is the management document? Where is the plan of management? Where are the issues? The Government expects us to take these things on blind faith. It has created a very important precedent this time by allowing this extension to stage 1 to incorporate Kakadu stage 2. Not only has the Commonwealth Government embarrassed various governments and various groups in Australia, but also it has caused serious embarrassment to the World Heritage Committee. How will things be dealt with in future? I understand that there was concern in debates on this issue in Paris about the procedures involved, about the way in which this had been bulldozed through and the way in which the Committee was severely embarrassed because the procedures of the Australian Government were not in keeping with normal practice.

As I mentioned earlier, the documentation the Northern Territory Government put before the World Heritage Committee forms a very comprehensive document. It is in three parts. It outlines in detail the specific location of the area, the nomination, the purpose for the submission, the basis for making the submission, the status of the Northern Territory, the Aboriginal land considerations, the world heritage proposals, the world heritage procedure, the consultation, the process for nominating Australian properties and the Aboriginal traditional owners. The documentation goes into the details, the criteria, the convention, the consideration of the issues, the nomination and the evidence in support of the Territory's submission, the resources available, the evidence of there being no immediate danger to the area and the various scientific proposals which argued about so many different issues. I seek leave to table for future reference this important submission to the World Heritage Committee, and I invite comparisons with the documentation that has been submitted by the Commonwealth Government. The comparison of the documentation belies the inadequate, incorrect and stupid statements of many members of the Australian Labor Party in the last fortnight.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address two matters tonight. The first is Afghanistan. As honourable senators will be aware, at this very moment there is being played out on the eastern perimeter of Afghanistan a life and death siege of a town called Khost, which has a population of some 40,000 and which has been under attack by mujahedeen resistance fighters for some three weeks. They have successfully surrounded the town, and the end result is that the Soviets are desperately trying to air lift supplies into that area. But that is just a symbol of what is happening in Afghanistan, and what has been happening since the Soviet invasion on 27 December 1979. Tonight I want to draw attention to what I regard as the very disappointing response of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on this issue. I believe that he missed a golden opportunity to exert some real influence while he was in the Soviet Union. Instead, as one might have expected, he settled for a few grand public relations gestures and a few flattering camera angles. He was content to accept what was put to him on the issue; he simply went through the motions. In my view he has been played for a sucker by Mr Gorbachev on the issue of Afghanistan. He simply accepted a few honeyed words from the Soviet leader and let the matter lie.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the starkly apparent refusal of the Soviet Union to negotiate a meaningful withdrawal, what is required is for the Prime Minister to express his disapproval of the unacceptable preconditions which have been attached to Soviet military withdrawal. The Press has tended to suggest that all that is required is for a timetable to be set. Mr Gorbachev, in his meetings with President Reagan, was prepared to come lower than the usual 15 to 18 months and to offer a 12-month withdrawal period. We were told that the talks then stalled on the basis of the starting point.

It is not quite as simple as that. The reality is that the Soviets also insist on two principal conditions: first, that the United States of America should stop all aid to the Islamic resistance forces-the mujahedeen; and, secondly, that it should support the formation of an interim coalition government under the leadership of the Soviet-backed People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. That party is simply a Soviet puppet. It is the private outfit of Mr Najibulla, formerly the head of the secret police in Afghanistan, which everyone knows would not last more than a few days if Soviet support were withdrawn.

It is therefore clear that, whilst Mr Gorbachev is prepared to indulge in an orgy of moral hand wringing on the issue and to make it appear to the Western world that somehow he is desperately anxious to extricate himself from the morass, he has not done anything tangible since his speech in Vladivostok in July 1985. I would have thought that 18 months was a fairly reasonable time in which to have taken action, especially if it is suggested that the whole withdrawal process can be accomplished in a 12-month period. Therefore, I think it should be apparent, even to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), that Mr Gorbachev is simply not serious. He is wanting to delude Western opinion into thinking that somehow the Soviets are about to accede to Western pressure and that, therefore, there is no need for the West to concentrate attention on the issue. The reality, of course, is that he is playing for totally unacceptable conditions. The Prime Minister has either refused or neglected to see through that approach.

It is very disappointing when one puts that alongside the response of the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, who steadfastly refused to raise the issue with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, when he was out here earlier this year. Mr Hayden was adamant in his refusal to condemn the Soviet invasion on its anniversary in December last year, despite a number of other Western nations being prepared to express their outrage. I think it all shows a picture of an Australian government not prepared to take the issue seriously. Whether the Prime Minister has taken this position because there are only 1,500 Afghans in Australia and the Australian Labor Party does not think it is likely to get a majority of support from them at Federal election time, I do not know. But the reality is that the Prime Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty cheap.

—Well, I would have thought that most things about the Labor Party are explained by looking at the numbers. The Minister was a fortunate beneficiary not so long ago and he knows how close things can get if the numbers do not quite add up at the time. I would have thought that there has to be some fairly blunt political reason for Mr Hawke's otherwise inexplicable refusal to tackle this very serious issue. He may think that Australian-Soviet trade is more important. But there are moral issues in international politics, and this is one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought, if one had regard to the recent vote in the General Assembly which was something of the order of 122 against and 19 for the Soviet position, that Mr Hawke would want to be on that bandwagon. He is very good at trying to curry favour with the majority. One would have thought that this was a very good opportunity for him at least to express his disapproval of the Soviet procrastination. But, no, all we had was a lip service mention of it in a Press conference, and that is that. I for one regard that as a very disappointing and totally inadequate response.

I would now like to touch briefly on Telecom Australia's proposal for timed local calls. It is interesting that, ahead of the announcement that will be made tomorrow by Telecom of the various options involved in timed local calls, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans has today, for the first time, put down some rational thoughts on the subject which provide a basis for sensible discussion. He said that more than 82 per cent of all local calls presently take six minutes or less while more than 88 per cent take eight minutes or less. He thought that the vast majority of users would therefore be beneficiaries of timed local calls because the pulse or timed interval would be something around the six to eight minute mark and those calls, therefore, were likely to cost less than 20 cents. I would have thought that to be a starting point. It may not be where we end up. It may well be that the whole issue will be dead and buried before it gets off the ground.

But I want to deplore the orgy of political opportunism that has been indulged in by various State Ministers and Premiers in recent days-all of them, Labor. All are determined to ring every possible inch of milage-if I can use that expression-out of this issue. It is quite clear that they see it as a populist crusade, one that has some cheap votes in it. The very real danger in this approach is that the whole concept of restructuring cross subsidies, of looking at where the burden falls, will be lost in a welter of political opportunism.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the questions from your side at Question Time? Do they not fall into the same category?

—We are entitled to legitimately flesh out some of the difficulties that arise with the proposal. Unless and until we have the sorts of rational contributions that at last have been made by Senator Evans, there really is not much more than a fear campaign. Understandably, I suppose, in that sort of vacuum, people are going to draw attention to the dangers that might be inherent in the proposal. I think there are some pluses that deserve to be taken seriously. This will provide an opportunity to restructure, to ease the burden on STD users and subscribers in rural and remote areas. My colleague, Senator Panizza, for example, says he believes the current system is operating quite unfairly in a number of rural areas. He is forced to pay $1.80 a minute for STD calls to Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: All of this problem arises because of the outmoded structure of cross-subsidisation that places an inordinately heavy burden on STD users, the majority of whom, in terms of frequency, are businesses. We can all deplore the fact that businesses appear to have a large capacity to pay but the reality is that they also have a much greater ability to circumvent present arrangements. That is precisely what we are seeing at present. They are now prepared to install private networks, make much greater use of satellites, and, in many ways, circumvent the whole basis of the existing cross-subsidisation. Once that capacity to milk the STD users is gone, conversely there is a much lesser ability to subsidise local users. Local users are not all pensioners and disadvantaged people. They are often middle class users. I suppose most of us here represent the middle classes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except Senator McGauran. He represents the rural workers.

—All manner of interests are represented here tonight. No doubt Senator Tate's Tasmania is in a class of its own in that regard. At the moment the structure is quite scatter-gun in its approach. It does not take account of real needs or the capacity to pay. Perhaps one of the best examples I have come across in recent times is that the holiday resort of Orpheus Island where, in reality, it costs something like $15,000 for a new connection, is charged only the maximum rate of $1,300. That is ridiculous. Similarly, internationally-owned cattle stations in remote areas that again have a great capacity to pay are able, because of this blunt approach, to get connections at a much lower fee. The time has long since passed when we can ignore the ramifications of cross-subsidisation.

SPEECH.PARA: One further matter that is worth looking at is the announcement today that the Western Australian Government anticipates that it will save about $35m by installing its own local equivalent of Queensland's Q-net. The Victorian Government has recently announced the creation of Visitel, and those three States-and inevitably, I would have thought, others-will jump on the same bandwagon. In other words they are rebelling. They are prepared to install private networks that will service all government departments. That will create a very serious leak or bleeding in Telecom's revenue capacity. As a result, a much greater burden will be put on the system.

That is why I think that it is scandalous that people of the order of the Victorian Premier, who is no doubt desperately concerned about an imminent State election, talk in the way that he did today. He described the proposal as an insult, suggesting that, somehow, it was all about punishing pensioners. That sort of nonsense is not only mischievous but dishonest. I deplore those sorts of self-serving contributions. Grandstanding for the purposes of election campaigning may be understandable in some contexts, but it will be a national tragedy if this proposal is still-born because it has been kicked to death by vested interests and State Premiers. I hope that there will be a lot greater concentration on the economic implications of the proposal and much less political opportunism on the part of State Labor governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate, a jewel in Victoria, and that is the township of Koroit. Nestled in the Western District of Victoria, Koroit is a most picturesque township, with a proud history. The development of Koroit began back in the 1850s. It began with William Rutledge surveying the district around Koroit. Following this survey, many labourers were brought out from Ireland to work the land. Those early Irish labourers or tenant farmers of the nineteenth century eventually came to own the land they once worked. Most of those farms are today owned by descendants of the early Irish settlers. Therein lies the charm and mystic attraction of Koroit.

SPEECH.PARA: The town features many grand old homes and is presently transforming the old council buildings into a museum and library to celebrate its proud Irish heritage. Famous Irish names of Koroit include the Maddens, Collins, O'Tooles, Gavins, Gleesons and Mugavins. I am sure there would be Ryans, Duffys and O'Briens also in the township.

If Koroit is the jewel of Victoria, then one fine Irish lass, Siobhan Bourke, is the jewel of Koroit. Siobhan Bourke has taken the Miss Victoria crown for 1988. It is a fine tribute to all who have an Irish heritage that Siobhan Bourke is representing Victoria in this nation's bicentennial year. Siobhan Bourke is the daughter of Micky and Ellen, owners of the well-known `Micky Bourke's' Koroit Hotel. I am informed the pub serves green beer on St Patrick's Day. I wish Miss Siobhan all the luck of the Irish in her quest for the Miss Australia crown, to be judged in Albury on 12 February.

Mr President, at this time, it is worthy to mention that some time ago I attended the Melbourne Celtic Club's 100 years celebration. Besides having a thoroughly enjoyable time, the difficulty of the Irish in migrating to Australia was brought to my attention. I have since investigated this concern and found a strong case for such a concern. How ironic that the Irish, who first settled this country-some by choice and some not by choice; but certainly all were fine contributors to early Australia-should now have difficulty doing so.

As we prepare to enter our bicentennial year, it is a time to reaffirm our beliefs in traditional Australia and those Australians who have contributed to our traditions-and the Irish people are so much a part of traditional Australia. I have asked Mr Mick Young, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, for comment on this matter, and I am still waiting for a reply. I believe that this Prime Minister, who calls Ireland his spiritual home and calls his Cabinet `the Irish Cabinet', should hang his head in shame-along with the other members of his Government; the lot of them-for their neglect of Irish migrants. Name alone is not enough to call oneself Irish; one must also have the Irish soul. I would like to conclude with an Irish proverb for Mr Hawke's Irish Cabinet: May you be in heaven half an hour before the Devil knows you're dead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words tonight about the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) in the light of some recent attacks that have been made on the Institute, which I believe have been quite scurrilous. I refer particularly to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 December by Tony Sarno, which was headed `Sports Factory Flop'. That article was unbalanced, highly selective, totally negative and based on unsubstantiated evidence which in any event appeared to be several years old. Much of the article seemed to be based on comments or quotes from Don Talbot, who was an early coach with the Institute but who left as long ago as 1983 to coach the Canadian swimming team.

SPEECH.PARA: The article completely ignored the positive results that the Institute has achieved in the past couple of years. Last night in Melbourne the 1987 Sports Australia Awards were announced. It is very interesting to note the representation of the AIS amongst those award winners. One dozen awards were made, of which two or three were in a category which could not, by their very nature, be awarded to AIS athletes or people associated with the AIS. Setting those aside, AIS sports men and women last night won the following awards. Kerry Saxby won the Female Athlete of the Year Award in athletics. Sarah Fitzgerald won the Junior Female Athlete of the Year Award for squash. Jason Stoltenberg won the Junior Male Athlete of the Year Award for tennis. He is the number one junior in the world and winner of the Wimbledon Junior Championships this year. Richard Aggiss won the Coach of the Year Award for men's hockey. The Team of the Year Award was won by the men's hockey team, and 11 of that team were either past or present AIS scholarship holders. The Junior Team of the Year Award given at last night's Sports Australia Awards was won by the girls 16 years and under tennis team. All the girls in that team are full time scholarship holders with the AIS.

Those latest awards follow many other notable achievements by AIS scholarship holders. I will mention just a few of them. AIS swimmers won seven gold medals at the 1986 Commonwealth Games and provided nearly 50 per cent of the successful 1987 Australian Pan Pac swimming team. AIS trained athletes at the 1986 Commonwealth Games won two gold medals in weightlifting, two gold in rowing, and one gold in diving, as well as numerous silver and bronze medals in these sports. Ten of the 12 members of Australia's netball team, which won the World Championship in 1984, 1985 and 1986 and was the runner-up in 1987, were AIS trained. Three of the men's rowing eight which won the 1986 World Championship were AIS trained, and the whole eight members of the crew undertook their final preparation at the AIS. Three of the women's rowing four which won the 1986 World Championship were AIS trained. Twelve of the 18 world youth soccer squad which made the final series in Chile were Institute trained.

The Sarno article in the Sydney Morning Herald also talked about poor coaching at the Institute. He totally ignored-he made no reference at all-to the following success stories. Richard Aggiss coached Australia's men's hockey team to the 1986 World Championship win. It was Aggiss who, last night, won the Coach of the Year, Sports Australia Award. Brian Glencross coached Australia's women's hockey team to second place in the 1986 World Championship. Wilma Shakespear coached Australia's netball team to world championship wins three years in a row, in 1984, 1985, 1986 and the runner up position in 1987. Reinhold Batschi coached Australia's men's rowing eight to a 1986 World Championship win. Peter Shakespear coached Australia's women's rowing four to its 1986 World Championship win. All of those are AIS coaches.

Sarno in his article also totally omitted to mention some of the other top flight coaches associated with the Institute, including probably the two greatest squash players the world has known in Geoff Hunt and Heather McKay; Bill Sweetenham for swimming; Ray Ruffles, the tennis coach; and Pat Clohessy, the middle and long distance running coach; Ju-Ping tian, the women's gymnastics coach; and Adrian Hurley, the basketball coach.

The Sarno article was a selective, distorted and emotive disgrace. However, it was not atypical of some of the criticisms that have been levelled at the AIS in recent times. Undoubtedly there is room for improvement at the Institute, despite what has already been achieved. The Institute receives a large amount of taxpayers' funds. Indeed, since it was set up by the Fraser Government in, I think, 1981, the Institute has received close on $70m of taxpayers' funds. Therefore, it must be required to demonstrate to the public that it is using these funds effectively and efficiently. For a period in the mid 1980s there was very proper concern that not all aspects of the Institute's activities, particularly the financial aspects, were under control. The appointment last year of Mr Ron Harvey to head the Institute has corrected that problem. As well, the Institute has produced a strategic plan covering the next few years-a plan that had not been produced before but which was very badly needed. Morale at the Institute which had been going downhill has been improved dramatically in the last 12 months or so. The Institute has come a long way in the past couple of years. No doubt, it can do better. Hopefully it will.

Of course, the Institute should not be immune from criticism when criticism is due. However, that criticism should be objective and balanced and it should be based on facts. I am afraid-I regret-that some of the recent criticisms, particularly those by Mr Sarno, fail to meet any of those three criteria. Whether it is another example of the Australian syndrome of `chop down the tall poppies', I do not know, but if we are going to have our institutions denigrated without any due and proper basis for criticism then I think we do ourselves a disservice. I hope that we can, at least as far as the Australian Institute of Sport is concerned, get away from that very damaging and negative approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss a serious deficiency in the provision of health care to the frail and aged in nursing homes and hostels. The deficiency to which I refer concerns the failure by the present Government to provide even a basic care and maintenance dental service to our aged. It is a failure which I would have thought would have been totally unacceptable to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1 July this year nursing homes became subject to new Commonwealth funding arrangements. From that date all nursing homes, whether State owned or private, have been subsidised by the Commonwealth on a patient per day basis. As a result of a Commonwealth-State working party on nursing home standards which reported in June 1987 a number of `outcome standards' were set to which nursing homes must comply if they are to receive Commonwealth funding. Outcome standard 1.8 requires nursing homes to ensure that: `Residents are enabled to maintain oral and dental health'. The standard then lists a number of considerations. Firstly, there must be evidence of attention to oral hygiene. Secondly, dentures must be correctly fitted in accordance with the resident's needs and preferences, cleaned as required, discreetly labelled and correctly stored when not in use. Finally, residents have access to treatment for dental and periodontal conditions. It is clear, however, that no resident will be able to maintain oral and dental health as required by the standard unless that person has regular access to a dental practitioner for the purpose of check-ups.

In Western Australia the only dental care provided to nursing home residents comes from a resident's own practitioner-if indeed that person has a private practitioner-or if that person has a family which cares enough to take that resident to the family dentist. The Perth dental hospital does operate a single domiciliary unit; however, this is a treatment based service which operates only on demand. Further, the unit is required to meet the needs of the entire community-not only those in nursing homes or hostels but also those non-ambulatory persons who reside in their own homes. For the domiciliary unit to come to a nursing home there must be a dental problem identifiable by the nursing sister. The fault with this is, of course, that nursing home staff are simply not trained to detect dental problems. They can see if a resident is physically ill or in pain; dental neglect, however, is often invisible. Therefore, unless dental pain is brought to the attention of the nursing sister by the resident, that person will receive no dental care whatsoever. One blatant illustration of dental neglect that was recently brought to my notice concerned a 91-year-old nursing home resident. She told a visiting dentist that he was the first dental practitioner she had seen since she had arrived at the home some 14 years previously.

In 1986 the Western Australian Oral Needs Survey, showed that 25 per cent of those persons 65 and over were dentate or part dentate. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figure in 1979 was 14.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that word?

—The proportion of our aged who are dentate is improving. At present, however, at least 75 per cent of those over 65 wear dentures. I will read on, and Senator Tate will then understand. The Nursing Homes and Hostels Review in 1986 indicated that there were 73,000 persons in aged care accommodation throughout Australia, and that they represented about 5 per cent of the total aged population of 1.6 million people. This means that around 55,000 nursing home and hostel residents are required to wear dentures.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that one of the considerations under the nursing home outcome standards concerned care for dentures. Nursing home staff are required to ensure that dentures are correctly fitted, cleaned and stored. Once again, however, nursing sisters are not trained sufficiently well in dental care to perform even this basic task. One shocking example of denture neglect that was recently brought to my notice concerned a nursing home resident who had a bolus of calculus half the size of a ping pong ball lodged in his lower denture. I am sure Senator Tate will understand what that looks like and what it is. When the examining dentist showed its presence to the senior nursing sister-a sister of some 35 years standing-she said it had been there 8 years ago and she thought it was simply part of the denture. This is not the fault of the nursing sisters. I am sure they are well trained in caring for the aged and they do a very fine job in most demanding circumstances. Nursing sisters, however, are not adequately trained in dental care and hygiene and cannot be expected to take the place of a properly qualified dental practitioner. Dental hygiene problems encountered in nursing homes will expand and proliferate in future years as the fruits of improved and modern dental techniques begin to show on our aging population. Australia's aged will have less need for prosthetic services, and a greater need for maintenance and restorative services for their own teeth.

It is quite clear that nursing home staff are not sufficiently-if at all-trained in dental care. If they cannot identify neglect of a person's dentures when part of their task is to clean them, how can they be expected to be aware of problems with a resident's own teeth? Plainly, it is impossible. What is required is for this Government to provide, or undertake to fund the State governments so they can provide, a dental care and maintenance service. This most basic and necessary of health care services must entail at the very least an examination of the resident on admission to a nursing home and regular examinations by a dental practitioner thereafter. I believe that it is not appropriate for this Government to seek to avoid responsibility by passing the buck to the State governments. As we know, the Commonwealth subsidises nursing homes. As part of its commitment to do so it has set certain outcome standards which must be achieved by nursing homes if indeed they are to receive Commonwealth funding. One of these standards requires the nursing home to ensure that a resident is able to maintain oral and dental health. This cannot be done unless each resident has access to a regular dental care and maintenance service. The Commonwealth has undertaken the responsibility to set the standards for nursing homes. The Commonwealth must provide sufficient funds to see that these standards can be attained and then maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1177), Senator Harradine asked me as the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the clinical study conducted at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital which revealed that a number of abortions have been performed on pregnant women who have been disappointed with the sex of their baby as indicated by chorionic villus sampling tests? Is it a fact that most of the aborted foetuses were female? Have the abortions been performed at taxpayers' expense through the Medical Benefits Schedule? What action is proposed by the Government in respect of this grave matter?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question.

My attention has been drawn to an article in the ``Australian Dr Weekly'' which refers to a clinical trial on chorionic villus sampling conducted by a Dr Tom Boogert of the King George V Hospital for Mothers and Children in Sydney. The article mentions that five women, who participated in the trial, decided to terminate their pregnancies because they felt that their foetus was of ``inappropriate sex''. The article states that dissatisfaction was expressed in relation to both male and female foetuses.

I am unable to say whether these specific pregnancy terminations attracted Medicare benefits. While the Medicare Benefits Schedule includes items for medical services which may result in the termination of pregnancy and Medicare benefits are payable where medical expenses are incurred as a result of the provision of such medical services, doctors who perform these services do so within the framework of the laws of the relevant State or Territory, and neither the Commonwealth Government nor the Health Insurance Commission intrude into patient-doctor relationship by way of requiring details of the medical circumstances surrounding the provision of a service to a patient.

While I am concerned at the alleged findings of the trial, as reported in the ``Australian Dr Weekly'', doctors undertaking any procedure for the termination of a pregnancy must do so in accordance with the laws of the relevant State or Territory.

As a national health insurance scheme Medicare must cover a large number of medical services which are rendered in a diversity of circumstances. For these reasons Medicare is not intended as an instrument for resolving the complex issues raised by abortion and in particular those arising from the ability to obtain genetic and other information very early in pregnancy. The question of whether it is appropriate or desirable for abortions to be performed in the circumstances outlined in the ``Australian Dr Weekly'' article is an additional social dilemma imposed by the emergence of new technology upon an already complex legal and moral matter. Society must make judgements about the balance of benefits and undesirable outcomes as these new developments occur. Of necessity, governments made broad appraisals for public policy purposes which may not be capable of reflecting fully each different circumstance.

It is recognition of these broad and difficult issues that has influenced all State and Commonwealth Health Ministers to agree at the Australian Health Ministers' Conference to the establishment of a national bio-ethics consultative committee which will consult widely and advise governments on the development of appropriate public policies.
